Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy Remastered
...David Cage is weird...

Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy is an adventure game from the prestigious David Cage of Heavy Rain and Beyond Two Souls fame.

Despite its original release in 2005 and this remaster released  in 2015 the game still very dated. Not in a performance or visual way but in its overall feeling or vibe. You can use gamepad or mouse and keyboard, typically I don't bother to bring this subject up but other than the obvious differences. The game actually plays quite differently. As in you have direct analog control with a gamepad and should you choose to play with mouse and keyboard (as I did) You will be greeted with tank controls. Which can be a bit jarring when camera control is taken away from you and to the games credit it when it is taken away the camera seems to direct you in very helpful ways as to not get you lost but does indeed take some getting used to try and find your roots again with tank controls.

The game has this feeling of Resident Evil mixed with Eternal Darkness. Both because the general horror nature of the game and Eternal Darkness because there is a mechanic in which you must monitor your every action as it effects the mental fortitude of the player character.

You play as 1 of 3 characters. Lucas Kane, Carla Valenti, or Tyler Miles. You switch in between them after their specific sequence is over. In the beginning it feels a bit odd. As if you are being forced to take a side. As you probably know, its in the trailer, it happens in the first 5 minutes, this game is old; its not a spoiler but Lucas Kane murders a man in a bathroom. Carla and Tyler are the detectives assigned to the case. So right from the very get go you are given subtle clues as to which side you wish  take as well as have plenty of character moments. This is a David Cage game after all and every little decision means something down the line.

The main interaction with the game is walking around and finding clues or talking with people. Action sequences are either directional quicktime events, a sort fake simon says game or a test of endurance by pressing left and right a bunch. There is also a couple of sequences which I didn't find very enjoyable and tested my patience quite a bit. Without saying anything explicit, it involved moving very slowly, regulating your breath and searching for a clue relevant to the situation.

There is also some VERY strange sequences with licensed music. Specifically with the band Theory of a Deadman, a band I listened to in High School. It felt very strange, maybe a little forced but in all honesty is wasn't the first time the game started to feel a bit campy and stop taking itself so seriously.

THE GIST
Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy is a very good adventure game, though in all honesty my ending did not feel very satisfying. The story goes places I never would have guessed and in my story one character had a very dramatic change of character that felt incredibly forced as if it was just something people expected from a blockbuster film. It made zero sense and I'm completely baffled by it. However its more a of a sub plot thing even though its alluded to as otherwise.

Very old feeling adventure game but with some modern convenience. Sort of tows the line between nostalgia and something that telltale might do. Voice acting is well done but some of the sequences repeat if you ask too many questions I couldn't tell if it was a bug or just to reiterate things so you didn't forget them.

The games has some problems but the story is engaging and the characters are rather interesting so the small issues it does have can be overlooked.

Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy Remastered

It starts with what is probably the greatest opening I've ever seen in a video game, continues with you trying to figure out what happened from both sides of the fence ('cause you get to play different people's timelines) and ends... ah yes the ending...
In my opinion, the ending is more than disappointing. It's full of reeeeaaaally poor design and writing choices (  ing superpowers, flying, running along walls, suddenly appearing AIs that are trying to take over the world, an extremely unnecessary romance which pinpoints the illogical character development and a really anticlimactic finale  ) which ruin pretty much everything that you worked for the entire game. Because when you find out what's going on you just wish you hadn't.
Nevertheless, remembering the mentioned first 3/4, I still have to give this game a thumbs up. Not just because I loved it 10 years ago, but because the story still ties me to my chair. Despite my disappointment towards the end, I would recommend this game to pretty much everyone who is into story-based adventure games and hasn't yet played it, and if you have played it, just grab that sweet feeling of nostalgia on sale.

Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy Remastered
Fahrenheit garnered critical acclaim when it first came out 10 years ago: its QTE events and story were something seldom seen before and more than made up for its shortcomings.
Nowadays its innovation is lost of course, and the game hasn't aged well but it is and always will be a classic.

PROS:

-a good cast of characters,all fairly interesting

-a compelling story, the beginning is especially very strong and makes you want to know what's happenening

-the various game scenes feature a nice amount of variety

-great soundtrack

-good voice acting

-nice cinematic cameras in certain scenes

CONS:

-story starts to become a bit too surreal towards the end, several different elements also seem to have been introduced just to try and make the mistery more complex

-the over reliance on QTEs is more distracting or annoying than anything else, some QTEs are also too drawn out for their own good or require inputs way too quickly

-having a limited number of retries for each QTes is annoying and feels out of place in a game like this one

-despite the HD treatment the game clearly shows its age with bland textures, fairly simple models and low res effects

-somewhat sluggish controls paired with a camera view that can sometimes get in the way

-wooden animations

-certain character interactions feel too sudden and forced just to further the plot

- a few glaring elements left in the release really made me wonder, examples are a stretched texture on one of the main char's face (in a couple of levels only, luckily), the game client quickly dropping back to windows to refresh itself when loading a level and no dpad support

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=455665544

Fahrenheit surely shows its age then, and this re-release basically just put a new coat of thin paint on it: the game's shortcomings are even more obvious in our modern gaming age and its reliance on QTEs can often annoy the player.

That said it's also easy to see why Fahrenheit was so successful and paved the way to games like Heavy Rain and Beyond; its strong story and interesting characters are still worth a playthrough after all these years and those who havn't played it back then owe it to themselves to pick up this piece of gaming history.
Just have patience if the gameplay can feel awkward and shallow, the tale this game tells is worth it.

Pro Gamer Manager
TL;DR
Released from Early Access way too early. Features and mechanics are not fleshed out, game decisions rarely matter and seem completely random, probably due to lack of any type of visual feedback which is crucial in this type of game. Great idea, but poor execution.

The Idea of the game is pretty solid. The game is split into two parts, the first you get to take control of an amatuer gamer and turn them into a pro either at FOBA (the game's version of MOBA) or FPS. The second part involves leaving your old life behind and managing a team instead.

I'm gonna break down into pro's and con's for easier reading :-

Pro's
Very unique idea

Turn-Based, the game uses an energy system that allows you to make a number of actions each day. (Can be seen as a con too, but I prefer turn-based for this type of game)

Ability to stream to make money

Runs on most toasters
Con's
Lack of feedback from most aspects of the game. This is the biggest problem with the game that has been mentioned countless times to the devs but yet nothing has been done about it.

Too random. This is somewhat tied in with the point above but outcomes of matches/tournements seem totally random, even if a similar strategy is used. This makes the game extremely tedious as you have no idea why the outcome is how it is. Stats, research, champ choices in FOBA and weapon choices in FPS don't seem to matter.

While they did add some features that the community asked for, they didn't flesh out most of it out and it just feels tacked on. Gear is a great example of this, all this does is give you a passive stat once you reach certain conditions (basically achievements). Could have easily have made a PC shop that gave us the choice on what parts to purchase to increase certain stats or what not. Moving into new, more expensive houses, have zero benefit whatsoever.
The game came out of Early Access WAY too early. Unless you want a very casual, randomized clicker I would stay clear of this game until they flesh it out properly.

Update
So it has been nearly a month since release and the game is still in Build 175, I'd just like to point out that this was the lastest build back in the 19th of April, a week prior to release. The fact that we had no new build on release, no patches whatsoever post-release and no sign of the devs in response to any of the feedback since then, leads me to believe this game will no longer be supported. :(

Pro Gamer Manager
Early Access Review

At this stage, PGM just can't be recommended. I honestly think it was released to Early Access too early.

The core concept: A single gamer growing through the rankings, creating a team and eventually winning at the highest level is a fun idea... But everything beyond that seems to be mired in bad design choices.

I know, that sounds unfair... but let's examine the first few minutes of gameplay.

Alright, I've started a game. Oh, hey, my player has been randomly generated. Name, appearance and nationality. Well, that's okay. At least I got a name I can pronounce. Okay, so we play FOBA? We FOBA player now.

Huh, this pick/ban phase is a little strange. There are three bans between two teams, and the layout makes it impossible to ban out AD champions. Huh. I guess that'll make more sense later on, when I start running the pick/ban phase myself.

Wow, these champions look a bit silly. Still, that's understandable, it'd take far too much effort to come up with a ton of unique champions. Hell, they're probably randomised too. Everything else seems to be so far.

Alright, I lost the game. It's okay, everyone loses their first game. Especially when they have to play support. But still, I'd like to know more about those champions...

Wait, where's the champion info page?


I think you can see where this is going... And it doesn't get any better. Nothing about FOBA is explained. All I can assume is that we're supposed to guess at how the game it played based on our pre-existing knowledge of MOBAs. Which is reasonable for a player like me, right?

What, for instance, is the difference between a Chaser and an Initiator, or a Soaker and a Protector? What do these choices do to alter the game? NOTHING is explained about the results of your games, either in the soloqueue stage or in the later team stages.

Ah. The team stages. Okay, bear with me, this is gonna get a bit meta.

Pro Gamer Manager is realistic.

No, really. In PGM, during what I'll call the 'bedroom' stage, you can choose to NOT play FOBA, and instead play one of three alternate games for stream potential. (FPS, Troll and Minecraft respectively). This will award you quite impressive amounts of money from your fans.

You don't get money from streaming FOBA. Apparently MOBA players are stingy.

And the best part? You can rack up way over a thousand credits in a single day while streaming, whereas you get virtually nothing from participating in the team stages... Hell, setting up advertising revenue or an eshop can result in tiny amounts of money.

So an HOUR of streaming can net you 300 credits with 500 fans via donations and subscriptions... But a shop where you can buy stuff with that same money, and have it go to the same place? That generates 100 credits a WEEK with a thousand fans. And this is at the stage where you can no longer stream for some bizzare, non-existant reason, thus cutting off your only reliable source of credits!

The funny thing is, that sounds realistic. A lot of the popular streamers (IE: The ones making the serious bank) AREN'T esports professionals.

So... The moral of Pro Gamer Manager is... Don't be a Pro Gamer? Just stream. Then you won't go bankrupt.


This game needs so much redesigning is a little bit sad. Here's hoping Early Access works. I'd quite like a good game based around this concept.

When i bought this game i thought it was going to be similair to a game called Game Dev Tycoon because of the look of te core gameplay. This was only kinda true.

The first big problem with this game is the lack of things to actually unlock through research. In game dev tycoon you not only had over 100 game genre's to unlock and playwith but also Marketing strategies , game engines , graphics , physics engines multiplayer and much more features to add to your game. In Pro game manager there were very few things to actually research. in career mode i think i research like two things before getting the option to switch to career mode. In career mode theres like only 4 or 5 things there too except they make the prices to get them ridciolous when it dosent feel like they actually do much.

My next issue with the game is its random events and popups. 2 in particular i remember is Injuring my hand so my reflexes were damaged and a new headset that came out. You cannot use your money to buy new equipment so why bother telling me about a ing headset that dosent exist for me to buy? I honestly think the whole reflexes thing is t too cause i never see a difference even when they game says they are improved. When you had popups like that in game dev tycoon it was the result of your decisions. for example one decision is To release your old game engines to the public or to sell them. is you sell it you make money but lose fans if you give it away you gain fans. its that ing simple and it makes game dev tycoon much better than this garbage.

Next is THERE IS NO TUTORIAL? WHYYYYYYYYYYY. it makes no sense to not have a tutorial its jsut plain lazy. I have no idea what stats are good for what freaking role because it has no  tutorial. Game dev tycoon has a great tutorial it tells you how to mkae reports to figure out what people care about more in which game genres and which game platforms do better with certain genres. Theres too many things to put your stats into to not have a tutorial. You just have to guess untll you start doing better in games.

Money is also pointless in this game. You have nothing to spend it on except for upgrades that dont really do anything or feel like they are worth it. Buying a house is pointless all it does is increase your monthly expensese like wtf is the point of that? It dosent help you dosent add anything theres no point at all nothing beneficial of buying a better house.

Even in the Manager mode everythings feels like a waste of time. i see my fans go up but your fans going up dont impact anything except money which besdies needing it for paying your players wages. In Game dev tycoon when you got more popular you got invited to interviews and even to E3 eventually. Something like that would make my fans seem they are better than just me getting more money.

With these things in mind in general i just never feel like im making progress in my 6 hours of playing. i see numbers go up and sometimes i win sometime i dont.  Even when you win championships you just get money its really lackluster to see nothing come out of my effort. In Game dev tycoon when you get popular you get newspaper articles magaznine articles , interviews and E3 showcasings and all that feels like progression because its a gradual rise to beign a big game developer. in This game everything feels the same nothing feels like the next level.

No achievements , No trading cards they just dont give a .

Pro Gamer Manager
Hello, this is my first serious review.

I'm an avid gamer and dedicate most of my free time to gaming and checking out titles that could be cool and fun.

Pro Gamer Manager did have an appeal at the start... same Game Dev Tycoon art... managing your own eSports team... so I figured the mechanics would be similar, thus, making it a fun and entertaining experience. I was wrong.

I can see the devs tried to make an entertaining title, but the formula does not work. In MANAGING GAMES you want to see that the decisions and actions you take, affect the outcome of the matches whether in a good or bad way. But when you play Pro Gamer Manager, the decisions you make, affect the outcomes in a really vague way or they don't affect it in any way and are unable to change its outcome.

You never know or are told (at least give us a hint of how the mechanics work for god's sake) how things are going to affect your results. You can pickup styles and different tactics but they are really vague on how you should use them and really basic. They try to make it simple but making it that way just takes away the whole experience of being a Professional eSports team.

Even if the devs assume you're used and knowledged about MOBA or FPS games, it's difficult to figure out what to do in every situation, even with Trial and Error. I might be wrong if I say that the decisions you take as a manager or a player DO NOT affect the outcome BUT; when I played Pro Gamer Manager I always felt that way and, believe me, IT IS NOT A PLEASANT FEELING.

I really tried to find something redeeming and have fun with Pro Gamer Manager, but either I haven't tried hard enough (prob not) or the game in itself isn't fun, probably the latter.

It also has some bugs that are not gamebreaking or really important, but they are really simple and basic bugs that kind of break the experience too (16-15 as a valid victory result on a FPS match even if it's not meant to be CS, can't click too fast on incoming messages or they will delete themselves).

Pro Gamer Manager defeats its own purpose as a game and a managing game, such potential wasted because of a bad execution.

I wouldn't recommend to buy this game in its current state, it's basically not fun for me and I've requested a refund.

Pro Gamer Manager
Early Access Review

So I won a copy of this game on Letigress' stream. My understanding is that she (the streamer) had teamed up with the developers to promote the game. Which was pretty cool.
So I played the copy I won for a couple hours. Is it interesting? Heck yeah! Is it fun? Well, depends on what you're lookng for. Right now it kind of plays like an idle game that you can't be idle for. You start a game or start watching a pro to increase stats, and just wait. Then the growth doesn't seem to have a huge impact on your playing. And things seem very vague right now. Champions don't have names, just graphics. You don't do the draft, just make some broad strategical calls, and the computer takes over.
Do I think you should buy this game? Sure. It is worth $10 in my opinion, if you have money to try out small indie games. If you're looking for 20 hours of content, this game is NOT for you. It could be eventually, but it needs more development.
I want:
Champion names
Ability to draft
More customization of my character
Clear growth in character with all the stats
More options than just play or watch
A more interesting early game
Ability to get in game money and customize room
More depth! Right now this feels generic at times
Great idea, guys! Keep at the game. It could be special. :)

Pro Gamer Manager
Lots of people have given lists of Pro's and Con's so I'll skip that side of things and keep it simple.

I bought this game around 6 months ago when I heard about it and it was difficult to play but I seen it had a ton of potential so I was happy to wait for release, sadly it seems either the developers didn't have the time and money or the skill to realize this game's potential.

The main issue with this game is a total lack of player feedback, you make tactical choices before each match but the game doesn't tell you what you did right and what you did wrong, you have a ton of stats but the game doesn't tell you what each stat does, there are a ton of heroes to play in the MOBA mode but there is almost no information about the heroes, just a basic thumbnail, whether they are a support, ADC, Jungler and whatever and whether they are Utility, Healer, Burst and such but no other information at all.

If this game gave some worthwhile feedback to the player and went a little more in depth with the heroes instead of just a name, thumbnail and the bare basic info then I could see it being really good, but unless that happens.. it's not worth buying at all.

Hopefully a developer with more experience takes the idea of this game and makes something better because a game about being a manager of a Pro gaming house and/or being a professional gamer could be awesome, sadly.. this game isn't.

TL;DR version: No depth, no player feedback, no skill involved, just RNG, not worth buying.

Pro Gamer Manager
Played it until about Day 60 or so. I was a big fan of Game Dev Tycoon and this seemed very similar to it so I thought I'd give it a go.

The biggest hangup I have with this game is that no matter what, nothing you do seems to have any affect on the outcome of the battle (I only played FPS player and not manager). After I unlocked streaming and got it up to about level
10, all options of genres to stream vanished except for FOBA and FPS.

I bought both upgrades for the houses and they did absolutely nothing. I thought you'd get some better hardware or it would be easier to stay in high spirits and get benefits to gaming, anything really but no, nothing.

I can't seem to get passed star level 95. I don't know if that's working as intended but you go into the league tournaments and you'll often get beaten by guys that are half of that of your level.

You can upgrade your hardware but the last one you need platinum gaming status and it seems pretty damn hard to achieve. Simply for the reason that you can win 1 map and then lose 10 in a row no matter what you do.

You have a rage bar that fills up whenever you lose a ranked match but I have had it up to full and down to nothing and I honestly can say that I see no difference in the outcome battles with this either.

It is certainly in need of some tutorials. I see other people say that there is a not of Counter Strike terminology in here and never having played it, I had to look up some of what they're talking about to get an understanding of what skill is supposed to do what.

I think if they ironed out the few bugs that existed and made things less random or maybe give some kind of explanation as to what is doing what, it could turn out to be a really fun game. In its current state though, I can't recommend it.

Pro Gamer Manager
UPDATE FOR FULL RELEASEThe game is now out of Early Access. Prematurely, as you'll find out.

Many of the points below - written for an early version of the game - still stand.
There is little to no feedback, not even to mention explanation. If you are not aware of the terminology in League of Legends or Counter-Strike, you will have a hard time understanding without researching it yourself.

The game is a big grind for stats which ultimatively do not seem to matter. The results (winning, losing, stats) seem incredibly random, even if your team is half of the world top 10 players.

I had a lot of hope for the game when it was in Early Access. I do think this was released way too early and the premature release hurt the game in the end.

If you find this review unhelpful, I invite you to tell me why in the comments. Will do my best to explain my verdict and would happily take feedback.

Pro Gamer Manager
Early Access Review

as much as i want to tell people to go out and buy this game, i cant. Everything in this game is RNG and has no actual value. litterally nothing in this game has a value modifier (sp?) and is completely based off rng. You want an aggressive team, go ahead play a season of aggressive build style and still get reports about your team is not being aggressive. you want your team to do troll picks, sure go ahead, you'll still get msgs saying your team doesnt like the current practice set up and wants troll picks. pratically everything on the finance/staff members side is a waste. not a single one gives you  more income (or value) than their weekly salary. your scout is worthless and wont give a good pick to save his life. on top of that, you must fire the role you're trying to replace, just to view potential replacements (ie that adc you want to replace, gotta fire him, just to view the crap list of people available or to sign the 5th support that your scout found). the teams stats dont have any value to them. despite putting 5hrs into this game, i cannot find anything that i enjoy about it (and i enjoy progressional building games like game dev tycoon). you cant see how much everything cost until its too late and you cannot fire any staff members (despite them being completely worthless). no back button, so even if you're investigating something, its already too late (ie your scout got back with a potential team member, gotta kick the person you want to replace, as you cannot view his recruitment page again, despite having no idea what role your scount found). money: your source of income before you create a team is great (and a bit OP), but once you expand to a full on team, you better pray to RNG that the famous hockey player wanted lessons from your adc, as there is ZERO source of income (besides placing in the top three at the end of each tournament). dont waste your time building your player (or his toons) into the top solo Q player, as it will be worthless once you create a team.

random other nitpicks: no audio control, so you will be forced to listen to the Sims build mode music until you take your headphones off. spelling, its  (i know mine isnt great either, but im just ranting and not producing a game). one save file, at least give us three so we can save different variations, when we're experimenting.

I have high hopes for this game, but even at a discounted rate, its not worth it atm.

I'm well known in the community, even across servers, for effectively codifying the proper use of Mabinogi's Magic skill set with a comprehensive guide that underwent many, many revisions over the years (and which is still referenced and quoted to this day).  I played for over six years and sank countless thousands of dollars into the game.  Mabinogi is my most-played video game of all time by a nigh-incomprehensibly-large margin (just not on the Steam version, which will explain the lack of hours logged here).  I've shrugged off changes that have made similarly-tenured players quit.  And as a relatively respected player whose advice carried significant weight with newbies and old-timers alike, I have one thing to say.

Do not play Mabinogi.

Mabinogi's combat was originally, at its core, a rock-paper-scissors system.  Normal melee strikes are deflected by the Defense skill.  Defense can be broken with Smash.  Smash is not as fast as normal melee and will always be trumped by it.  This, combined with many different enemy AI patterns, required players to be able to read the enemy's movements well in advance and react with appropriate timing, because all attacks carry some degree of stun and enough consecutive attacks will knock a player backward.  In the original release and for some time thereafter, tanking was completely non-viable because player health was vastly outclassed by enemy damage potential, requiring every combatant to be adept at reading and reacting to enemy movements and encouraging the then-commonly-espoused battle philosophy of don't get hit".

Mabinogi
Dude I used to love this game, and so did so many others. Like I had some of the happiest times in my life through this game; I started this game with 2 of my real life friends, found an amazingly fun guild, and made an amazing friend (though I'm sadly no longer in contact with them) as well as other great friends. Now, sorry for this giant rant, hopefully you read it. I seriously loved this game.

I went and replayed the game about a year ago, hoping to relive my happy times, and to some extent I did, but to a very small extent. I went and played on the Mari server, the once biggest server in the game. I found ALOT of fun through Martial Arts (it was boxing basically), and it was flashy, and the enemy AI (The AI used to be really smart and worked very well, but it was never upgraded to combat skills like Alchemy and Dual Guns, so it became really stupid when you used these skills) was still functional using it, but besides that, everything that made the game crumbled. There was so many damn skills, each one rendering older skills useless. Magic to a point and archery more or less were replaced with Alchemy. Then puppeting came and replaced Alchemy's biggest selling point; having a golem. Then came Dual Guns to completely replace archery (like so few people used archery, why not go and fix it?). The last thing that was added before I gave up on the game was Ninjistu, and I just gave up. It was so silly and extremely anime (yes the game's korean, but it had taste and a really nice art style; not just full fledge kawaii desu Naruto rip-off crap), and I can only imagine this replaced another skill class.


That wasn't the only thing that made me leave, there's a bit more. I could deal with a load of crap skills as long as I had some fun ones, but each new event was complete crap. Back in the old days events were so much freakin fun! Like there was a skiing event, a cotton candy sheep event, and a water balloon party event! (just to list a few). Aw man these were all great and alot of fun to me! But when I returned, it was just non-stop re-hashing of the dragon boating event (where you go down a river in a raft, fight some mobs, get a reward, rinse and repeat) and the Tara event (a japanese style event with a dart throwing mini game and a test-your-strength hammer game.) The Tara event was fun when it released, but it REALLY overstayed its welcome through it being rehashed every other week.

The economy also went to complete crap. Current day rare items would cost about 10 million+. You wanted a guitar? Better be rich, because you're gonna have to dish out about 20 million. Not only that, all old rare items went to complete commodity. Like I had a rare Leprechaun outfit that was super rare when it first came out; I was one of the maybe 20-ish people who had it on Mari, but when I rejoind they were barely even worth 100k (this is basically normal spending money in player markets). Due to Nexon just re-hashing old content, extremely rare items became to the point of being only uncommon to just somewhat rare. I used to be so proud of alot of my rare clothing; since alot of the game was about fashion and being distinct and being yourself, I felt proud walking about with some really cool n rare clothes, but now that satisfaction I had was quickly diminished.

Lastly what made me give up on the game was how lonesome and empty the servers became and how crap the once thriving and amazing community became. I played in about 2009 to 2010, and when I did, I could basically just walk up to anybody and either join in their conversation or start one, and befriend them. It wouldn't be some weird akward conversation either, people would just talk and be friends with eachother. The game used to be a huge party. You could walk down dunbarton (basically the games main town) on almost any server and find naked people running about PvPing one another, and then just down the road find a group of people participating in Elves vs. Giants war. It was great! But when I went back, the place was completely lonely. Nobody talked, there were barely any live guilds anymore, most guilds being dead, and nobody Pvp'd anymore. For the most part, the game was just deserted.

Sorry about this huge dang rant man. I just really love this game. It was really important to me. I made alot of great friends through the game, some that I'm sadly no longer in contact with, but I still have the fond memories. This game was amazing in every aspect in its prime; great combat, great community, and great events; there was something to do for everyone, and the game truly was a fantasy life. You wanna go and do something? Go do it! You can! Everything felt important and was satisfying. Even just fishing and gathering potatoes and such was fun, because you always had a friend while doing it or just someone to talk to, and a reason to doing so. I'm always hoping to find another amazing game like this; a game that'd make me excited to wake up and see what's going on, and just a sheer joy to play. I keep hearing about FF:XIV, and here's hoping that I'll be able to enjoy it like mabinogi.

Once again, sorry for this giant rant; I'm just super passionate about this game. This game meant alot to me.

Mabinogi
*Edited and revised for further clarity and information*
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

An interesting mmorpg. Having played many mmorpgs before, mabinogi is a favorite due to its dynamic combat system. There are infinite battle combo possibilities as the gameplay involves fast paced action with a unique do-it-yourself strategy allowing almost limitless freedom to choose how you play. While the game features talents (i.e warrior) like most mmorpg's, it doesn't limit what you can and can't do allowing you to choose what skills from any tab (melee, magic...etc) you want to train giving a really unique gameplay individual to the player rather than restriction, emphasizing complete freedom in how you like to play.

Another appealing factor for mabinogi is the anime-style graphics rather than the traditional realism based graphics that give the game a relaxed outlook rather than a serious tone.

Having played this game for several years and watching it change and grow i can point out a few perspectives on its pro's and cons:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pro's:

- Freedom to play however you want, as whoever you want to be with no linear path set out for you to take. There are no penalties for doing what you want or neglecting to do certain things if you don't want to. This allows a player to choose what to do, whether it be fighting and training, crafting and trading, or even just socializing.

- Active and alive community full of players from veterans to newbies; never a dull moment no matter where you go (Alexina is one of the most active servers in-game and Dunbarton is one of the most active towns in-game).

- Immersive and involving storyline that spans out several chapters, events, and in-game years that pit you in the midst of the struggle as one of the milletians" involved in the conflict between the gods and various factions in Erinn.

- Constant updates and add-ons to the game; whether in the form of a new storyline chapter or the many year-round events

Mabinogi
I am ghoultrooper of Alexina lvl 11k. I've been with Mabinogi for a long time playing on and off since 2008. i wanted to input my views of the game so here we go:

The Pros~
+ Unique Rock paper Scissor style of combat *
+ Infinity customization in coloring anything from the soles of your shoes and outfits to the hilts of your weapons
+ Newbie Friendly Beginner System ( helps you somewhat catchup to the current players )
+ Unique Rebirth Leveling up System which has no LvL Cap ( main reason i haven't ever permanently quit )
+ Events come by frequently and so do content updates every few months
+ Many Crafting Skills
+ Abundant amounts of daily minigames/quests that you can do
+ Nice Story
+ Playerbase is Mostly Friendly.

The Cons...
- Nexon.
- Has a somewhat steep learning curve.
- Reforges are from cash shop only but are obtainable from other players via in game gold.
-* The unique combat system slowly dies off as you gain High Dmg. you will end up using just the efficient clearing methods ( although that can be said for most of any game )
-~ Inventory can become an Issue if you're a hoarder like i am. Pets are almost a must buy utility BUT you are able to buy pets from other players with gold also so...
-in my honest opinion, at least half of the NA server is lazy af. so many  people just afk and don't run anything ( missions, dungeons, etc. )
- 7  channels but everyone clogs up on channel 1 and channel 2 through 7 are almost like ghost towns zzzz....
- Durability.

Neutral
**- Despite what many people say, Nothing in Mabinogi is actually Pay2Win. Everything is obtainable through grind or luck. things in the Cash Shop are more of Convenience/ Fashion Items.

Conclusion.
I find the game fun to play every now and then but once you've got your gear and many of the skills done there isn't much left to do. the Dye customizations are great!
I Recomend any new players to find a nice guild or just a nice veteran player in general to help guide you through. guilds are generally very nice in Mabi overall and will help you often.

Mabinogi
Mabinogi is one of the greatest MMORPGs out there. Very Unique and Very Fun.
I was recommended this game by a friend and I told him that I wasn't very impressed by its 'looks'. Sure enough, I at least gave it a try...and From that point onwards, I have never stopped playing it. That was about a year or so ago. That's how amazing this game is!
Mabinogi is one of those games that doesn't require you to complete EVERY SINGLE quest and task; it's all completely up to you to make the choices and do what YOU want to do.

One of the main things that makes this game so unique and fun is its combat and leveling system. The combat in this game requires more stragetic choices and as well as good timing of skills and attacks to do some damage against foes, rather than just pressing the skills button to do some extra damage. Also, the leveling is very different to other games. There's quite a lot to explain but to put it shortly: There's no level cap. You can just keep on leveling.

Another thing is the gaming community. I promise you, that this game has one of the most friendliest communities I've ever played with and that is what keeps me playing. Simply just asking for a little assistance and someone, who hears it, would usually come by and help you out.

Last main thing is the story and updates. The story of mabinogi is very unique and it is separated into 'Generations'. Each generation can pose quite a challenge and usually isn't something you can just rush through. The story overall is a very interesting one with its twists and turns. Each update is always something that I can look forward to as each one usually has some sort of event with it, giving players the chance to win great and useful prizes.

There are alot of other great things that I can say about this game, as well as a few minor problems. But overall, this game ROCKS! and I recommend it 100%!

Mabinogi
I do apologize for my lack of game time. I played Mabinogi directly from Nexon before it was released on Steam. Though it seems I have almost no time on the game, I guarentee I've spent at least 150+ hours on the game.

Mabinogi
Mabinogi is an interesting little mmo that is about you the player being sucked in your computer and ending up in a world called Erinn. You are called a milletian by the worlds people and as you discover more things about yourself, the story unfolds into this tragic and sad conflict of many different people. This is the main focus of the story and I will say that its decent. It will keep you interested but the story mission lines are short. Though at this point in the games life, there are tons to complete. And speedrunning even at low level will only take a couple of hours to finish.

Now on to the Mechanics. Mabinogis combat is simple yet hard to master. It is a lot like rock paper scissors and every skill has its counter. Smash> Defense Counter>smash. Theres many different skills to choose from and you will always feel unique from other people.

The skill leveling on the other hand is somewhat similar to UO (Ultima Online). You have to use the skill repeatedly to rank it up. For example Smash would require you to kill 10 enemies using smash, smash a critical on ten enemies to rank from rank B to A. These are just examples, but the number of times you would have to repeat using this skill increases to hundreds or even thousands depending on the skill. Some rank themeselves up and you won't even notice it as you play. Other skills will require you to go out of your way just to train them and could take hours of your time just doing that. Life skills like blacksmithing could take you about a month to do if that was what you had spent your time on for a whole month.
To rank skills though, you need Ability points. Ap (for short) is given by leveling. I level up to 80 per rebirth for example. After you hit say 80, you will want to rebirth. Rebirthing removes the stats you gained from levels but you keep your stats that you gained from skills. You can only rebirth once a week but you can rebirth for free every three weeks. If you would like to buy a rebirth once a week its about 10 bucks.

This is actually one of my problems with mabi is that its very grindy. Its a very unique game with huge amounts of character customization. Just very grindy. The questing is totally fine with not much grind at all. Some of the story quests mix it up with puzzles. Its just the actual building of your character.

If you are looking for an mmo thats different and you can waste a ton of time on but stay engaged, then this is the game for you. Game has quite a bit of sandbox features such as housing and character customization with tons of outfits and skills to mix in. There is even farming.

If you are looking for a game that will not waste your time but still give you a great experience then this may not be what you are looking for. Mabinogi has to much grind hidden under those colorful cartoony graphics to justify playing only 1 hour a day. You can very well play the game for free without spending a dime, but you will want to. They offer limited edition pets constantly, Various limited edition clothes, and rebirths to make your life easier.

So all in its a very unique mmo and its hard to lie and say that it isnt. But playing an mmo like this or wow really worth it to you? After all of the fun is said and done and you have seen everything it will turn into a job. Every mmo that is currently out in america will have you grinding for hours. Even guild wars 2 has grind at the end. So is it worth it to you?

10/10 Would die due to server lag again, thanks Nexon love knowing I can count on you! <3

...But really, I'm gonna be writing a serious review here. I love this game so I'm recommending it, Mabinogi is a fun, casual game to pick up and play at your own leisure. Currently my main problem is the combat. Ever since I first started playing this game some six or seven years ago I've noticed one major thing; Nexon's server stability is complete t. If you play this game with the idea that you're going to mainly be combat oriented, you're gonna have a bad time!

Combat in this game is all about picking your battles wisely. Two key factors in combat is lag and targeting. I've already talked about lag so let's talk about targeting. Unless you're good at pointing your mouse in very specific places, you're gonna wanna hold ctrl to auto-target the nearest enemy to your mouse. Now, this isn't a bad thing... unless you're fighting a large boss monster. I'm in the beginner dungeon trying to target a giant red spider when his little buddies are nowhere near my mouse, yet I target them anyways and aggro unwanted enemies, thus getting myself killed.

That aside, this game has a number of features that make for a great atmosphere. The soundtrack, for example is one of the best I've ever heard in a free-to-play MMORPG. Not only that but you have the ability to pick up an instrument, write your own music and then play said music. The only other game I've seen that implemented would be in LOTRO so this feature is a huge thumbs up in my books.

Mabinogi offers a wide range of skills from combat to magic to simple gathering and crafting. Each skill has a rank and the more you work on the skills the more training it gets to the next rank. Before ranking it up you need to spend AP which is gained when you level up. Back when I first played this game AP was really hard to come by so you had to pick and choose what skills you want to work on, the same can't be said now as I have more AP than I know what to do with! Personally, this is a bad thing hiding underneath a good thing. Having all this AP means that you can work on more skills, but at the same time it means that everyone can pretty much be a jack-of-all-trades. This bothers me slightly because it takes away from the idea of players specializing in specific things, constructively forcing them to work together.

Community is...well, as I said in my review of WAKFU, you have to know where to look for them. Sure you'll see a group of people hanging out in the Human starter town in channel 1 of any given server, but aside from that I don't see many people aside from your everyday player running to and from one place to another, too busy to stop and chat. There are guildstones placed all over the place, you can click on them to bring up information about that guild. You can also just pull up the guild interface and search for guilds so I find the guildstones pretty redundant. There are also guilds recruiting on Nexon's official forums as well as community forums, which gives the opportunity to speak to the leader or recruiters before joining.

There are more features about this game that I'm missing, I'll be editing this review at a later date but I thought I should add some more of the game's core features to the review since it was originally pretty bland. I still recommend this game and even though I talk about negative points it is still a great game that you absolutely must experience at least once. Thank you for reading!

Mabinogi
Mabinogi, by definition, is the closest MMORPG to Sword Art Online ever created. Wether you acctuly like the anime or not, there is no doubt that Mabinogi closely resembles some of its elements. However, I whole heartedly say this, Mabinogi is not for everryone. Why you may ask? Well, simply but, Mabinogi is very, very, VERY grindy. If you want to have a half decent character, you need to grind. See, there are 2 ways to play Mabinogi. 1. You can play just to dork around and talk to some friends you convinced to play with you. 2. You can feel like a toatol badass when your character is so combatically stacked, that plowing through hoards of enemies with one quick swoop becomes incredibly entertaining. That' right folks, you want some fun out of this game? You gotta learn to fight, and fight like a pro. This is where Mabinoig is the most grindy. See there are multible classes (or talents). And each talent has its own weapons, and stats, and blah blah blah. But here's where the game is intresting, some talents work off the same stat, thus making it that if you did both classses, both would become stronger due to you training that stat. Here's an example for you: If you do Close Combat, which get's its power off of your strength stat, and you alos did Ninja, which also get's its power from the strength stat. Now both of these talents become stronger because they both work off the training of the strength stat. Some people will take this to the extream by taking many different talents that rely on strength, or intelligence, and train them up so that they can be powerful in a whole arsenal of classes. Now how do these classes work? Well remember how I said this game is kinda like Sword Art Online? Well basically each class has X amount of skills, and each skill can be trained and ranked up by using AP. Every skill can go from rank F to rank 9, and then rank 9 to rank 1. This obviously is where the game becomes very grindy. In order for your skillset to be half decent, your going to have to train that skillset a lot and earn lots of AP. However, that makes becomming a respectable warrior all the more rewarding. Mabinogi is honestly very addictive, it plays off its own grindiness, pulling you in and making you beg to bring your skill up just one more rank before bed. Basically if you give Mabinogi time, and take the time to learn the ropes, and find your way around (I would suggest using the Mabinogi wiki page) then you will find that Mabinogi is a really great game.

Mabinogi
Mabinogi was a lot of fun. Using 'was' because I played it for over 5 years and outgrew it already, but couldn't just leave without reviewing my experience.

Let's start with the good stuff.

-Uniqueness
This game is old, and it was way ahead of its time. There were so many features other MMO's never even though about having. So much stuff to do.
There's not even a level cap so you could just literally keep on playing this game until it died.
Updates are frequent and have actual creative/interesting content.

-Combat
How do I even begin to explain how amazing the combat in this game is.
Sure it's point and click, but its deeper than the typical point and click game.
You actually need to think about what you're doing instead of just spamming 1-9 skill keys like other similar MMO's do.

-Graphics
For a game from 2003(?) the graphics don't harm the experience.
The anime style of the game still kept it refreshing.

-Story
Oh man, the story in this game..
All I can really say is that its confusing and doesn't flow together but its interesting at the least.
The directors kept changing for this game and they never continued each story arc, they made their own instead.

Mabinogi
An Affectionate Retropective...
I haven't touched this game in a while, thus I can't represent what the game is now, however I can give my thoughts on what it was like a few years ago. The only reference used here is my own memory; this will mostly likely have bias, as a person who did enjoy the game. I bolded the important bits for tl;dr.

The story is actualy good for once, or at least the first three generations were. I can't remember what the rest of them were about, though I do remember that they continued the story line in one of the later generations (17~18 I believe). I don't think I've ever seen characterization of this extent in any MMORPG; to this day I still occasionally wonder what ever happened to Triona and Ruari. The NPCs are recurring, meaning that they still are relevant through out the game relative to the story. There's even a relationship system with the NPCs, though I do think it could be fleshed out some more. Perhaps they've already fleshed it out by now, who knows? I remember giving lots of bread to the nun that's always outside the Church in Tir, I'd finally got her to warm up to me after ~50 loaves of bread and occasionally she'd give me a boiled egg. It was ... heart warming, and it's probably the only thing remotely similar to human affection I'm ever going to get from a girl.

The music is god tier. Each NPC has their own special song. The nun outside the Church had a particularly wonderful tune. Here it's better to show you, listen for a bit: https://youtu.be/rG2Z9dnovKA
It almost seems like each song was composed to maximize nostalgic value, even more so once I heard the lyrics to the theme song sung by Tanaka Rie; it was as if it was speaking directly to former players. Not to say that new players can't enjoy the music as well, it's just that listening to these pieces right now, it has more impact than one would think.

It's an ever lasting game. There is no level cap, how it works is that every so often you'd reset yourself to level 1 again keeping your skill progression. You can literally play for as long as you want with out it getting too slow to level. And when I speak about leveling it doesn't nessesarily mean grinding.

Even with the unconventional combat system (for it's time), you're not required to grind or even kill anything at all. The game doesn't follow the point, click, and wait system that was common during that time, it was a little more dynamic than that; in fact back in the day getting hit twice usually meant death. Goblins, being one of the lower forms of enemies, would still deal out high amounts of damage both in raw damage and in numbers (multi-aggro). The good thing is that you don't have to kill monsters if you don't want to, with the release of non-combat leveling, you can be a farmer that levels up by touching chickens, milking cows, etc, or you could just blacksmith things all day. I found it particularly fun to simply search for gems to feed to the loli living in my knife.

Customization is a core aspect of the game. If I had one good thing to say about Nexon's cash grabbing, it's the customization options. They do a pretty good job of offering a bunch of choices. That's all on top of the innate customization in the game, I can't even count the amount of clothing articles this game has. Even in the case that you see someone wearing the same thing you are, there's dye. mathmatically there are millions of possibilities, for God's sake you can dye your weapons. You write your own music, you design your own plot of land, etc. Combat wise some of the key choices the game shoves at you is Paladin vs. Dark Knight, Elf vs. Giant, I think you have to choose the Demi-god thing too; I can't say for sure, I never got that far in the game (those quests were too dificult for me).

Not to say there's nothing negative to say about Mabinogi...

The graphics may be a bit blocky for this generation, especially with these fancier games coming out. My defence to this is that the magnitude of customization offered here would not be realistically possible with next gen" graphics

Mabinogi
This game is garbage and will devour your soul, time, and wallet. 10/10 would play again

Mabinogi
While Mabinogi is pretty new to Steam. I played it when it first came out #hipster.

Mabi is a game that basically plays like a more awesome, anime version of Runescape. If I have to be honest. You can train talents and skills related to combat, tailoring, cooking, carpentry, fishing, etc. It's basically a virtual life simulator that happens to have weapons and monsters involved. There are marriages, familiies, and of course the classic guild.

The combat system is strategy based, with a heavy emphasis on stacking and planning out the use of your skills (Combo. If you will). Simply left clicking on an enemy is enough sometimes, but when you start diving into deeper dungeons, or the dark, deep wilderness - you're going to want to know how to run your dang combat skills.

Recent updates have made the game MUCH more accessible as far as talents and skills go. And with frequent. FREE updates coming constantly, there's no shortage of content available to keep even the old school" players entertained.

The music is amazing

Mabinogi
A once great game now nothing more than a black hole for your wallets bordom.  Maginogi, coming on 9 years live, has seen better days with more activity.  What can be said?  Nexon, the publishing company for the devcat studio based in Souel, South Korea, has watch its hit game run into the ground.

Mabinogi
I've found that I can be really picky about MMO's to the point that I'll only play one or two. Character customization and freedom are key things for me and Mabinogi has those. It is not perfect, but I don't think any MMO will ever be. I'll list some of the good and the bad (and other key notes) and let you decide if it's for you.

--Cons--
Nexon/Cash Shop: The cash shop does support the game, but with people spending hundreds, if not more, each time a Gachapon comes out it gets a bit excessive. There are some useful consumables, and some pets and outfits that change frequently.
Grinding: Grinding is very real in this game. Finding materials or items for quests or crafting can take hours. Training some skills can also be a pain in the .
AP: Skills are more important than levels and all skills have their own rank and use AP to get those ranks. I listed this in the Cons because it shouldn't be spent wildly, even though it is technically unlimited, because it can take a while to get.
Quests: A number of the quests are the generic, lackluster fetch or hunting quests.

--Pros--
Events: Nexon always has some sort of event running and 9/10 are at least decent (there is one where I had to fight two dragons (with other players) and all I got was a crappy MP potion. That event was cut short and replaced). Some events will give cash shop consumables, unique outfits, pets, exp, or just other unique items.
Customization: There are several free options for physical appearance and your armor and weapons can be dyed. Finding a player with the exact appearance and outfit and colors would be difficult unless you coordinate it.
Classless: Something I like in games. Rather than choosing a class, you choose a talent that helps with training associated skills. You can change your talent and it doesn't restrict any equipment or skills. You could be a Mage with heavy armor bashing things in the face with an umbrella.
Story: There is an extensive story, but all of it is optional. There are some exceptional rewards for parts of the story (transformations, a free pet) but with the open world you never have to touch it. It's also possible to start later parts of the story. Best of all, the quests are generally unique.

--Neutral--
Dungeons: Dungeons are randomly generated and are have some unique rewards. Searching for a specific reward, however, goes back to the grinding note. It's especially annoying to have a multiple floor dungeon and not get the drop you need.
Races: There are three playable races in game, each with their own pros and cons. This and your name are the only things locked about your character, but I listed it in Neutral because I'm not especially for or against it.

Overall, I'd rank Mabinogi a 8/10. There's an extensive wiki available online, and you can find some helpful cash shop items in player shops (can be a little expensive though). There's also a few minor glitches, but all games have that.

Edit:
I figure I'd write an actual review for this since I now have 700+ hours invested in this game.
Do you want a game where you can become a blacksmith who's also a mage?
An archer who just happens to use an oversized lance or a chef who happens to be a scientist?

Look no further but be warned: The game is a lot easier compared to when I first joined but that doesn't change the fact you will have a hard time. There is a variety ways of optaining gold but mercy will you still have trouble affording repairs.

The game was, and still is, designed to be played with others: You can't really do it alone for the beginning, in fact in the beginning NPCs encourage the player to meet others.

That doesn't mean somehow the game becomes easy with more players: Throwing impossible odds at you in the later chapters is pretty much mabs at this point.

Now if you're interested thus far you're probably wondering if this is P2W: It's not. I've heard people say this game is P2W but that's not really true, unless you want pets, almost everything else can and will be sold by other players. In fact for 400 hours wasted I didn't pay a cent and I still managed. A lot of the paid stuff isn't even that good, it just looks fancy.

You will struggle; you will suffer. You will lose and you will fail so many times but if you keep at it you'll eventually pull through.

So in conclusion: Don't.

Since the recent physics update i felt the need to re-write my review.

This is quite literally the best racing game ever conceived. I already held it in extremely high regard pre-0.8 and had taken plenty of time to master the game - And then boom. A complete overhaul of the aero, tyre and suspension models. Why? Because the community said the handling didn't feel quite right.
They decided to then cram some equipment into a van and drive all the way to Barcelona from the UK to get some more feedback from the real world RX drivers, to help pinpoint where improvements could be made.
If this doesn't show some real dedication to the early access model and prove that they're actively striving to make this the best rally game ever made, i really don't know what could change your mind.

DiRT Rally v0.8 has managed to become my favourite all time game - Taking the throne from my childhood SNES classics and there's still more to come! DiRT Rally
Encouragement Edition
So far I've put 31 hours into DiRT Rally, which is nothing really, since it took me roughly 30 hours to be able to drive confidently. Now that it's out of Early Access and despite glowing reviews from that period, I want to offer words of encouragement to those who have no experience with rally simulation games. My experience with rally sims is literally that, 31 hours. For a long time I thought my big brother was kinda crazy with his Richard Burn Rally, GT Legends and what have you. I stayed away from his racing sims, cos I knew I wouldn't be able to compete with his stage times. So instead we got competitive in games like NFS: High Stakes (the Snowy Ridge stage in particular) and the old Colin McRae Rally games, which had enough arcade handling for me to be able to compete with him. Naturally he played with assists off, where available. I on the other hand wouldn't even know how to begin to setup my car, let alone understand how turning off certain assists would translate into the handling of the car. And I pretty much still don't. For someone my age, I've driven very little in real life, but my mechanically inclined big brother knew exactly what he was doing back then. So most of the time he was kicking my , both in and out of the games. I keed, I keed.

My immediate conclusion after the first few hours with DiRT Rally was that I had no clue how to drive. A drunk elephant skating on ice would have more finesse. While I didn't rage-quit as often as I was expecting to, at the start I was playing only in third person view, thinking that my experience with the NFS, GTA or Colin McRae Rally games would help me here. It didn't. What I soon realized was that an outside view of my driving made me too aware of the track, which is probably just me, but that coupled with racing sim handling spelled disaster for me. So either by brazen choice or through cunning design, I chose the cockpit view to complete an entire stage, which I had never done in any racing game before. Sure, I've toggled it on and off here and there, but I had never stuck with it until now. This had an interesting effect on my driving, cos I was assessing the track and my line of driving more by feel than by actually seeing the track from above. I mean besides listening to your co-driver, which is important if you want to win. All that said, I think it's a good idea to put some 30 hours into it before you drift off to other games, cos being an FPS guy mostly and after taking long breaks from it, I was essentially starting afresh every time I returned. Even if your skills are still there, the stage conditions from Wales to Greece will bring you back to earth in no time.

Recently I graduated to Clubman, which means you'll do 6 stages per race and have 2 opportunities to repair your car. While my initial reaction was oh no

WOW!  I never thought i'd see the day that Codies produced any driving game with such authenticity, let alone a spiritual successor to RBR.  I'm amazed and somewhat shocked how good Dirt Rally is.

Took a while to get the settings dialed in to my liking and it still needs work on the FFB (base lateral and centering forces) .   Also the damage model could do with a bit of refinement, but otherwise very, very good indeed.

Please Codies, don't be tempted to dumb this down or add a whole load of peripheral fluff before release.  Keep it pure and focussed on the essence of the sport.  Continue in the same vein and you'll make a lot of serious racers very happy.

If Ken Block appears even once and calls me 'dude' I'm gonna hurt someone.

DiRT Rally
You like vroom cars? Awesome. You like realistic cars flying over y roads that will punish you for your mistakes...but won't kill you for them like an actual car would? Read on.


Two things first. This game requires a DirectX 11-capable GPU, and there is an achievement for having played the game in Early Access. I don't know if it'll prevent 100% completion, but it is a thing.

Apart from that, this is 100% recommended for rally fans, and anybody who isn't afraid of a challenge. DiRT Rally is the fundamental opposite of DiRT Showdown, and it shows. Excellent physics (Codemasters' most realistic to date), truly awesome sound, breath-taking graphics, oodles of cars and a great variety of locations already. Between the career, multiplayer (with leagues!), fully customizable modes, achievements, and aforementioned car/track variety, there is a lot of value here.

Rally is predicated less on being the best right from the start and more around improving yourself as you go, gradually pushing yourself forward. Which is good, because this game really does simulate rally, and it is unforgiving. New players, trust me when I say you will screw up and it will probably be frustrating - because I sure feel it! And that's okay, because improving yourself in this game is truly rewarding, and driving itself is more often than not its own reward. Hell, veteran drivers aren't always perfect either. This game is quite possibly the most elegant combination of game and simulator I've ever seen.

The community will probably tell you to turn off all the driving aids from the start, but they're there for a reason. One must learn to walk before they can run, so I would suggest incrementally turning them off whenever you feel comfortable enough to. Or...not. How you use this game's remarkably wide-ranging realism/aid preferences are up to you.

If there's any criticism to be had of this game, it's that you kind of need a controller or wheel to really get the most out of your vehicle, and you will need to push your vehicle that far eventually.

The career progression is also rather impersonal: you mainly interact with the championships via sterile menus. I'd like to see my car in the service area so I can look at its damage in detail. I'd also like to see showcases for the cars, complete with short videos and historical information for people deciding which car to buy. The presentation is still good, but it's kind of impersonal for a representation of rally. I'd like to see something more like what's described in this special-interest review[www.worldrallyblog.com]:

Off the top of my head

Earth 2160
Let me start with saying I am a huge fan of the earth series,

-Earth 2160 continues the story of its predecessors through 4 campaigns of around average length that will most likely keep you busy for a while.
-The game features 4 very unique races which vary greatly in terms of playstyle.
-Lets you modify your units as you see fit to execute their job perfectly.
-It comes with a skirmish mode and supports up to 8 players for lan and i-net multiplayer. Has a bunch of extra maps added to it, some of which I recall seeing in fan patches.
-The game natviely supports most modern resolutions up to 1920x1080.
-Despite its age the graphics are still very neat to look at and features like its day and night cycle make the game quite pretty.
-Note: You will have to register the game ingame via its product code allocated by steam to unlock its full content, which might scare some people off but I dont exactly see any harm in it. (not like most modern games dont require you to make accounts :p)

Gameplay:
Eurasian Dynasty (ED)
The ED originated from Russia and while they may not be the fastest, they certainly have some of the toughest units in the game featuring heavy tanks, artillery and bombers. They weaponry ranges from conventional weapons to heat rays.
Their basebuilding consists of placing a main 'core' at the center of your base from which you build pipes to connect a variety of structures and generators to power your network of buildings. They can also build walls and a variety of other defenses.
Their ressource gathering is done by mobile refineries which can hover from depot to depot and process all ressources gathered on the spot for a steady income.

Strength: Very tough units, able to turtle quite well using a ring of walls around the mainframe, simple ressource gathering
Weakness: Slow units, buildings are vulnerable to get disconnected from the frame and can get disabled due to lack of power, basebuilding takes up a lot of time and needs to be planned ahead a bit in order to make room for future buildings.


United Civilized States (UCS)
The UCS originated from the United states of america, they have a variety of mechs and jets at their disposal and use a lot of energy based weaponry as well as ballistic missiles.
Their basebuilding is probably the most 'normal' and executed by flying drones that place structures which then build themselves as they drain the ressources needed. Their bases have the unique feature to use add-ons to enhance buildings in a specific way, such as making generators create more power or making refineries generate more income.
Their ressource gathering is rather traditional and has flying harvesters land on top of the ressources, gathering them and returning back to the nearest refinery for dropoff.

Strength: Fairly easy to master, strong missiles backed up by laser weapons, simple basebuilding which doesnt need babysitting. Can place turrets and walls to some extend to provide decent defense. Can teleport freshly trained units.
Weakness: Their structures while efficient can get costy to replace with a bunch of add-ons added to them and expanding to get more ressources does require you to set up additional outposts. Their laser weaponry is prone to get tackled by shields early on which renders them inefficient.


Lunar Corporation (LC)
The LC created orbital colonies and initially settled down on the Moon. They were able to study alien technology and feature the most advanced weaponry out of all the races. Their vehicles are hovertanks, infantry has jetpacks and aircraft are speedy.
Basebuilding for the LC means placing a basic module on the ground and stacking other modules on top to create a tower which depending on modules you places can fill in a variety of roles from research and unit training to combat modules to turn them into tough fortresses. They can also place external turrets and laser walls and all structures can be placed anywhere as they are dropped in from the sky. (you can only call in a limited number of buildings at a time though)
Their ressource gathering is as simple as dropping a mining base next to a ressource field. They will harvest and process it automatically.

Strength: Some of the fastest units in the game, very strong weaponry that is specialized to usually fit a single purpose, probably have the ability to expand in terms of ressources easier than any other race, can build foward or hidden bases anytime, anywhere.
Weakness: Due to their 'stacking' mechanic of modules their structural integrity is often at risk and they are prone to have their buildings get sniped which are even more expensive to replace than fully modded ucs building, their early game units while fast are fairly weak in terms of hp.


Aliens
The aliens are a new addition in Earth 2160 and feature the most unique playstyle using cloning and evolution to create their units and having no ressource gathering in the traditional way.
They can morph strong defensive structures which are able to provide heavy cover for units while they clone and evolve or block off ressource points from your enemies.
Instead of ressource gathering their units absorb a small amount of ressources to evolve into different species, starting with a basic unit that has no way of attacking and a basic mothership you have to clone them to create more and evolve those into different strands to create the perfect army.

Note: It is advised that you keep at the very least one basic unit to replicate as you might be unable to reproduce if you dont!

Strength: Strong structures, heaviest aircraft in the game, fast and lethal units, can easily poke at hostile bases and harass them.
Weakness: Beyond static turrets no way to defend yourself, take great amounts of planning and macro management to keep track of your units and their evolutions, easy to get harassed and crippled if cloning units are exposed.


Virtual Agents:
Virtual Agents are 'Hero units' which will offer their services for the highest bidder. As Aliens have no means to store ressources they are unable to obtain any.
Agents pop up every now and then , initially after a few minutes three random ones will pop up and ask if the player wants to hire them. You have to be quick and go for whichever suits you best or simply bid on them all if you feel generous with your ressources. Your enemies also have the chance to obtain them and can make them a better offer. In the end they will join whichever side is willing to spend the most money on them.
Once hired you can spawn the VA anywhere you like and they will remain in your service for a limited amount of time till their contract expires, after which you have to pay them again. If they get killed their contract is also terminated.
Those Virtual agents offer a variety of bonuses for certain playstyles, such as reducing the cost of flying units by 25% or having your ground units start as veterans. The VA's also come in a variety of shapes and often are a powerful unit on their own that if used right can pack quite a punch.
You can have up to 3 agents at a time which will most likely start to chat with one another at some point. This usually leads to quite some hilarious conversations which might entertain you if you like bad puns and sarcastic comments.

Note: Virtual Agents can be disabled during game setup if you dont want to have them around.



Thats about all I can tell ya, if youd like to know more you should just take the game for a spin, especially since its currently on offer for a laughable price. The rts genre usually doesnt bring forth as many games as other genres do currently which is why many of us still play 'older' games to pass the time.
This one is a little gem, sure has its flaws but it can be a bunch of fun, especially if you're looking to get it to play with some friends of yours who are also willing to spend a single dollar or euro to get it.

Earth 2160
Featuring four races, each unique and interesting in their own way, Earth 2160 has an average storyline that doesn't really enthrall or engage in any way. There are three groups left from Earth who are fighting it out and trying to maintain a foothold in the future of mankind. Add to that an interesting alien race that has some especially unique features, and you have a recipe for a fun game. Earth 2160 has a campaign for each of the four groups: The European Dynasty, Lunar Corporation, and Union of Civilized States represent the groups from Earth, and the aliens representing the fourth playable race. If you're looking for a deep single-player experience, you're sure to find it with Earth 2160, as it takes time to work through the campaigns for all four groups.During the campaigns, you'll find out that each group really is different and depends upon a certain strategy to achieve victory. Another great aspect is the ability to research and create new units to combat the enemy tactics you encounter. Unfortunately, if you find yourself up against a unit that your newly created and research units are ill-equipped to defend against, you'll quickly find yourself on the losing side of the battle. Relying on a single strategy, weapon, or defense type will quickly lead to defeat. The key in Earth 2160 is to maintain a constant vigilance and be on the lookout for what sorts of technologies your enemies are employing, and work to create your own units to combat them. There is a ton of strategy involved in this, and it works to great effect.The interface for getting around, controlling your units, building your bases, and handling other options is a bit clunky. There are icons that have convenient tool tips that appear, which makes things a lot easier, but when you're looking for a specific action, you don't want to have to hover your mouse over each icon to find the one you are looking for.Graphically, the game is one of the best looking real-time strategy games I've ever played. You can zoom in to insane levels, and each unit looks as good up close as it does from a distance. Battles between groups of enemies are fantastically exciting and explosive looking, providing a brilliant show that almost overshadows the results. The environments are large and pleasant to look at, and once you've gotten your bases built up and lined with defenses, it's like gazing at a landscape straight out of a science fiction movie. One of the coolest things is the transition from day to night; watching your units light up the night is extremely cool. Another great graphical aspect is the trails that your vehicles leave on the ground. Tire treads, steps, it all looks amazing and comes together to form a fantastic-looking experience.Sound, on the other hand, is a mixed bag. One of the worst aspects of Earth 2160 are the voiceovers. The soundtrack is pretty good, and changes with the action, which is nice. It's nothing really excellent, but it does provide ambience and helps with the suspenseful atmosphere.There is a skirmish mode as well as multiplayer, and if you get tired of the lengthy campaign, you can always find a friend to play against or take on the computer in the skirmish battles.Earth 2160 is an excellent title that is sure to stand the test of time for real-time strategy fans.
