Earth 2160
Earth 2160 is a great game but might not appeal to everyone.

The game seems a bit outdated by today standards, especially graphics wise. Furthermore it's a somewhat slow paced game that requires time and thought put into it.

It's a science-fiction based RTS game featuring advanced base building, ressource gathering and combat. The economic aspect of the game is quite basic. Gather ressources to fund your base and units, base building is pretty extensive depending on the factions. The combat is quite good but challenging. One of the most important mechanics is the unit customization, through research you can design your own units with various strengths and weaknesses. This allows for some major tactical planning and you really need to think what type of unit is effective against another type of unit. Overall this mechanic is very rewarding but can be frustrating. Sometimes your units will just be annihilated and you won't have the time or patience to find a new design that suits your needs.

Two aspects of this game that I find very appealing are the factions and the campaigns. The factions are completely different and feel distinct. Each faction has a unique way of playing and focus, some have completely different structures and designs that opt for different playstyles. The mission campaigns are extremely well done, especially for an rts game. You have dialogues and cutscenes, some rpg elements as well and a decent storyline. Furthermore you will have several campaigns at your disposal to play.

The multiplayer is seviceable and works quite well. So are the graphics and soundtrack. Nothing to complain about.

Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

This is a quite interesting project so far and it's going to be even more promising in the future.
Pros:
- Two big modes are sure to make it into the release build: Singleplayer Campaign Mode (somewhat close to the BI classical campaigns) and Multiplayer Campaign (imagine a Clash of Clans in WWII setting... without constant donations reminder and the urge to watch the progress of your base each few hours).
- Classical isometric view on warm and homey 2,5D graphics. Just like the old times, but with better effects.
- Rock, Paper, Scissors gameplay in a whole - vehicles are good at destroying defences, infantry has something for everyone (apart from defences), and defences/obstacles when put in place can cripple any advancing enemy.
- Developers are listening to the community, setting the highest priority to bug hunting and making the most wanted features come out first.
- Great oldschool music, artwork, map decorations (some - with borderline humour)... You'll like it when you notice it :)

Contras:
- It's not BI as I thought it would be. Don't get me wrong - It's a fun game to play, but it's just not Blitzkrieg I. Not yet.
- BIII is kinda poorly balanced on higher, advanced levels. I believe it will be fixed soon, but atm t5+ of the headquarters can be pain (imagine fighting Pershings with your KV-1s).
- It's still Early Access. Expect to have some minor pathfinding bugs (I've met no other).

Overall result?
I'd say it's 7/10 for old Blitzkrieg players, 8/10 for Clash of Clans players and 9/10 for those dissapointed in Company of Heroes 2 fantasy-like setting (such as myself).

Update 11.24.2015
Game has surely evolved a lot since the last time I've launched it in the September. All sorts of improvements are here and ready to go:
1. Pathfinding got fixed in a small unit groups. Yes, tactical combat still requires a lot of micromanaging but hey, it's what the Blitzkrieg series was about since like forefer.
2. Developers really DO listen to the Community. All of the suggestions I've made as a regular Community member were answered to. Some made it into the game (like treating fortifications as if those were units in the means of a balance).
3. Generals provide a unique experience with each and every faction. You can customize both your army now and the defences of your base like you see fit.
4. Most balance issues are now gone, whilst 'Sauron's eye' should be fixed IMAO. It is a little bit too much OP.
5. Numerous UI improvements here and there finally made the game easy to navigate.
6. Should be first, actually... Now you can switch maps in Multiplayer Campaign. Yes. You can.

Blitzkrieg 3 - Review
Story:
Blitzkrieg 3 takes place in WWII Europe, where you control three forces through their battles:
Germany conquering France, Russia conquering Germany and America fighting for Sicily.

Gameplay:
In singleplayer, the game is a typical RTS, you command units, that are either added to your forces by you freeing them, fullfilling objectives or just as reinforcements. You have no impact on the types of units that your army is made of, so you basically have to adapt to your army, and not the other way around.
The three nations have the same units, maybe with minimal slight variations, but the overall gameplay is the same for all. And this is where strategy comes in:
The game is basically beatable with very few, very basic strategies, once you learned an effective way to defend/attack you can always go back to that, since
all nations play the same. Thus the singleplayer is nothing special.
The multiplayer on the other hand features something very unusual for this genre: You are provided with a base, the size of which grows with your level,
that you need to build up and defend with units and structures from other players. Upon an enemy attacking, your units are controlled by AI. You gain resources
over time, that you can use to buy and upgrade units and structures. When attacking, you are matched against a random player of similar level and have to fight their setup. It is an interesting concept, very often seen in mobile games.

Pros:
+Nice graphics, creating a fitting atmosphere
+Troops speak in their native language

Neutral:
~The multiplayer gameplay is new for this genre, but often seen on mobile devices
~Singleplayer offers nothing special

Cons:
-The singleplayer is very basic
-All nations play the same
-There is no straightup 1v1 battle

Conclusion:
I don't think I can give this game just one score, so I went ahead to give it a singleplayer-rating and a multiplayer-rating:
Singleplayer: 6.5/10
Multiplayer: 8.5/10

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

This is a fun game that is being updated on a regular basis- I'm not sure why there's so many negative reviews. For me, the pros and cons of this game are as follows:

Pros:
- Fun to build defenses and adjust them after watching replays of people attack your defenses
- Plan attacks and decide what force composition to use based on what general you use
- Quick games- they cap out at ~15 minutes
- Fairly rapid progression, with accruing bonuses based on how long it's been since you've played
- No microtransactions, so you avoid pay to win scrubs

Cons:
- It's not as complex as Company of Heroes - the tradeoff being that you don't spend an hour on each match
- Graphics are dated

If you want a WW2 multiplayer RTS fix but don't want to play Company of Heroes, this fits the bill nicely.

Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

I was hesitant at first to review Blitzkrieg 3, due to its mixed reviews on Steam. But given that its still in development, I figured Id give it a shot, and Im glad I did.

Blitzkrieg 3 is a fantastic strategy game, with features I havent seen elsewhere. The key thing to remember is that its not Company of Heroes. It isnt about moving your troops cover-to-cover. Its about blitzkrieglightning war. Its Pattons no holding ground strategy, and the strategy that allowed the then-evil Germans to steamroll half of Europe.

It also doesnt feel like a WWII game. You can play as Americans and still fight against Americans, and the same goes for the Soviets and Germans. It feels more like a post-apocalyptic war-game with WWII weapons, where you build your defenses and raid the camps of neighboring tribes.

Now that we have that out of the way, lets get to the point: these factors are what makes Blitzkrieg 3 fun. While one side needs to try and plow through the enemy, the other side needs to build a base to defend against the attack, and this means finding all kinds of creative ways to ambush them.

The game starts with you at your base. You get a set number of fuel and supplies to spend on upgrading building and units, or on your defenses. The base building is a game in itself, because your base is technically a full map that other players can attack at any moment.

Think of it like Home Alone, only with tanks and guns.

Read my full review here: http://techzwn.com/2015/07/blitzkrieg-3-is-like-home-alone-with-tanks-and-its-awesome/

I would complain about the fact that all you can do is attack other peoples bases but we got PVP gamemodes so maybe that might improve things. I honestly suggest you buy a game like Men of War AS2, COH or COH2. Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

So Blitzkrieg 3 is in my opinion a WW2 light RTS game. The multiplayer is a carbon copy of Quest for epic loot with a WW2 theme. You dont actually fight online opponents. You build upp a base with defences and raid other players bases to get more resources and upgrade your base.

During these raids the opponents base is controlled by an AI same goes for your base when invaded. If you are into that its ok. But dont expect VS multiplayer couse there is none yet.

My biggest gripe at the moment is lack off control of your units, by that i mean you cant tell your tanks which way to face and you cant give your infantry units orders like throw granades, run, or take cover.. Your units do this bythemselves hence why i call it a light RTS game.

The graphics are Ok. The sound's are mediocer at best, machine guns sound more like pee shooters instead of machineguns. It has destructible environments but nothing compared to CoH2. Unit movement and behaviour is not very realistic. Tanks move and turn way to quick instead of feeling like lumbering metal beasts.

If you want a more standard WW RTS i would reccomend CoH2 instead. Better audio

Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

As an early access game, Blitzkrieg 3 has a lot going for it.  However, early access also implies that you'll be receiving an incomplete or flawed experience from that of a retail (launch) game.  All of that said, I will try my best to provide an unbiased and objective review, detailing the qualities and deficits that Blitzkrieg 3 currently has.

Pros:

[+] Excellent graphics.  Beautiful, highly detailed maps--there are animals, roaming vehicles (trains, cars, etc.), and people who are doing daily tasks.  Trees fall down as tanks run into them, fortifications explode and crumble, and shots richochet off of vehicles creating an impressive realism.

[+] Base building.  Organizing your upgrades is always fun.  There are tradeoffs to consider as you are leveling up, because you can't possibly level everything up at once.  Do you want improved infantry?  How so?  Do you work on individual upgrades to existing units, do you upgrade research options or upgrade the barracks itself?   The tradeoffs aslo exist in how you upgrade your defenses.  Do you want a widespread defensive network, or do you want a few key structures that are hihgly upgraded?  The options are impressive.

[+] Strategy.  Despite what others are saying, there are lots of strategic options that open up conisderably the more you unlock and play.
-Command points can be spent on a variety of support options.
-Artillery to weaken defenses
-Smoke screen to hide advances
-Spies to scout the bases
-Reinforcements

[+] Army composition.  The options are pretty limitless here.  There are four classifications of vehicles and five classifications of infantry, and determining how many of each can be a very important decision going into battle.

Cons:

[!] Pathfinding.  This is something that will presumably get better over time, but right now tank pathfinding is horrendous, at times.  This becomes even more apparent the larger the vehicle is.  And taking into account that as you upgrade your vehicles, you replace them with a larger chasis (stug to jadgpanther for instance), this makes it even more problematic.

[!] No expanded multiplayer options.  Currently, there's only 1 v 1 asychronous battles.  I love the asynchronous battles, by the way, but I'd love to see 2 v 2 and greater options implemented.

[!] Building off the above, there are no integrated community options.  No friends list, no chat system, no way to invite others to look at your base and basically zero player-to-player communication.  [This is a huge negative]

[!] A lack of unit explanations.  I would love to see a detailed tactical tutorial or in-game guide.  Right now I have no idea how to use an MG squad versus an assault squad versus a normal rifleman squad.  All three seem relatively samey

I spend hours on creating a good defence with measuring out killzones and positioning my fortifications only to find out my opponent can take one infantry unit and use it`s line of sight to call in way to many barrages and wipe out all my hard work without being able to counter it with anything at all. After bombing down all your defences they just roll in 8 heavy tanks or tank destroyers and destroy what is left of your fortifications ( with of course using the line of sight from an infantry unit and the massive atack range of the tanks ).
Since the opponent bombed out all your units allready you don`t have any line of sight yourself anymore, and your opponent just takes out what`s left of your units using the fog of war. Other than a game like COH where you don`t get any time to organize defences and get overrun before you can even place one building, this game let`s you choose when you are ready to be attacked, so no stress and when you are ready you just accept a battle. At this time i think 30 euros is a bit too much for the game because the part i would spend the 30 euros on ( building and spend time in sorting out a good defence ) is not working for me. As an attacker i`ve won like 40 out of 60 battles in total, defending 3 out of 30 with 60 hours of reviewing and modifying my defences.

Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

I heartily recommend holding off on this purchase at the time of writing.

I see potential in this game. While the people comparing this to offline defence mobile games are not wrong, I believe this kind of gameplay can be an engaging experience. Others will talk about high-level balance, but I have only been able to sink a short time into this game due to the following concerns:

1) Unclear instruction. The tutorial currently gives brief highlights of where the first couple of buttons to press are, but after that, nothing. It is a trial-and-error system to figure out what you must do. I was confused. Still am, although after two hours I think I have most of the interface figured out.

2) Bugs. Yes, the game is early access. But you knew that, it's an early access review. Regardless of the release state of the game, I am here to say that the current state of bugginess impacts the playabilty of the game. Objectives dissapear from your screen and there appears to be no way to get them back. Unit pathfinding struggles immensely. You cannot target units behind buildings (you will target the building itself). There appears to be no way to adjust a unit's heading when controlling it in battle, causing micromanagement dances when trying to get a tank to stop reversing into the enemy.

3) The game seems to spazz out pretty horribly if you have a less-than-stellar internet connection. I have a less-than-stellar connection, but I am able to play other online games without major issue. This game freezes near-constantly, and for seconds at a time while playing. Worse, it does this WHEN TESTING AGAINST YOUR OWN BASE. Meaning, even what should be a local single-player experience appears to communicate through the game's servers.

4) Attack/Defence balance does seem to be massively off, though others with more time in the game will have better opinions on this. Simply put, the defender and attacker appear to get the same number of units. As any RTS player will tell you, this is an automatic win for any semi-competent attacker. Concentrate on one point in the enemy's defences, and it's pretty much right-click to win. The attacker can even continue to call up reinforcements to replace any lost units.

Until such time as all of these issues are resolved, I must strongly advise against purchasing this game.

Blitzkrieg 3
Early Access Review

Early Access Constructive Criticism :D No Donkey sh1it!

1.	To my pleasant surprise, the narrative in the tutorial mission alternated between Russian, German and American forces. I love the way the developers choose to give different perspectives during the same session. Its an interesting way of displaying what kind of impact, your actions have on your foe, as the perspective changes.

As you get the chance to play thru the eyes of your rival, you immediately see the aftereffect of your consequences. Its a new take on storytelling, its very entertaining and refreshing.

2.	Cool moments: During a tutorial mission, you are given a few German infantry to clear out a poor Russian village. And here I was, in the middle of nowhere hoping to spread democracy. Oh, well! We musn't disappoint our fuhrer, maybe we will find some MANA vodka.

I split my infantry into two squads. I started off by sending squad one to occupy an empty house on the outskirts of the village. This immediately started a firelight, my first squad was taking incoming fire from a house further up the street.

I tactically maneuvered my second squad thru a forest into an assaulting position on the flank. Using the new ability assault building, my second squad dashed forward out of the bushes into the house, screaming, pulling ears and vomiting on a chicken, ending up with five Russian KIA inside, oh and we found really fluffy teddy bear in the basement, to celebrate our victory, my heroic soldiers baptized it PUTIN.

3.	Sniper Unit - Sounds inaccurate in game. Last time I checked, yelling wasnt part of the sniper weapons inventory. I swear to God, every time you give the sniper an order the dude goes ape sh1it, and starts screaming patriotic slogans.

The entire idea of having a dedicated unit going stealth, is silence. At least put some effort into making him act covert and whisper in response. Small changes to sound, can make a big difference to the atmosphere and characteristics of a unit.

4.	There seems to be no function at the moment to see your troops behind objects. And with such a rich and beautifully detailed environment, sometimes its hard to pinpoint your units in the field, you constantly need to reselect the units to find them.

Sorry, but I dont want to spend my time searching for my troops on the battlefield. Especially when there is a mission timer involved.  Some sort of highlight is needed to distinguish your troops from the background, Men of war dose this brilliantly. Take note.

5.	Ability About face - Being a Company of Heroes player for many years. I found myself selecting a vehicle and trying to drag the front armoured part towards the enemy. Im abruptly, startled and confused when I realise that no such function is available in Blitzkrige 3.

Its 2015, happy new year! Abilitys like About face should be at my fingertips, and not hidden away in the far-flung-bottom right hand corner of the UI menu.

Yes, yes, I know! There is a Hot Key, you can press R. But thats so 2005, Im not stating that simplification is bad. But coming from a CoH frame of mind, my RTS behaviour is tuned to having fast and responsive controls. In the current state, I dont feel that responsiveness is coming thru in Blitzkrige 3.

I know there is a red compass-marker you can utilise to set your vehicles direction, but that option is way too sluggish and clumsy to use. Having an instant clock, with an arch of fire, popup underneath your vehicle is faster and better way to do it.

Why not include a more fine-tuned approach of controlling your vehicles for those that want that possibility. Instead of this barebones, point and click. There is definitely room for improvements to be made regarding this issue.

6.	At the current state Blitzkrige 3 does not offer any cover system for infantry. This is something that we should expect by todays standards. There is a missed opportunity here in NOT letting the player use destructive environments as part of cover.

A lot of effort has gone into creating a detailed destructive environment for Blitzkrige 3. And the developers have succeeded. I just wish the developers made the collateral damage more than just eye candy.

Let me illustrate an example.  - Battle for Monte Casino, On 15 February 1944 the abbey was almost completely destroyed in a series of heavy American-led air raids. The bombing was conducted because many reports from troops on the ground suggested that Germans were occupying the monastery, and it was considered a key observational post by all those who were fighting in the field.

Only after the bombing were the ruins of the monastery occupied by German Fallschirmjger (paratroopers), aiding them in their defence, because the ruins provided excellent defensive cover.

The point Im making, is that the destructive environment in Blitzkrige 3 could have been utilized to benefit both sides. This could have created some unique variation of strategies in battles. What you get instead is repetitive gameplay, with limited paths of approach.

7.	Which brings me to my next point, I find it odd that the developers of Blitzkrige 3 strongly incentivise the concept of artificial intelligence for defensive purposes, in base mode. Calling it core component of the multiplayer experience.

Yet, the game is lacking any meaningful Ai behaviour, the way Ai responds to human players is with basic triggers, which activate on conditions. Example: A is true, there for activate B and repeat, basically.

Someone once said, The best defence is an offense! So far, I havent found any way to change Ai behaviour perimeters when defending your base to aggressive stance or turtle defensive, hit and run or balanced tactics.

Its not fair to say that the Ai is inadequate. It dose its job, but it doesnt like to deviate from a set path. Doing anything complicated like taking the initiative or making a surprise manoeuvre is out of the question. Its all scripted and predictable behaviour, dont expect to encounter General Rommel in the field, anytime soon.

8.	One more thing, the tip popup in the tutorial disappears to fast, its stressful and should be fix. This problem is especially hard on new players, who are trying to learn the game.  Your popups dont have next tip or a back to previous tip buttons. WHY! WWwwwwhhhyy!!! WHHHHHYYY!!!!... . .. .why!

9.	OMG! I have no idea what the designers or concept artist were smoking when they created this Modern-bluish-sci-fi-metallic-transformers looking UI menu, Im pretty sure it wasnt water vapour. For the LOVE of GOD, the current UI doesnt fit the WW2 themed framework at all, change it.

Other than that, its a good early access start.

Dont forget to thumbs up if you like my preview and would like to see more. Dont be a stranger leave a comment. Cheers 4 reading.

With less love BatSithCrazy!

Simply Chess
TL:DR - Chess.com is the better free chess game, especially for online play.

Some things to know about this particular implementation of chess:

* Two clicks to move (one to select your piece, one to move). No drag-and-drop option, which is the biggest dealbreaker for me.
* Online play has extremely limited options for time controls (fastest is 1 minute/turn, second fastest is 10 minutes/turn).
* Computer play has no time controls and 100 difficulty levels simply labelled 1-100.
* Ad-free premium is $4.99.

I can make a case for this being a decent casual tablet game, but otherwise I would rather go onto chess.com.

Avoid. Avoid, avoid, avoid! You want free chess? There's several different things you can get instead of this. This is one of the worst implementations of chess I've tried. To the developer: if you have to release yet another chess program, at least make yours stand out. This one has nothing. It doesn't look very good, it has awful AI, it doesn't have normal chess clocks (fixed time per move instead), it glitches, and there are some serious very basic problems with it. Let's name a few shall we?

* It puzzles me how the AI levels were implemented for single player game. Both on level 1 and level 100 difficulty, the opponents makes moves like he was a monkey and picked the random one available. It places pieces on squares where they can be captured and in general plays terribly. For reasons I can't comprehend, it is stronger for example on level 45 difficulty, but don't expect fireworks.

I searched for a button to flip the board to actually view it from the perspective of my pieces and I didn't find it.
* Music glitches at random moments starting to make a repeated choking noise like a stuck gramophone.
* If you lose internet connection, even while playing single player, you'll be bugged by some cryptic error messages covering your scren

On top of all these problems, it keeps annoying players with advertisements.

Why would you want to play it? Other than to farm cards or perhaps gain achievements if you're an achievement hunter. And also... Why would anyone give this positive reviews? In the field of free chess, this one is a step backwards. Not only other existing chess programs and services are better and more professional, but also they are actually free and don't annoy you with ads every time you start a new game. If this game was another genre, it wouldn't have any positive reviews, because people would just say this is just a terrible rip-off of XXX

Simply Chess
It's chess.
On Steam.
It's free and offers single-and multiplayer locally and online.

...

Have I mentioned that it's chess?

If you really need more information to decide whether you want this game or not, here goes:

Gameplay:
Simply Chess is a turn-based strategy game with gameplay mechanics that closely emulate tactical warfare scenarios including multiple specialist units that need to be coordinated with the goal of ending the oppressive monarchist regime of the other side's king (as opposed to the benevolent, generous and generally awesome monarchist regime of our king). While the attempted targeted military assault on an enemy head of state may sound like a brutal, bloody premise, it should be mentioned that the graphics have been toned down to a degree that lets you easily forget that this game is basically about two armies trying to obliterate each other.

Sound:
There's sound. If you like classical music, you'll like the sound here. Because it's classical music. Also, no dying screams of the lowly soldiers whose hopes, dreams and future are thrown away to enable the continued decadence of their ruling class, so that's a plus. Or not, if you're actually into that sorta thing, you creepy, disturbed human being...

Characters:
The units in the game each have unique... I guess we could call it special moves. Or just moves. Let's go with directional capabilities.
Yeah, the unit types all move differently. In terms of balance, the game does a good job of evening the playing field between the two sides, even if White tends to have a systematic advantage, getting a headstart in the default mode (which one may change if one is so inclined).
Other than that the factions in the game are not all that different from each other - a stroke of genius that supposedly aims to make the player think how both sides in a war are usually just staffed by poor schmucks who get to suffer the consequences of their respective leaders' poor life decisions.
The game has strong RPG elements, such as upgradeable units (pawns can level up to become queens if the requirements are met) and... yeah, no - that's it.
I'm sure that, given enough time, the developers will get the hang of balancing the various units in the game - as of now, queens are hopelessly OP and just waiting for a nerf.

Difficulty:
The single-player AI can be adjusted from disinterested cat randomly trying to push pieces off the table" to "knows how to play chess much better than I do" up to "dear Kasparov

This is a game with chess that is free, with integrated multiplayer.

It has ads, yes. But they can be removed for a reasonable price.

The dev team have been quick to fix bugs, and have kept in constant contact with the community. The game is plain, and could do with some improving. But it is clear that they listen, and for any issues, just approach the devs through the discussions.

On a side note, anyone complaining that this game is free, and saying that is a bad thing? You are absolute morons. It is free, and to try to use that as a negative purely on the basis of it's being free is inherently anti-consumer. You can literally test out if this game is for you, without paying a penny up front. Buy premium if you want to feel like you've bought this game. otherwise, just enjoy that it's free.

Of everything on steam, a decent, free chess game with a responsive developer is a breath of fresh air, compared to all the pay-for Slaughtering Grounds and Temper Tantrums that just want your money and don't care about quality.

Of course, this isn't the best chess game out there. but with the dev team pushing through the bugs, and their quick response time to critique, I've no doubt in my mind that this game will get better.

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 - Episode II
For those that missed the first episode of Sonic 4, this is a 2D platforming game staring everyone's favorite blue hedgehog. The plot is the same as its always been, but with a twist. Dr. Robotnik, the evil antagonist of most every Sonic game has now teamed up with Metal Sonic! The dude with 90s attitude isn't alone though, he now has Tails to go with him. With Tails, come new mechanics, such as jumping into the air, and calling Tails to lift Sonic like a helicopter. If you're on the ground and use the tag button, it summons Tails to combine the two for a super fast attack. If you need to use the helicopter ability, the game will have a little billboard to tell you. This game feels more a kin to the Game Boy Advance games than the original Genesis games which the first episode clearly drew inspiration from.

In Episode 2, you have four zones with three acts each followed by a boss fight as a fourth act. Not just that, but later into the four hour game, you unlock a playable Metal Sonic with four zones and one act each. These zones use assets from the first episode. So in all, there are 16+ levels for you to master. These levels feel a lot longer than the first episode and the Genesis games as a whole. Some levels feel like six minute marathons with no end in sight.

The levels are big and offer many paths to the exit. You'll have to avoid an array of enemies, spikes, and even death traps. You'll collect rings everywhere and these rings aren't just because dullards love shinny things, but as long as Sonic has at least one ring, he can take another hit. Even if you have 100 rings and get hit, only 30 will spray out of Sonic. When you get hit with no rings, it means death for the fuzzy blue guy. There are plenty of check points in each level if you die. A game over simply means that you'll need to start the level again. If you collect 100 rings in a level, you get an extra life. If you have 50+ rings at the end of the level, a giant ring will appear that will take you to a special bonus stage.

These bonus stages are updated versions of the old Sonic 2 bonus stages. You'll follow Sonic running down a 3D half pipe. You can boost and jump. There are a few check points that need X amount of rings to get past. So as Sonic, you'll solemn down the tube moving left and right, collecting rings and dodging obstacles that will lose you rings. At the end you'll find a chaos emerald.... that somehow isn't green. Whatever. Collect all seven to unlock a yellow Super Sonic.

New to the Sonic 4 series is local co-op and even online co-op, but since the game came out in 2011, good luck trying to find a partner. There are online leader boards for time attacks. It adds to the replayability I guess, but more than that, the game has a red star ring on each level to collect. These rings are either tough to find or tough to get. Its an extra challenge for veterans.Sonic and Metal Sonic play the same. Left and right to move, with a single button to jump. Hold down to duck and hit the jump button to start a spin dash to get momentum to go up slopes. You still need to charge it which takes time. That's why the airborne dart attack is not only a much better way to gain speed instantly, but you can also lock in on targets accurately hit them no matter what the angle. Episode 2 didn't make as much use of the homing attack as the first episode, but it does make travel easier, darting for an enemy or a springboard. The only difference between Metal Sonic and the ordinary version is lack of an ally. No helicoptering around or bowling through enemies.

Calling Tails just feels slow. Tails automatically zips right back to Sonic wherever he is, unless he just died, but it just halts the game to wait. The Sky Fortress kicks off with an airplane mission that has Sonic atop Tail's plane that gives you full control to move the plane left, right, up and down. Complete with Sonic able to jump and attack. Under normal circumstances, I'd think it diversifies gameplay having a plane dodge enemies and twirl through barricades to destroy them. This felt like a slow auto scrolling level (act). There was still a part where the 2D platforming returned, but then it was just back to being on top of a plane. It felt dull, slow and boring. Then having to fight the boss on the plane was unfun.

The real snag that I have for this game is how long and dull the boss battles are. They take traditional, classic boss battles and completely twist them around into mega bosses. See I like the twists and fighting giant bosses, I just don't like how tedious every boss was. Having to damage each boss for three minutes before the final phase of the boss fight left me clueless and dead ate up most of my 4 hours in the game. These 3 minutes on each attempt felt like 10 and I was never in any real danger. It wasn't a challenge surviving the 3 minutes, it was just a delay for the real challenge. At least the game takes full advantage of having Metal Sonic as an enemy. You get three boss fights against him.

The game has other down sides too, like a timed race against sand flooding an area. Sonic needs to go up, breaking through barriers, then down. This would separate the casual players from the hardcore. It ate up two dozen lives and was quite the difficulty spike. Then on the final two levels, when Sonic went down hill or uphill, the entire screen would shift so Sonic wasn't running downhill, he was on a horizontal plane. It was disorienting, and might cause someone motion sickness.

Water areas feel better in this game than they have in the past. Sonic jumps higher and Tails can carry him, so you have more maneuverability. Under water still slows down Sonic and he can't swim. If you're underwater too long, Sonic will need to get oxygen from big air bubbles that drift their way up.
The soundtrack feels Genesis in a good way. Percussion and synth horns. Its all upbeat happy game music. The graphics are bright and vibrant. There is a good color pallet here. A dusty yellow castle with an aquatic greenish blue moat. A winter wonderland theme park, lit up for a holiday with blue ice water. A metallic sandy red oil rig in a yellow desert. A yellow sky fortress with fans to propel Sonic into the air. Dr. Robotnik's gray and purple metal lair. As each zone progressed, the acts would change their color pallets so you'll see day turn to dusk. It all adds to making each of the three acts feel different. Having Metal Sonic's 4 different zones with 1 act each adds a lot of diversity, even if 3 acts each would have been nicer.

Even with all the bad, its still a good game. Better than most other 2D platforms out there for $15. I enjoyed the first episode better, but it felt like they took the gameplay a step in the right direction. If its on sale, take a risk.

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 - Episode II
I want to get this out of the way before starting this review, why was this episodic? This easily could've been the next main series Sonic game as Episode 2 looks WAY different than Episode 1. But was it for the best? Yes. The engine has been updated for full 3D graphics like in Sonic Generations and the physics have been fixed, which was a major problem in Episode 1. Another problem in Episode 1 was unoriginality, which Episode 2 changes around (apart from Not Wing Fortress Zone). The bosses are now not complete jokes but I found the Eggman bosses annoying and enduring complete with a 17 second loop boss theme. I have much more enjoyment with the Metal Sonic fight in White Park before Sky Fortress ruined his reputation. The music is still Mega Drive samples but I found more catchy tunes in this game than Episode 1. Also, this game has Tails who follows Sonic like in Sonic 2 and you can perform tag actions with him, like flying, swimming underwater and 69. So is this an improvement over Episode 1? In my opinion, yes. Still not worthy of the name Sonic 4 but it's a decent improvement. 8/10

It's fast and the highlit of the game are the boss enemies, because you haven't seen those boss fights in previous sonic games. It feels so more fresh and more like a unique game. Summed up you can say: Average Levels and Awesome boss fights.

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 - Episode II
Sonic 4 Episode 2 is a game I'm completely inconsistent with. I played it for half an hour and thought it wasn't worth playing through, played it again from beginning to end and hated it, and then played it through again and honestly thought it was on par with the Genesis games.

In comparison to Episode 1 it's definitely better. The physics are improved and the graphics no longer look like New Super Mario Bros. but worse. A lot of people complained that classic Sonic was absent from the first game, and took it way overboard, but I kinda do agree that modern looks really unnatural here. Thankfully there's a mod for that anyway if it bothers you that much.

The game controls a lot better than Ep1 and it's at least satisfying in this game, but still not quite as solid as in the classic games or even Generations. Sonic feels like he lacks weight on the ground and momentum building isn't quite right, sometimes requiring homing attack spamming just to reach your max speed on the ground.

The level themes are all blatantly reused concepts with the exception of White Park which while I can compare it to some levels it doesn't outright copy anything. I hate the fact that a game selling itself as Sonic 4 is almost nothing but recycled levels and enemies, but the levels themselves have so many new concepts that it's still pretty fresh as a whole, and the likenesses of Episode 2's levels to classic levels isn't as offensive as in Ep1... with the exception of Sky Fortress which is nearly identical.

The game's visuals are absolutely gorgeous. I'd say Sonic 4 Ep2 is the most scenic game in the series. It's incredibly polished visually. I can't say the same about the soundtrack, though. While I initially really hated it, I realized on subsequent playthroughs with Super Sonic available I never used him for just one reason; I didn't want to stop the level music. While I do actually really love the compositions themselves, the instrumentation is horrid. They clearly went for a Genesis style tinny-ness to the synths but it just sounds awful on some tracks, specifically Sky Fortress Act II and the Death Egg's theme, two songs which I would actually really like if they used better synths.

Oh yeah it's also really short. This game has five zones in total and 25 levels in all if you count the boss levels and special stages. I think with a casual runthrough of both this and Sonic 2, Sonic 2 would still be longer, but I consider Sonic 2 to be fairly short for a Sonic game I dunno. Completing the game without all of the Chaos Emeralds yields a message to go collect them, but there's really no reason to, because it does nothing to the ending. Little Planet is still stuck inside the Death Egg while Sonic and Tails feel good about themselves in their escape pods. This could be thought of as a lead-in to Episode 3, but as of now Sega has no plans for one. One of the developers has said that they might make one if Ep2 sold well. Did it? I dunno but I certainly don't want the Sonic 4 series to end like this.

The game was actually short enough that I turned to achievement hunting to elongate it. Which was odd as this was after I'd already had my fill of this game and dismissed it as another bad Sonic entry. I actually WANTED to come back to collect achievements and actually found a lot of fun with the game, both in gathering the achievements and just playing the game itself. However I will say that the achievements are absolutely pointless. Certain gameplay elements like the Red Rings and presence and abundance of rings before boss encounters were clearly just implemented for the game's achievements on release, but getting said achievements has no bearing on the actual game whatsoever. Collecting all the Red Rings or getting the last hit on every boss as Super Sonic, none of this affects the game at all. It doesn't even have a list of the achievements in game so really it's questionable why they're even there other than to make this short game slightly longer.

All in all though I did find a lot of fun with this. The game's length as well as reused settings are the biggest problems, but they're pretty well made up for with a beautiful presentation, pretty enjoyable music and most of all a lot of good level gimmicks and physical designs. Is it as good as the classics? Eh, probably not, if only because it's not completely orginal, but I had just about as much fun with it anyway.

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 - Episode II
This is the game that every fan of the classic sonic games should own

Sonic the Hedgehog 4 - Episode II
Sonic the Hedgehog, that little blue ball of fur. He whizzes around in a blur. Faster than a speeding bullet. The thrill! The exhilaration!

Those wonderful feelings that come to mind whenever I think of Sonic and his buddies. When thinking of a character like Sonic, it's hard to separate nostalgia from true feelings. Hopefully I'll be able to do that!

Sonic 4: E2 is a fun platformer. Colourful landscapes, and cute enemies create a vibrant atmosphere. The graphics are acceptable for a 2D game in this generation. The game struggles to run on low end machines, even those that pass the system requirements. The game just isn't playable with system lag, or low FPS.

The gameplay is okay, but I do have a few issues. To me Sonic was a different kind of platformer. It was all about whizzing through the levels as fast as possible. I got great joy from timing my jumps just right, getting enough coins for the special levels and bouncing off the enemies on the way. Unfortunately S4E2 doesn't feel right. Sonic at full speed feels sluggish, and that's a word you never want associated with our heroic hedgehog. I never felt out of control, Sonic never flew off the screen. Some people might call that a good thing, but I think a fair few fans would agree with my perspective.

I was able to play some levels co-op. The levels are the same, one player controls Sonic, the other Tails. The problem with co-op is as soon as one character gets a little bit away from the other, the player behind has to use the catch up button. This just made the game feel like a chaotic mess. However, this chaotic mess was extremely fun. It enabled some awesome near-death escapes.

The game is trying hard to be like the 2D Sonic games of old. It introduces some new abilities, like forming a super-ball of death with Tails (which is the best way to go through 80% of levels), or dashing through the air by double jumping. Ultimately this is where it fails. It's an okay platformer, and it has a pricepoint that reflects the length of the game but it doesn't stand up to classic Sonic games.

Whilst the game does not stand up against previous Sonic games, it is quite a fun platformer. The levels are a nice length and fun to run through once. There isn't much replayability there though.

Bottom Line: Fun co-op game. A little lacklustre when compared to classic Sonic.

Call of Juarez: The Cartel
The Call of Juarez series is one I'd definitely recommend giving a go. Every game in the series is distinct and has its own identity, which is something I really appreciate. I'll avoid going into too much detail about the rest here, but they're all a good time with individual strengths and weaknesses that form a satisfying whole.

Unfortunately, the defining characteristic of game number three, The Cartel, is that it's an utter shambles. The classic Wild West setting of the previous games was ditched for a staggeringly uninspired modern-day Los Angeles/Mexico counterpart, which is exactly as appealing as it sounds (i.e. not at all). Likewise, the hole left by the entertaining and likeable cast of the first game and Bound in Blood (like legendary gunslinger Ray McCall) is filled with some of the flattest caricatures to ever spout tired one-liners. Once all the character and charm of Call of Juarez has been stripped away, what you're left with is a medicore first-person shooter that is an absolute chore in single-player and probably not much better in the new co-op mode. Solo players be warned: your AI partners are incompetent, and they will make no effort to hide it, though they will continually belittle your performance as you carry them for the game's entire duration.

Lackluster AI, boring gunplay, dull visuals and an uninteresting plot combine for eight hours of unmitigated tedium. The only saving grace is the way the game ends, which could have been a pretty cool conclusion to a much better game, but is of course held back here by being part of The Cartel. In retrospect it's good that the series had one final outing after this, though The Cartel remains a testament to how quickly good games can go bad. It's almost worth playing just for that lesson, though I'd suggest you try any of the others over this rubbish.

Call of Juarez: The Cartel
Even though I'm giving it a thumbs up, I have mixed feelings about this game. The Cartel is the worst game in the Call of Juarez series, but it does have a few features that other games in the series (and even many co-op FPS games in general) don't have and make this game unique and somehow enjoyable to play. I would recommend this, but only when it's heavily discounted and you've got one or two friends to play in co-op with.

PROS+ Good campaign mode with an intriguing (and underrated) storyline and characters, 4 endings and amazing soundtrack. It includes co-op mode, which is required for the full experience.
+ Replayable: 3 playable characters each with their own objectives, roles and dialogues (e.g. talking with different characters on the cellphone). Playing the story once with one character, in fact, may lead to plot-holes.
+ Varied levels with car chases, nightclub shooting, highways and more.
+ Random challenges mid-game (e.g. kill X enemies before the other players). It kinda kills the teamwork sometimes but I find it to be a nice addition, also because the main characters, plot-wise, don't get quite along with each other.

CONS- Unfinished: the game got released when its development wasn't finished yet. It is technically horrible, with dull graphics, many bugs and audio issues. Expect frustrating moments.
- The main menu and the first levels are dull (luckily the game gets slightly better and more interesting afterwards).
- The gunplay, the driving and grenades.
- No drop-in joining (players can only join your co-op match at the start of a level).
- Multiplayer is dead.

Personal rating: 58/100

The game as-is, is MOSTLY technically horrible, but if you can get past its technical issues and focus on everything else, you might enjoy it in co-op with one or two friends.
If only Techland had more time to develop this it could have probably been a masterpiece; co-op mode is good and unique, the story is decent with memorable moments, but the rest is heavily unpolished. Dead Island, which is made by the same devs, got released in the same year.

Tip before you play: don't tell your friends what you're doing and what your character says in certain moments for the full experience!

Call of Juarez: The Cartel

Call of Juarez: The Cartel
The Mexican Drug War, Juarez style.
Call of Juarez: The Cartel, third installment into Techland's CoJ series, seems like the misfit child of the bunch.  It's not as good as Call of Juarez: Gunslinger; it's not a game to be taken seriously or to carry any real expectations for, whether you're a fan of this developer or not.  As action shooters go, it's definitely more of the same.  It did provide me a brief bit of fun & includes a potentially decent cooperative experience.

The Dead Island series & Dying Light are by Techland too, so if you liked those you'll be at home with The Cartel, which looks and feels similar in a number of ways.  Level design, enemy AI, linearity of missions, visuals/art, side tasks involving item collection, gun aiming & handling, driving & playable characters with unique personalities & combat characteristics all felt familiar.  What you shouldn't expect much of in The Cartel is homage to the CoJ series itself, 'cuz there ain't much.  You do get to play as a modern day McCall, dual wield revolvers, take a brief jaunt through a familiar place & hear a schpeel from a guy who's obsessed with the treasure of Juarez.  None of that gives this a real connection to the rest of the series, however.  In my opinion it lacks the flair that makes the others entertaining.

By 2011 standards The Cartel is decent, & I'd say by today's (2015) it's mediocre but worthy of purchase on the cheap.  I got it on sale and can't imagine anyone doing otherwise, by now.  It's a very brief campaign consisting of 15 missions; took me about 7 hours to finish on Medium difficulty, with the AI companions rather than real teammates.

The AI teammates worked out well enough, although I regrettably didn't play it with anyone else & thus missed out on what looks like a fun three player co-op.  You can breach rooms together, provide covering fire allowing allies to advance & also engage in some friendly competition via the Secret Agenda feature (each law enforcement agent has an ulterior motive & they each mistrust each other, so you try to catch the other two red-handed while being sneaky & accomplishing your own hidden objective unnoticed).

I tried doing some multiplayer action online but was unable to find anyone for the Cops vs. Criminals mode or the online campaign mode.

This game is published by Ubisoft & requires their client, Uplay to run alongside Steam.

There were some (sadly not too) farfetched news clip cutscenes and a lot of interagency bluster between the LAPD, FBI & DEA that I found entertaining.  The entire game is pretty much a sensationalized portrayal of the Mexican Drug War.  Each character & most of the dialogue was cliche.  I feel like I'm describing a Hollywood blockbuster film.

I'm not saying I wouldn't recommend Call of Juarez: The Cartel to anyone; it was okay.  It just doesn't merit recommendation unless you're looking for a quick bit of shoot-em-up action & don't have better alternatives - or if you're a big fan of this dev & just crave that experience.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
Everybody look at me 'cause I'm sailin' on a boat!

After two hours of play, I have to say that I'm impressed.  After just a couple tutorial missions (each and all skippable in turn), I was turned loose to make or break my company.  After a few lucrative ore contracts, I found myself smuggling contraband on the Mediterranian.  And got busted.  And my cargo seized.  And fined.  And my ship impounded for a week.  A time-based contract I still had in the hold expired, so there were penalties there.  And harbor masters didn't care to allow convicted smuggers in their ports, so harbor fees went up.  All that in two hours and not a moment that felt repeatative.

A few features that I liked:  Your home port determines what bonuses your company gets.  I picked Lisbon for +5% on ore contracts and -10% to fuel.  The trick is, the smaller the port, the larger the bonuses.  So you have a reason to keep smaller ports and the ships that can service them.

There is some ship customization.  The Feeder I started with had three levels of Hull and Engine upgrades, which increased range and speed respectively.  There was also a license upgrade that would allow me to carrry what appeared to be hazardous waste.  Unfortunately, there does not appear to be options for custom paint or appearance (other than your ship name emblazoned upon the stern and bow).

I remember reading a comment somewhere saying that the music was repeatative and annoying.  To me, it sounded like every port had it's own song.  And each port felt VERY unique.  I'm already developing favorites and least favorites.

The only meh item I encountered dealt with other ship traffic.  Large ships move fast and looked intimidating at first, but it turns out they can stop on a dime and give the player right-of-way.  I would have liked to have seen navigation lights and right-of-way implemented (and fines for failure to obey maritime traffic laws).

Anyway, back to my ship.  I'm saving up for a fleet.  And I'm naming all my vessels after internet porn sites.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
OK, this review is primarily for the campaign game as I still am in the progress of completing it.

THE GOOD:
If you remember Ports Of Call, this game has a very familiar feel to it.  So much so that I would consider it the spiritual successor to that fine game.  The ship docking is nearly identical, smaller feeder ships are more difficult to dock than the larger post panamax & larger ships that have side streamer jets that will allow much better maneuverability than the tiny ships.
Many varied ports are available worldwide to sail into and each port has very unique feel to it.  Hamburg & Santos are especially technical and can be quite challenging and fun to sail into at full speed.  They have an option to pay a tug to skip the manual docking for a fee based on your ship size.  The fee can be quite a hit to the profitability of the runs... Which leads me to the Bad...

THE BAD:
Profitability:  I have noticed that the smaller ships, while they carry much less cargo, and in some cases are significantly slower, are FAR more profitable than the larger ships.  Cargoes are 3 to 5 times more profitable per container than the larger ships.  THIS IS A COLOSSAL FLAW IMO, and a huge reason that my fleet of over 200 post panamax ships is starting to bog down my computer.  I refuse to make runs where the cargo value for my huge UCLV ship is equal to a post panamax ship 3 size classes smaller.
I have found that there are ways to crock the game model by leaving feeder ships in the company contract ports to generate hordes of tiny highly profitable contracts meant for feeder ships, but this exploit should not be needed.  The value of the cargo should remain similar through all the ship classes to motivate players to want to get the giant ships (which are a blast to drive) because they are big money as well as big fun.  Instead I am forced to slog through thousands of port tug fees to remain profitable.  Which leads me to the UGLY...

THE UGLY:  The worst part of the campaign is the outright thievery of the investor.  The first several status upgrades come along at reasonable intervals and have logical milestones to nudge the player to create a shipping empire.  Once the player hits the Magnate level though, the game bogs down into mindnumbing repetition.  The game becomes a treadmill of completing company contract after company contract.  The fun quests" of filling a whole slew of varied contracts to a specific city are no more.  The "driving quests" where you are tasked with parking several of each ship are gone.
Tycoon level is the worst though.  Your only goal is to gather enough money to buy out this thief

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
I am not much of a game player, but have always been interested in the shipping business and business simulation. I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed playing this game. Some people will enjoy the docking of the vessels in the various harbors. As you gain experience you will be able to get to and from the dock faster. Some ports are extremely easy (Lisbon), and others, quite challenging (get one of the larger boats in and out of Vancouver). So people looking for a game that builds your skills handling various ships you will likely enjoy this.

There may be some small issues with the underlying rules. For example, was surprised I could pickup cargo from NY for Havana. Suspect that isn't a realistic route.--more likely such goods travel to an intermediate port first (like Halifax). Also, not totally sure the rules follow the Jones Act. But one can really spend time figuring out how to keep the vessels as loaded as possible, and efficiently moving the most TEUs for the most money. I didn't like it when my ships had less than 50% of the capacity in use at any one time. I found this more challenging then moving the boats around, and therefore I would sometimes just let the game dock the ship to save time even though it negatively affected my reputation.

Again, not a gamer, but surprised how much time  I have spent playing and enjoying this game. If you like simulations, you'll probably find this entertaining, if not informative.


TransOcean: The Shipping Company
This is the first game I purchased via the Steam recommendations.  I am certainly not disappointed.  So far, I have 10 hours in the game, and I feel addicted.

This is a fairly simple simulator/logistics game.  The game has a tutorial, and I'm playing through it.  However, if you played similar games, such as Cities in Motion or Railroad Tycoon, then you can probably figure this out.  You buy a ship, get a contract, and then deliver the goods.  You have investors, you can take out a loan, and your ship will need fuel and maintenance.  From that standpoint, it is very easy.  As you get more ships, you gain more capacity but lose some capability.  Eventually, you can create company specific contracts that require delivery of a certain good to a certain location; at this point the complexity starts to become apparent.  To keep it interesting, you also have to deal with storms, pirates, and fires at sea.

While the game is fun to play, it still needs some polish.  I've had a few popup notifications remain on the screen.  I can play through them and sometimes get them to disappear, but its a bug.  While there are hazards, like storms and pirates, they purely random rather location specific, thus avoidable.  For example, I had a piracy near the Canaries, and I hit a storm with one vessel while another vessel sailed through the same area at the same time without the storm.  Personally, I find these oddities to be minor imperfections and potential room for growth in the development.  Overall the game is very solid platform and is good enough for this early release.

A larger area for growth is the games focus on cargo container shipping.  I commented about this in relation to US ports on the forums.  I was happy to see the game designer respond within hours of my comments.  While my request won't go fulfilled for now, I'm satisfied knowing that they understand the issue.

I'm definitely getting my money's worth from the game.  I think the game is playable for most ages.  If you are into sims like this, you'll love it.  If you prefer FPS games, then you'll probably hate this game as it is not meant for you.  I recommend this to all the simmers out there.

If you never encountered the 90s classic Ports of Call Amiga game then this Tycoon merchant marine simulation game may open your mind to how oddly addictive and geeky this kind of game can be.

It kind of appears to be another version of the Ports of Call game brought forward into the 21st Century though some of the features such as a few entertaining, sometimes nailbiting minigames are sadly missing which kinda like takes a bit of the soul away from what made the classic so popular many years ago.

http://www.metallicat95.com/?p=388 -- my review page


TransOcean has all the nice elements for a trading game  transport cargo from port to port, trying to make the most money and boost your reputations in order to improve your shipping company. Travel to more ports, play the ship driving minigame to get in and out of the docks for more status (and to save money and see the nice scenery), buy more ships, complete company contracts, and get rich. Or go bankrupt if you fail, but the game is overall fairly easy to play.
This is a single player game, with a sequel with multiplayer and more features coming out in May 2016,

As such, my recommendation is to get this one on sale, unless you cant wait to get your ship captain fix now. The polish of this game is a good sign for the future of its replacement, and I expect that you wont get exactly the same sort of challenges and game play features in the sequel.  This original game does, though, contain the background story and missions which set up the campaign mode of its sequel, and may be a little easier to play (in single player).

There are two basic game modes, the campaign  a mission-driven game with an investor who gives you orders and wants to be paid back, with the ultimate goal to become a tycoon and take control of the company  and the free game, where you just run the shipping company however you want. The campaign can be a challenge to win, but also provides a nice tutorial on how to play.

Much of the joy of the game is making smart choices and watching your company and bank balance grow. You will spend most of your time watching your ships sail around the world, and making decisions when they reach ports. Refuel now, or wait for a cheaper location? Select cargos for the best pay, but take into account the chances of getting new valuable jobs at each destination. Repair or upgrade your ship as needed. Some cargos require upgrades in order to legally carry them  take them without and you risk customs inspections and fines. Time spent sitting in port costs money, so that is another hard choice.

Some jobs have time deadlines. They pay better, increase your status if you are one time, but penalize you if you fail. The company contracts you can take give you a mission to deliver a specific kind of cargo from one specific port to another, with a time limit as well. They add another piece of depth, trading guaranteed work with a good payoff at the end (and more status) for a commitment which makes you miss out on valuable high-paying loads to other locations  or taking them, and risk failing the contract.

All the ships in this game are container cargo ships, and can carry multiple cargo loads as long as they fit on the ship. Sometimes you have enough to fill the ship and go to one destination, but often you must it several destinations in order to travel fully loaded. Each port docked at takes time and money.

Early in the game, you will dock manually and play a simple ship driving game to get into or out of the harbor. It isnt hard to do being slow and patient, but most of us dont want to wait too long, and so you take chances and risk damaging your ship. Succeeding boosts your status. Being Famous means youll get better deals and cargos than a small, Unknown company and captain.

Later in the game, especially once youve seen all the ports in 3D, youll just pay the tug costs and skip this part of the game, as long as you have the money in the bank.

There are dangers which can affect your ships travel  storms at sea, fires, sickness, reefs, pirates, rescue missions  plus the risk of customs delays if your ship isnt running legally. Taking the risky illegal goods (counterfeit and questionable merchandise) pays very well, but has much higher fines and delays if you are caught. Plus the illegal goods are confiscated, unlike loads where you arent compliant with regulations.

Most trips, though, are uneventful for legal, properly maintained ships. Youll spend your time making good choices each time a ship hits port, and when you cast off to send it to its next destination. The game proceeds in simulated real time (you can accelerate the clock, and will do so often in the early game). With more ships in play, you will have a lot on your mind, as you try to figure out the best way to make money and complete your missions.

The sequel adds competition -- AI and human multiplayer -- and expands a lot on this game.  But the basic elements seem similar enough, with, I hope, enough improvements to make it a really great game to enjoy with friends.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
As a big fan of transport simulator games like Transport Tycoon I jumped on this one. The game is fun, for the first 5 hours or so. Unfortunately it suffers from repetitive gameplay and the tedious management of your ships. When you start to have more than a handful of ships to control the game becomes overwhelming. On top of this, the banker and her loan will be with you for a long long time. In 10 hours of game play I was still not close to being able to pay her off due to the requirements.

It feels like there is potential here for the game to be better than it currently is. Right now it too quickly becomes a micro-management simulator. Even with the problems I'd still recommend the game as I feel like I got my money's worth out of it; just know what you're getting into before hand and only pick it up during a sale.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
A lot of people thus far keep comparing the game to ports of call, and there are a ton of similarities between TransOcean and POC, you can choose to play the game more like the old DOS game Ocean Trader. TransOcean: The Shipping Company
My review is from single player only. I work for a container shipping company, so this game caught my eye a while ago. I expected something like the classic Railroad Tycoon series, but with ships. What I got was something different, but in a bad way. The game itself isn't horrid, but more something that is vastly inefficient. The mini-game of docking the ships manually when they call ports is tedious and just isn't worth it at almost any point in the game. The whole thing is pointless.

The business element is very lacking, and I was disappointed that the one of only ways they could think to make the game challenging was to vary the same starting scenario. The only thing that changes is the insane interest rate the player is required to pay to the angel investor, along with her ability to sign annoying shipping contracts with huge penalties without your consent. Starting capital should be something the player is in conrol of, or at least given some options. I haven't beaten the game yet, but so far the only risk is getting caught without proper liscense to carry goods and varying interest rates. All of the systematic risks associated with shipping, storms, fire, whatever are all completely random and don't even affect other ships on the same rotues. There is no political risk, market risk, exchange rate risk, or purchasing power risk. The game is supposed to be global, but has nothing global about the simulated economy nor is it dynamic in supply/demand.

Last, and probably the biggest deal breaker, I don't enjoy the micro management required in this game. Having to approve every single ship when you call port is annoying, and it seems almost impossible to set up a static voyage using supply and demand or contracts. Every port you have to pick new goods based on what is available and then decide where the ship is to go next, and because goods cant be transferred at ports for a hub and spoke strategy, the only way to play is by having direct routes for every ship. In late game, you have so many shipts they are calling ports every 4 seconds so the gameplay never feels like it is going anywhere. Youre costantly being inturruped by having to agree to pay the docking fee, load more goods, and then choose the next port. The only way to keep ships in specific areas is to basically micromanage contracts, and have them sit in port waiting for a contract that keeps them from having to go from the EU to Asia, or float them completely empty to another port, which is again heavy micromanagement when you consider how many ships you have to track in late game, and not realistic at all.

These business simulators still have things to learn, and it makes you truely appreciate games which are very well done like the Railroad Tycoon seres. They are still amazing. The next installment of Transcean is out this summer, I hope it is a little better.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
Simply put its a great game, if you are interested in a game that is all about managing a network of ships, ensuring you can afford the ships, fuel, repairs and any fines you incure all the while needing to keep enough money in the bank to pay your greedy investor then this may be the game for you.

The graphics are exactly what you would expect from a game that is essentialy a map and a bunch of finance screens, simple clean and easy to understand. The docking part of the game is quite fun but when you have 10+ ships can become very tedious to dock every ship. The advantage of actually docking yourself is you save the moring fee's and when it come to the most expensive ship in the game thats a lot of money especialy if you dock the ship and leave the port. So it comes in handy throughout the game and while you dont need to use it ever it can be useful (especialy if your ships is empty and you need to move to a different port and want to save some money), its also quite fun and challenging as some of the docks are very oddly shapped and possitioned. The graphics for the docking are nice clean and I expect will stand the test of time nicely.

Every aspect of the game is fun, if a bit repetative, however with the docking mini game you can vary it up and keep the fun alive. It does become very repetative nearing the end of the game as you are simply trying to buy out your investor and the money you need is huge and can take a little too long to reach, which is the only real downside to this entire game. I wold have liked to have seen a few other elements like competiton with other companies and the such but alas not in this game. If the game starts to feel repetative try taking on a contract that is restrictive or try and get a chain of contracts, there are many ways to keep your interest, you just need to look for them.

The tutorial is very good and is perfectly integrated into the main game so no need to stop and start. You follow the instructions and you start making money. My personal recomendayion is to always but the ship with the highest top speed and bigest hold, the distance it can travel is imaterial, especialy when you reach level 3 and 4 ships.

Pro's
Graphics are simple and clean and will not feel dated in the years to come
A number of different challenges throughout the game.
Piloting the ships are fun and challenging, the latter ships with thrusters, makes piloting a dream.
Finding the best routes to make money is a lot of fun.


Con's
Can be repetative, especialy later on.
You will hate how much the investor takes from you and can be annoying when you simply want to finish the game.
Becomes a little to easy in the late game.
When you have 15 + ships it still takes forever to buy out the investor

Conclusion, this is a fun game that will keep you occupied for many hours, however its not for everyone and you need to be a tycoon fan to get the most out of this game, and even then trying to end the game will annoy you.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
There is almost no game here. Here is the game in a nut shell.

1. Select highest value cargo from list.
2. Click button to auto undock (Or spend 3-5min undocking to save a tiny amount of money)
3. Wait for boat to get to new dock.
4. Go to step 1

Later on pirates will attack at random and steal ships from you (Or you can pay more than the ship is worth as a random)

I put a few hours into the game and still have no idea how you are supposed to be able to buy larger boats, it said I could do it, but never showed any for sale. Not that I needed them, money comes in far too easy.

This game needs a lot of work to be fun IMHO.

TransOcean: The Shipping Company
Not a really difficult game, some nice logistics.

What's it about:
In the campaign you begin in Europe and from there you spread to the world, obviously ships will get bigger and you will make a lot of money in the campaign but you have to keep in mind you have to buy your company back from the investor. I have bought the company back, took me slightly over 60 hours of only campaign game-play. I have not had any game-breaking bugs so far, so no severe ones that I encountered. Theres only the loss of frames when moving the view in docks when multiple ships are in the same dock, though I almost never do that. Further more.. you can manually dock and cast off your ships (press spacebar when manually taking control it is fun) which will not cost you any money.. it will when you auto do it.

Free play?
Yes there is that option, have not reached that point yet.

Recommend it?
Yes, but I read they are making TransOcean 2. So it is up to you to buy this one or wait for the new one.

Soldier Front 2
Solider Front 2 is an absolutely awesome game.

Pros:
+ Great graphics for a F2P
+ Not pay to win at all
+ There are loads of great serious gamemodes but many humorous ones like snowball fight, party, etc.
+ Nice inventory/loadout system.
+ Not much of a learning curve, so it's fun for people of all skill to enjoy.
+ Fast-paced, quality gameplay overall

Cons:
- Not too many people play anymore
- 99% of players are 12 year old Filipino kids that don't speak English (not to be racist)
- Awful community
- Hackers... so many hackers...

Overall: 9/10
This game has its cons, as does any other game, but it's definitely a gem in the free-to-play genre.  It has great gameplay and graphics, and it's especially fun with friends.  Highly recommended.

Soldier Front 2
Soldier Front 2 is without a doubt the best F2P FPS experience i've ever come across. (And FPS is my main genre with quite a bit of experience) It in many ways manages to match and in some places exceed both its F2P brethren as well as its more costly retail alternatives. SF2 is as you can tell, is a sequel to a once very successful F2P title back in 2004/2007 in Korea & later internationally by the name of Soldier Front/Special Force. This game manages to not only outdo its (very) dated predecessor but also remain a viable option in todays overpopulated shooter scene. Everything from the animations, guns, and gameplay very closely mimics its big brother Call of Duty, and does a damn good job at delivering the same experience without paying every year for a new edition (map packs included). The game oozes quality and definitely is the best you can get when it comes to free to play currently at the moment if you're looking for COD-style shooters.

THE GOOD
+ Fantastic presentation & graphics for a F2P.
+ Weapons are affordable with ingame cash & permanent.
+ Quality COD-Style fast-paced gameplay.
+ A slew of modes to choose from including Classic Defusal to Coop.
+ Entertaining for both newbies and pros alike.
+ Tons of people playing all the time.

THE BAD
- Sometimes laggy players ruin a good match
- Hacking players can be a pain in the .
- Community is horrible and abusive to eachother. (They crossed over from the first game)
- No way to mute/report/kick undesirable players.
- Female characters run faster and are harder to hit.

THE UGLY
Raging 12 year olds from the philippines who constantly spam the chat with incoherent things like aw" "vovo" and "base"

BOTTOM LINE
I can hardly think of any free-to-play shooters that manage to compare with full retail games this well. It's very impressive if you enjoy COD-Style shooters. If they managed to fix the hacking problem

Many times you'll run around a corner and after you're completely around it, some guy shoots you from behind by hitting that one corner of the hitbox that isn't even supposed to be there.

This game is plagued with lag. SF2 consists of action-packed amazing adrenaline-rushing combat." When really it's "that guy's lagging
