Secret Of Magia
After being gifted this game, I really really want to recommend it, but I just can't. Here's why:

Pros (+) :

1. Pleasant and fitting music though it feels... Not so original.
2. Strong monsters (for those of you who like strong enemies in games) that scale with your level, including their loot.
3. Six different classes to choose from.
4. The character art is pretty, but everything else is what you would expect of a game of that genre, nothing special or unique here.
5. It's possible to upgrade your weapon as well as craft your own potions.
6. It's a fairly cheap game.


Cons (-) :

1. Classes are way too similar to each other. In fact, it doesn't matter which one you pick as they hardly differ from each other at all as there are no special abilities or talents. All of the classes can use the two OP weapons I will mention further down in this review.

2. Unfixed bugs are present in the game. Several of them. You can literally walk on the walls inside the church, an innkeeper won't allow you to enter the room you paid for and you can't walk behind a really tall building.

3. Hardly any balancing in melee fights: Enemies have more hp and hit harder as you level, while you hardly become any stronger. In fact, it wasn't unusual for enemies to be able to kill me with 2-3 hits once I leveled up just a few times. And that was indeed as a melee class with a higher defense stat than mages and archers. Also, there are two swords that can be used by ALL classes, and those swords can kill just about every monster without them ever being able to hit you as you hit them diagonally, while they can only harm you when you are in their path.

4. Spells are useless: only 2 spells and they don't really do any major damage. Also, enemies apparently have a 2 second or so invulnerability after being hit, which isn't much of an issue when using melee weapons (as a melee weapon takes about equally long to charge the attack), but it's a major issue when using spells as you have to time the spell right so you don't waste mana nor get hit while waiting for their invulnerability to wear off. Unnecesarily hard and really bothersome.

5. Very few quests for a game of that genre: I could only find 4 in the game and I literally looked everywhere and talked to every single npc in the game. Oh and they don't really give any directions so you more or less have to guess where to go for x quest.

6. Lacks content: Like I wrote above, enemies become stronger the higher level you are, and so it would be nice if you could buy or acquire better armor, but there isn't anything meant for mid-game fights and above. Also, why is there a random guy living in the middle of nowhere when he does nothing important? Why does everyone talk about the king and all when he actually proves to be completely irrelevant to the story and is, in fact, impossible to interact with?

7. Incomplete (or feels so) things: why are there guard towers with instructions on how to use smoke signals if you don't ever get to use it yourself or see it happen? Why are there so many locked doors?

8. Doesn't really have a lot of different weapons to offer: Again, no need to acquire any other weapon than one of the two swords mentioned above.

9. The crafting / upgrading system is more or less useless. Secret Of Magia
Secret of Magia is an Action RPG developed with RPG Maker.
I was given a key by the developer and I am sorry to say I do not recommend this game and here is why.

Let's start with the good things first :
The game offers not only between the choice of a female or male character, but features a class system that determines what can you equip. The HUD is nicely done and the quest system is rather original for a game like this.
The combat system is pretty good and the enemies are implemented in a smart way, the skeletons in the mines were one of them, as they genuinely surprised me and made me paranoid.
Another nice thing is that you can gather flowers and butterflies for the crafting system, sadly after an hour and a half I have not tried this system yet, but I gathered quite a lot of stuff.

Now for the bad parts :
I'm not sure if the developer has tested this game, but it's full of bugs, you can go inside walls, letters become plants when you read them, some blocks that should be solid are not, some that shouldn't be are, glitches here and there, couches have teleport blocks inside them, I was joking with a friend that in the first chuch you come across you can ascend to godhood by straight walking on the wall, most of the walls there are passable, even npcs climb them.
The combat while original for the first half hour, is kind of unbalanced, at least as a melee class, I was getting oneshotted the first levels which was pretty frustrating (slimes), I had to align myself diagonally so the monsters wouldn't have a chance to attack me but I could. I farmed a little, when I leveled up though, the monsters leveled with me and became a lot more tanky, giving more gold too. Now, the first real boss was not a big problem because by the time I had so many money I invested in health potions, he could never kill me, doesn't matter how much damage he did to me. After that you drop a legendary weapon which is a bow, a weapon my assassin shouldn't be using but he was using anyway (not sure if legendary weapons do not have class requirements). Some of the resources are inherent to RPG Maker and not original by the developer, you can judge if that affects quality or not.
I do not feel compelled to complete or continue the game as I did not have much fun with it, but thank you anyway for this chance (since I received the key by a developer or someone in contact with him).
All in all it's a low quality rpg maker title with some smart ideas here and there, but with a weak story, characters and quite full of bugs at the moment of writing, so personally I would not recommend you this game.

Secret Of Magia
Secret Of Magia is an action RPG that was made using RPG Maker.
It is inspired by games like The Legend of Zelda: A Link To The Past, Arc The Lad and Secret of Mana and takes you back to the NES/SNES days.

The game starts by selecting between a male/female character that you can later specialize in one out of 6 classes.
There is no tutorial in the game that shows you how to do certain things.
There is also no main quest or other information regarding the storyline, you have to find that out by yourself which is a good thing in my opinion.

While I really like the combat system and the sounds/music this game has a few main issues that need to be addressed like:

- Low texture quality
Because of low quality assets things get pixelated quickly and sometimes it is really hard to read certain things (in the UI for example).

- Missing widescreen support
Widescreen resolution should be supported in every modern game.
It would be great to have an options menu to select the desired screen resolution / aspect ratio.

- Missing key binding customization
Want to move your character by using WASD instead of the arrow keys? Not possible to change this anywhere unfortunately.

Other than these issues the game has a couple of minor bugs and design flaws, but nothing really game breaking.

All in all I can say that this is a solid game for a cheap price.
If you are into these type of retro action/adventure RPG's you should definitely consider buying this game.

Secret Of Magia
Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Secret of Magia with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

I had braced myself for yet another piece of RPG Maker garbage when I first loaded this game up. It took me joyfully by surprise when it turned out to actually be a real time adventure game similar to that of the old top-down Zelda titles. Hookshot included!

Sadly, the magic didnt last as I quickly found that nothing felt quite responsive or snappy enough. The sword swung in a pitifully small arc, the character feels very locked down to a square grid of movement, and actually trying to naturally navigate with a controller or D-pad is very uncomfortable. Even the hookshot moseys across the screen like a tranquilized snail. The story wasnt dreadful from the little bit I saw of it. The creatures, while rather disjointed and inconsistent in theme, were decently drawn and animated. However, when it comes down to it, playing Secret of Magia makes you reminisce of Zelda and sulk over how inferior this game feels in comparison.

Secret Of Magia
A technically flawed but mostly charming and low priced action adventure/RPG title, Secret Of Magia harkens back to older action adventure RPG titles and the inspirations and love for the Zelda titles is clear, and things like the friendly dialogue, brief random encounters, art style and music all fit nicely. There's also a fair amount of content, areas and enemies for the cost, and overall, while it has problems and does nothing special, it's good value for money and a competent aaRPG.

Full disclosure: I recieved a Steam key prior to this review.

Highlights
The variety of environments and pretty good intro level were enough to get me engaged, and the casual and unlimited nature of exploration from an early stage are worth mentioning. It's easy to skip ahead if you're impatient, but equally easy to spend an extra hour or two just exploring and grinding. There's also a variety of competent and occasionally funny dialogue from many different denizens in many different towns.
The music is also very pleasant to listen to, and sets the tone really well without getting annoying at all.

Overall, if the developer releases a patch or two and clears up some issues, this title will be worth picking up for what is essentially the price of a coffee.

Mistakes and Annoyances
I feel like a patch or two would fix up most of my complaints, but for the sake of completion and honesty here they are.

There are tons of small technical bugs. I routinely found myself clipping through walls and into inaccessible areas, I was unable to equip or de-equip items after certain encounters, and had no way to continue but to slowly suicide, menu systems sometimes became disabled for unidentifiable reasons and plenty more small annoying technical mistakes that should've been play-tested and fixed.
The support for using a mouse is great, and makes playing a lot faster and smoother, but the out of the box key bindings are frankly awful, and the in-game configuration panel isn't listed in the controls, nor accessible by anything other than messing around (it's F1 in all RPG Maker titles), and even that isn't properly labelled or actionable, and F12 causes crashes due to a bugged RPG Maker script. Again, these are little things that can be fixed fairly simply, but that's all the more reason to highlight them.

There are design mistakes too, namely the save system relying on positional altar markers. This means that, like some of the older Zelda systems, you can only save before entering an area or after travelling to a specific place. For a game that encourages player grinding and a slow death screen, this makes little sense. An auto-save or simply just a save button would've been a far better choice.
The main issue for me, however, was the combat. There is arguably a small level of skill required in coordinating where to position the player in regards to each enemy and the environment but, at least as the soldier class, it's mostly just about finding the next diagonal tile and slashing ad infinitum and became repetitive and bland after a short time and even boss fights are mostly about predicting the next move and getting in position.

Recommendations
Priced at just 1.99/2.99/$2.99 at the time of review, this is actually priced fairly, and will probably be worth picking up on sale for someone looking for a casual aaRPG with a nod towards older Nintendo titles, just not until some of the technical problems are corrected.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/396160

Secret Of Magia
It's rare that I will post a review for a game that I haven't completed in full, but I just can't bring myself to do much more than finish out the achievements and then give up Secret of Magia.

From the store page, the game looks like it will be a fun and fast paced RPG with dark, gothic graphics. However, when you play the game, you realize that it's the opposite of all those things. The color scheme and tones of the graphics are nothing as they are presented on the store page, which is very misleading. You can easily go around and avoid all of the monster fights; the monsters will not follow you or go out of their way to hit you. The only real fast-paced action here is how fast the main character moves.

The BIGGEST downfall of this game are the controls, whether you're playing with KB or a controller. It's just horrendous either way. I'm not sure how the developer even thought that the control scheme was a good idea in the first place. It's barely feasible on a controller, but downright hand breaking on a KB.

I should also mention here that any time you quit the game, the game crashes instead of closing properly. There is also no way to adjust your resolution or if you'd rather have full screen or windowed mode. Steam overlay also does not work in the game, but toast windows pop up and leave an annoying white rectangle on the corner of the screen.

At the paid price of a whopping $0.32 CAD, I can't say I'm upset. I got it at this price for the achievements, honestly. But anyone who is seriously considering this title for pleasure play should think twice. Don't support misleading store pages and broken games.

fyi ALT+ENTER toggles fullscreen

This is my thoughts thus far:

Pros
mouse support ingame and menus
controller support (may require configuring via F1)
great graphics (for RPG maker)
comical text
smoothly playable (did not encounter glitches or bugs)
decent music
Cons
occasional violations of grammer
movement keys are arrow keys and NOT WASD
this is a genre I don't usually play
Tips
Use the up and down arrow keys when entering a number to gamble. The reason the three numbers look like a dial that spins is because it is like a dial you spin with arrow keys.
Learn to use the mouse as well as the keyboard. It can make your play experience more fluid by using the middle scroll wheel as a the harpoon thingie instead of SHIFT. Your experience may vary.
There is an options menu ingame where you can change a few things but there is also another one specific to all games made using RPG Maker which is F1. If you are having any problems with the game you can likely fix it there.
ALT+ENTER as always will toggle fullscreen for nearly all games.

Football Manager 2016
This review is intended for the experienced FM player. If you are new to the series, or indeed the genre, you should buy this game. It is by far the best available in the genre. Highly recommended.

However, if you have owned virtually every CM/FM game that has ever been released, then perhaps the following comments will constitute a review which is closer to your heart?

Somewhere along the line, these games lost their soul. The most identifiable yardstick along this path was the moment the developers introduced overall star ratings for players. There was a time, in early CM games, when signing a player was a risk. You would look at their form, stats and overall value and make a decision. Sometimes, you would buy a flop and othertimes you would make a great signing. Now all you need to do is have a good scout and you can go on the star rating they provide. That might be good for your average ADHD fifa manager type players, but people buying these games, for the most part, WANT to spend time trying to make these decisions and don't want to have their hands held through the process. In a real-world scenario, a player who has scored 20+ goals in a season immediately attracts interest from bigger clubs. In this game however, you will simply overlook such a player if their star rating is poor. In these games form has absolutely no relevance when making signings. This is NOT an accurate simulation of how decisions are made in real life.

If you are a long-standing player of these games, ask yourself this question - when was the last time you bought a player who ended up not being good enough to make it at your club? This is something real-world managers live and die by, but is an element of football management which has been woefully overlooked by the developers. Somewhere along the way the developers have made the hardest decision in football management the easiest one. Signing new players should always be a risk. Think of the countless examples in real life of signings which on paper should have been stars. If there is one thing which is clearly evident, it is that even the most experienced and talented of managers occasionally buy players who flop. This should be the most important aspect of any football management simulation. Instead, this game provides you with god-like ability to predict just how good a player will be in the future through an overall star rating. In real-life, managers would make such predictions through a combination of the player's professionalism, age, determination, injury history and availabilility of experienced players for the youngster to learn from. These factors would also fluctuate over time and be subject to change. Hence, a player like Michael Johnson at Man City comes an goes.  By forcing players to consider these things the developers could make this game SO much more rewarding and return the franchise partway to its former roots.

As for the matchday engine, it is simply a non-event. The quality is just not there to warrant ever using this view. The ardent FM fan will not even care about the 3D view as it is not the aspect of the game which they find rewarding. Rather, it is taking the plunge and signing players and working them into a functional tactical system. Incidentally, tactics is the one area of the game which the developers have virtually got spot on. You cannot sail through a season just repeat using the same system like in the good old days.

My suggestion, stop trying make a stats-driven simulation and try to return some atmosphere to the game. You can make a start by providing authentic match day sounds. I could go for hours explaining how this game could be improved, but ultimately this is intended as a review and not a 'blue-sky' suggestion session for the developers.

I will obviously keep buying these games, if only for the reason that there is no other franchise which comes close in this genre. But everytime I buy the latest version a little piece of me (and the genre) dies. It is for this reason that I have to send a message to the world that as long as this game is not fulfilling its enormous potential, I cannot in good conscience recommend it.

Football Manager 2016 Beta First Impressions
Hey guys, I'm about to write my first impressions about the game, but keep in mind that this is beta / pre-order version. Also, this review is intended for Football Manager players that already know how to play this game.

Pros:


Most advanced animations yet in any Football Manager edition. What I mean by that is the fact that FINALLY you can see the difference in Flair / Quality between 2 players. New dribblings, crosses, decisions and finishing in front of goal. It was FM13 since I've been asking for more realistic dribblings / decisions / crosses in the final third but the game never got quite there, until now. Let me give you a short example: I am playing as AC Milan and Jeremy Menez was attacking the right flank as a Winger-Attack. In any of the previous versions, he would have done 3 possible things: attack the byline and cross, cutting into the penalty area or pass the ball back to the overlappting full back. Now, I noticed something absolutly beautiful: He did neither of those. His decision was to dribble 2 players like they were nothing by cutting inside the penalty area and then he launched a lobbed-cross to Luiz Adriano who was rushing forward from a deeper position. Now, besides his way of dribbling (which i've never seen before in FM), we can easily notice another MAGNIFICENT improvement: lobbed crosses. This kind of crosses are a must in a game like FM and I am finally happy it was introduced. So yes, new animations / decisions / dribblings / crossings. You can finally see the difference between 15 Flair and 18 Flair so to speak.
Game is in a much better state beta wise than it was last year (loading times, match engine and leagues)
Fast loading / saving times. Last year's beta was awful regarding saving times. It was something that eventually got fixed, but FM16 doesn't have this problem at all. In fact, to me it seems than the game loads/saves faster than FM15.
3D Match Engine is another thing that pleasantly surprised me (played 3 games). By this I mean it feels smoother, no visible glitches and artefacts. Last year we had all sorts of problems with 3d engine performance until it got fixed (the game ran choppy and stuttering a lot on anything above medium" quality no matter how powerful your machine was). And it doesn't matter whether you play as Bayern or Gateshead, because you will concede more than a fair share of goals from crosses at the far post, due the defender(s) inability/will to follow the run made by the attacking player.

- You will never/rarely actually get a goal, when you need one. Whether it's drawing level or winning a close encounter. And to pile on the misery, the opposition will also more than often score in the dying minutes, snatching either a draw or win.

- The aforementioned point makes the matches feel extremely predictable as you either absolutely smash opposition, go ninety minutes without a single chance or get the dreaded late conceded goal and all is visible/predictable due to the way your/opposing players move about on the pitch during the whole match/last minutes.

- Different tactical approach isn't as visible on-screen as one might imagine, which gives little incentive to create/tweak own tactics.

- Corner instructions are ignored (short corner instruction results in floating crosses being hit).

- Generally lack of new features with the exception of the terrible manager creator screen.

Football Manager 2016
Ah. Football Manager 2016. From the superb to the shocking.

Firstly, I must say if you're looking for a game with superb aesthetics, then Football Manager 2016 is the game for you. The menus, tactics, training, transfers, fixtures etc. screens look superb, as they always have and probably always will. Aesthetically it's a 10/10 game.

However, once you press that play button to start the match, it all turns truly dire. Never mind your coaching badges, your club's level or your standard of players/staff, you'll suffer (and receive - it can go both ways) some of the most shocking, and in some cases bizarre, pieces of gameplay you'll ever likely to see. Goalkeepers diving away from the ball, sometimes not diving at all, players not tracking the most blatant of runs, your star attacker continuously missing sitters while the computer's youth debutant with a finishing attribute of two bangs in a brace from outside the box. Those are just some of the things you can expect to see in Football Manager 2016 (though, that's been the case for years in FM to be honest.)

Admittedly, I'm definitely not the most skilled player, no question, but even so it's clear to see the game needs a lot of work to firstly get to the standard the developers give it and secondly to merit its price tag. I'd honestly say don't buy this game, I regret doing so especially given it's the same stuff (gameplay-wise) as in FM2015. I've been underwhelmed with FM for years now, they've seem to have slipped since the superb days of FM2009, FM2010 and FM2011.

But hey, this is just my opinion. Make a decision for yourself. It's OK to play, but it's definitely not enjoyable in my opinion. Thanks for reading.

Football Manager 2016
Wow, what a difference!  FM16 is much better than the poor shadow of a game that FM15 was.

Just some quick comments:

1.  The goalie AI is miles better.  The reactions are more realistic, and diving saves are made when they are meant to.  A lot less opposition goals scored with keeper just standing there.  I feel like my team has a locked door again!!

2.  The defence AI is also much improved.  Where last year they would let players through easily, there is a real feeling that the defenders respond to tactics you set and that makes such a positive difference.

3.  I love the new animations for scoring, celebrating, remonstrating, falling and tackling.  I really like the little flicks of the ball that have been introduced as well.  Also some nice improvements in the build of players' faces on the pitch.  My computer was rated 3* for graphics, but there has been no problem with the best quality setting being used.

4.  The new tactics screen is super.  It makes it a lot more clear to use the 'pie' graphic to show whether the players are suited to a position and now a role.  Much much better.

5.  The new manager builder is a great idea.  I kind of managed to match my face but I have heavy stubble and glasses - any chance that SI could introduce facial hair and glasses settings for this?  Wouldn't mind so much if it was just for the match engine, but my attempt at my face comes up whenever I am quoted on screen and whatever.  However, that is the only thing I don't like about the manager builder.

6.  Injury frequency is much fairer than in FM15.  I no longer have an injury list the size of Glasgow.  I've gone from a consistent injury list of 8 first team players out to just 1 or 2 - much more realistic.  This makes such a difference SI - please don't change it when you release the final version.

7.  Injury type and associated time out of the team is much better balanced than in FM15.  The option to play through injury is good too.  SI have listened to us here, which is excellent.  I was kind of dreading playing this game after forking out for the beta, simply because the injury system crippled FM15 in my eyes, and I was afraid that this would be more of the same.  I am very happy that I have been proved wrong.

8.  The prozone tactical system is great.  Now we can access substitutions in a much slicker fashion, and it doesn't take an age to go through.  This helps the game continue quickly.

9.  There is a definite distinction between match fitness and match sharpness, and both affect the performance of the players in their own way.  A lot of thought has gone into this, and it works extremely well, even in beta.

Can you tell I'm a little impressed??

10.  I haven't tried the team builder yet but looking it over, it seems a great option.  I'll comment more fully when I have the chance.

SI, thank you for giving us a much better offering (so far) this season.  I will be playing this version of FM a lot more than I played the last one.

Football Manager 2016
This review is based on being a FM/CM player for over 20 years and someone who only ever plays the full mode, not classic or touch.

If you have never played FM before then it is the best game you can play, it is the latest, most up to date FM and (excluding presentation) the best because while it doesnt add much, it is a subtle improvement on 15, just as 15 was on 14. Although if you can buy FM14 for under 5, then buy that, get an updated database and in terms of value to what you play there wont be to much difference.

The thumbs down is purely for players who play FM year in year out. This is just not worth the 35. I wouldnt have bought FM2016 but it was bought for me as a present that I didnt ask for.

If you are in any doubt then have a look at the new features on the store page, 3rd down is manager on the touchline. 3rd down, it must be pretty important, it must be a huge new feature! now scroll through the screenshots until you get to the picture of the manager. That is what you get. Basically a huge slap in the face to every long-term FM user.

On the Sports Interactive FM forums there is a huge wishlist thread with over 6000 replies. Pick any random page and there are countless wishes for in-depth training, media pressure, player interaction, ME improvments, Board improvements. With the exception of the ME there has been no noticeable improvement in any of these over the last two years. This year we are treated to new features such as create a club, fantasy draft and manager on the touchline. Fine new features in themselves, widely asked for? no.

The game is all to easy to create all conquering teams that win trophies year after year. In real life how many managers stay at the same club and keep constantly winning trophies? Obviously Sir Alex Ferguson and a few others, but it should be hard, really hard to do. Its just to easy in FM. How many young players who are deemed wonderkids in real life go on to actually become superstars? Not that many, a handful from each generation. Not so in FM, buy a wonderkid, play wonderkid, watch wonderkid fulfill potential. On the other hand, want to pluck a kid from the french second division who no one really rates and watch him suprise everyone (ala Marhez of Leicester), no chance. The constrictive CA/PA system wont allow that until a FM researcher updates it for you. Its a system that is showing its age. They may have served the series well, but many of the systems FM16 incorporates are basic and easy to control because they havent moved forward in the last few years.

Football Manager really hasnt moved forward with the times. 15 to 20 years ago a lot of managers did run the club from top to bottom but these days top, top clubs arent run like that. FM does a really poor job of reflecting this, sure there is the token Director of football, the token head of development, but again very simplistic, basic systems that just doesnt reflect top level football in 2016. Managing a top club in FM16 feels more like a quaint throwback to the 90s than an actual reflection of what fooball has become in the last 15 years.

3 years ago I thought FM was about where it should be. Now its coming across stale and out of ideas. Going by the wishlist thread in their own forums theres 100s of great ideas, but for whatever reason SI has entered the change UI, tag on some light weight features and sell for full price approach. Its sad to see. I will still play it, but every year its getting harder to justify paying 35 for a game that isnt moving forward and is no longer reflecting the sport I watch and read about. I will still rack up the hours, but more because there is no other game to buy than what SI have developed.

The FM series needs a huge shake up. Every year real life football grows, the juggernaught keeps getting bigger and expanding. Every year that goes by where we have new features like create a club and fantasy draft is another year where FM loses ground on the sport its trying to represent. Its sad that the people in control of the games direction have completely lost sight of what gave the game its cult following. It got the basics of the football world right and let the players imagination fill in the gaps and build from there. The basics of the FM world dont feel right anymore. Without that basic foundation the imagination has no support, FM needs imagination to work or it is just a game and FM was never just a game.

Football Manager 2016
Alright, in hope that I can beat the unfunny reviews of this game, lets crack this one out!

Football Manager 2016 is part of the continual football (or soccer depending on where you hail from) series. This is the eleventh game in the series and will release officially in November 2015. The game was made available early for people who pre-purchased the game to take part in the beta testing phase. This review is based off my time in the beta thus far.

The game play of FM16 is exactly the same as all of the others; you take management over a football team and run everything to do with the sporting side of it. This includes picking your teams tactics, choosing which players to take part in matches, setting training regimes for your players, buying and selling players, agreeing contracts of your back room staff and players. Pretty much anything which a manager of a football team has to do, you also do in this game.  Each yearly release of FM comes with over 200+ changes compared to the last years. Some of this years biggest changes are as follows:

Players can now customize their players appearance. I have to admit, I wasn't a huge fan of this; mainly because I have no real interest in what my manager looks like in game, you hardly see the character at all. When creating my manager, it seems as if the actual appearance of your character doesn't change all that much when editing the face, you just get a strange looking mess of a face. For me, I hated this feature as it adds nothing real to the game.

The feature I am most excited about is the addition of a Fantasy draft - we see all sorts of drafts in American football, but not so in soccer. This feature will allow you to play with friends, set a budget, and draft your own team to go head to head with people online. I have played a bit of it so far, and it is awesome. It has a sort of pick up and play feel to it; if you have maybe just an hour to spare, rather than getting engrossed in the full game, load up a draft and play a couple of games. This is a welcome addition to the game if you ask me.

A create your own club feature has been added; this feature was already kind of included in previous generations of the game via the game's editor tool, but now it has been encorporated into the main game. Personally I have never used the old create a club feature, and probably won't even in this release. But what this does do is allow you to create a club from scratch and build it from the very bottom of the league structure and turn it into one of the best teams in the world. This is what I would call a hard mode difficulty setting and is a project which you need to set probably hundreds of hours to if you wants to succeed.

The main screen display you'll be seeing the majority of the time, looks just like an email inbox, you'll be sent items of news regarding your team, the league you are in, potential players you'd be interested in, injuries etc. You can choose whether to show more items, or fewer items depending on how in depth you want to go. When playing the matches, you'll be shown a 3D match engine. This has gotten a pretty heft face lift compared to previous titles, and it now looks even better than before. The players have a much smoother animation cycle, the stadiums look better; weather effects look more prominent too.  The game has various options for how you can view the match; such as birds eye view, or touchline settings, personally I went with the directors view most of the time because it adjusts to the best angel depending on where the ball is.

FM2016, has the new game modes as mentioned above, the regular full FM experience,  and a sort of watered down version, aimed at an audience who don't want to spend hours looking over numbers and statistics, this mode allows people to play matches in a couple of minutes and maybe complete a season in a few hours. If you want to get the full experience out of this game, the Full Game mode is the way to go, if you want a casual experience, maybe try with the classic mode.

As with all other FM games in the series, this game has ample replay ability, and I will easily see myself racking up hundreds of hours in this game. It will suck every second of your spare time and more if you let it. You can finish a season in the regular mode in maybe fifteen hours, that's just one season. You can effectively play this game forever, the game will just keep going and you'll eventually have yourself your own footballing universe which you'll probably find more interesting than the real world.

Even though this game is still in beta, I have had no technical issues with this release thus far. I will keep this review updated in case I do run into any, but as of now, this is a technically sound game and runs like a dream.

To sum up, if you are a fan of Football, and want to learn about the management side of things, or want to drop the FIFA franchise and try something different, you will find no other game out there that does it as well as Football Manager. It is a no brainer for me to recommend this game for any football fan. If you aren't so much of a football supporter, you'll probably want to skip this over, as you may not fully appreciate the content on show, but for me, this is a must play.

This hasn't just happened a few times, it's continuous, one game ended 4-4, i scored 17, they scored 18th, i scored 23rd they scored 25th, i scored 53rd they also somehow scored 53rd minute, and the last goal was 4 minutes into injury time after i scored on the 89th. I nearly threw my PC out the window.

There are other bugs and parts of the game which aren't up to scratch, so overall dissappointed.

Try the beta first if you an, make your own mind up, this could well be my last year playing FM.

Football Manager 2016
The match engine must have been designed by Moynes. Every cross is an auto goal. 4 Defenders between the goal and the forward receive a cross or 0, a goalk keeper that 'Rushes out' and one that prefers to say in. A deep sitting team or one pushing forward. A cross will find the forward like a magnet. Whether the winger is crossing it from the middle of the field or by the corner flag. You can watch 5 defenders and a goalie all stupidly stare at a cross while a mediocre forward from a lower league connects with the perfect fit.

But maybe you say I am just a bad FM. And that is possible -- except you can look at the statistics of every other team. 80% of goals are crosses. In fact thats what most matches are between two evenly matched teams, its cross and counter cross.

The other banalities of the game are just quirks of FM -- a sliding tackle strips your player but the ball falls to another one of your player who gives it back to the sliding player -- but the crosses simply take you out of the game. Presumably some programmer watched a game once and saw a cool cross from the deep land perfectly on the tip of a strikers foot and decided that this is the only way goals can be scored.

Oh and also there is a pretty nasty memory leak. But thats usual for FM engines so if you soldiered on through to 2016 its no surprise.

Football Manager 2016
I think this is the first Football Manager in a few years to offer some actual innovations rather than just 'tinkering' with the system and interface.  It's about time that happened as well as some aspects in the game were getting really quite dated, especially the match engine.

On the subject of the match engine: It really looks like they have tackled this in 2016, especially regarding the goalkeeper and defence, who now actually interact as players on the pitch instead of just going through the motions for the engine.

Tactics ACTUALLY seem to work for once, so asking for direct football will actually get you direct football with forceful wingers and killer balls attempted.  They had started to try and fix this in 2015, but still seemed like they were going through the motions to mask a pretty average match engine.

I am really enjoying the new detailed staff page as well, you can now see exactly who is doing what at the club, and where your club ranks in the league at staff skills.  This was always an underdeveloped part of the game for me, as a club's backroom staff is just as important as the players on the pitch.

I hear the prozone is good as well, but not something I have looked at in detail as of yet.

There are, however, still some issues:

The blighted over developed press conferences are still in the game.  MY GOD these are boring, and I don't think SI actually realise how dull they have made this, which is ironic as a lot of development time seem to have gone into making it 'intuitive'.  Let's make this clear though - intuitive means nothing if it isn't entertaining.  My solution is simple...drop all the press nonsense, that just kills playing time, and allow people to have a preset button which gives you avatar a way of dealing with the press - range it from 'conspiracy theorist' right through to 'upbeat and passive'.  You can then change you demeanor as and when you see fit - so if you are in a slump you can do the 'world is against us' mentality if you wish to, without having to spend 5 mins reading through very dull rhetorical journo questions! The whole 'get your assistant manager to do it' just doesn't wash for me either, as press management is an important part of creating a team mentality.

The interface still looks like it was developed by a sociopath, however I get SI not caring too much as Steklo will no doubt just create a great new indie Skin over the next couple of months anyway.


Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

Let me qualify here, I like this game quite a bit and I think it does deserve all the praise it recieved. So why the negative review? Well for one, Steam doesn't give me the option to have a neutral review, and two I want to give potential buyers some reasons as to why they wouldn't want to buy in. Most of the negative reviews don't really do that, at least not in detail.

I've been following this game for a long time, a lot of love has gone in to its development, and it really shows through the quirky spritework. The problem with the development is that it's just been so painfully slow that I can't recommend spending $15 on it at this point, because the desire to check back in after a few months when nearly nothing new has been added fades away after over two years; and that's how long I've had this game. It was first released for beta purchase around April 1, 2014.

Over the course of two years, the story has essentially gained one new dungeon (of which there was only one before) along with a marginal amount of content that shows this game is going to be in development for many more years. The content that's there is good, sure, but it's not so stellar as to justify playing through the story more than once or twice.

The real mode that seems to add playtime to this game is its arcade mode, which is roguelike in nature, and requires a good understanding of enemy/boss patterns to do well in. Players play through two floors representing each area in the story mode, complete with enemies from said area, and have no chances to heal except at the end of each floor. Despite having numerous floors and all of the enemies from the story mode, it's pretty light on content in terms of roguelikes. There are unlockables and such, but they only give minor advantages, and as a result adding more floors to the mode seems kind of pointless in its current state. Even after over two years of going back to this game I struggle to reach the 7th floor of what must be over 14 at this point. There isn't much incentive to bother trying to reach those floors either.

So should you buy this game? Well that depends on how patient you are. After two years I'm pretty burned out and don't see myself playing this game for a long, long time. If you think you can wait for what could be 5 years to play a finished product and want to support the developers, then by all means get this game. If not, keep an eye on it and pick it up a few years down the road when it has a more justifiable amount of content to offer.

Edit: Thanks for all the support guys, since this review got so much attention I want to add a little more.

If you're worried about spending $15 on a game that won't be finished, don't be. This game is a safe buy in my opinion. Even though the development has been very slow, it has been extremely consistent and the team behind this game definitely has what it takes to finish the job. Secrets of Grindea has been in the works since 2011, and the quality of the content in it has only improved since. Their dev blog[www.secretsofgrindea.com] has a weekly recap that is posted nearly every week without missing a beat. So if you're interested, definitely keep an eye on this game, because it is one of the better early access titles out there, despite the slow development speed.

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying if you think this game doesn't have grinding in it...then seek help. There are people who care about you and don't wish to see you go down this path (not me per se, we've only just met. But I'm sure there are people who love you very much. Like your grandmother or that neighbor with the nice rack. Anyway, I'm going off topic here).

Secrets of Grindea is a tongue-in-cheek RPG that draws heavily on the nostalgia of games like Secrets of Mana, Zelda: Link to the Past, and Illusion of Gaia. The sprite animations and colorful backgrounds mimic classic 16-bit games and go well with the fluidity of combat. NPCs are prevalent in towns and in the overworld to the point where the world does not feel empty and that their character is not some lone warrior living on a planet full of monsters (though that sounds like an awesome game idea. Dibs). Each area has its own unique feel that you will hopefully enjoy because the aforementioned grinding will have you staying in one area killing the same enemies for drops.

The combat is extremely straight forward where your basic attack is spamming one button or having a charged skill where you hold and release one button. Let me go on record to say that I do not think this is a bad thing. Sure, you won't be chaining attacks that culminate in your wooden sword hitting with the power of a tactical nuclear device, but you will be unlocking and upgrading skills that define the way you, the player, wish to play. The skills are limited (for now I hope) to a 1 handed skill set, 2 handed skill set, and a magic skill set. The player is able to mix and match these skills however he or she wants and has the option to refund some or all of the skill points that were spent by spending gold (this is done in the menu rather than with an NPC). There is a bow the player can get from a sidequest but so far doesn't have a dedicated set of skills to leveling up the damage.

The story is pretty straightforward for an RPG of the era it emulates: You are a guy or gal that wakes up, is handing a magical bag that can hold anything without weight restrictions and are sent out to become a renowned member of the Collectors". It seems

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

Where to begin.  This game is as advertised.  It's a game similar to Secret of Mana (SNES), Crystalis (NES), Zelda-esque, Final Fantasy Adventure (Original GB)  and many other old RP games.

You can customize your character physically by gender, colour of your clothes, hair style and colour, and name.  Additonally, you get a vanity part for your hat, face, weapon, and shield.

The gameplay is very nice, you can be a full warrior, full mage, whatever you want to be; a combination if you want.  Although, being a healer is not an option.

This is a beta game, it's not complete, from my estimation it's a little near half done, if that.

You can play cooperatively, over the internet, using your steam friends list or direct IP!  This is awesome!

You grind in the game, if that wasn't obvious.  (What old school console RPG didn't have you grind?  It's part of the fun!)

The transition between keyboard and controller playing is seamless, you just start using your keyboard and it swaps to keyboard mode, you use your controller, it swaps to controller mode.  I found this particularly great!

The host of the game's save file is progressed in the story, however - if you're not the host - you keep everything you gained.  You simply have to play through the story (by hosting or single player) to go through it.  The rewards though, you do not acquire again, you already have them!  :D

This is an awesome game!  As far as I'm aware only three people are working on it and they're from Sweden.  They have me as a fan.  The sprite animation is awesome, the artwork for the avatars is great and expresses much emotion, and the game looks very polished for a beta that is not even half done!

I used to pay $50+ US dollars for games like these, and wait years for the next to come out.  I love the game very much, and I haven't even started exploring the Arcade Mode.

tl;dr - Buy this game if you loved Secret of Mana or any similar games on the console or PC.  Especially if you want to play it co-op with friends over the internet!

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

To review this game is to review it in two parts.

Story Mode: An amazing adventure akin to the days of Secret of Mana, Sword of Mana and Seiken Densetsu 3. Quick swordplay with an oldschool-meets-polish aesthetic that's filled with charm. Combat is quick paced and - with over 20 skills and spells with multiple charge levels, along with 30 talents - more or less unique for every character made. Every attack, skill and spell feels as if it has weight behind it for a thoroughly satisfying brawl through hordes of monsters and challenging bosses.

The story is serious at times, tongue in cheek in others without outright resorting to cheese. There's plenty of side-quests, mini-games and collectables, but contrary to the name no grinding appears to be necessary. The shield is as relevant to the gameplay as the sword is, every attack can be blocked if you know the exact timing, reminding me of the days of 'Timed Hits' from Super Mario RPG and Final Fantasy 8.

The music is beautiful, the characters well written to make you love or hate them, I can't say enough good things about Story Mode. The only shame is it's incomplete, but between pet taming, treasure hunting, fishing, card collecting, playing with 4 player online co-op and duking it out in the arena, there's more than enough content to keep me busy between updates.

Arcade Mode: All the rules from Story Mode no longer apply, Arcade Mode feels like an entirely different game. Less Secret of Mana, more Binding of Isaac. You start in an empty plain and delve within a randomized roguelike-esque labyrinth. Each room is different every time, filled with traps and all manners of enemies or bosses not present in Story Mode. HP is precious, mastery of skills, spells and shielding is required.

Arcade Mode is perfect for sinking endless hours into as you try to go deeper and deeper into the labyrinth, gaining points and essence to level up and expand your town, unlock new NPCs to aid you, take on quests for rare and unique loot not found anywhere else. Skills and spells are best experimented with in here to see which build suits you best. With friends it's harder, but with 4 people on screen the monsters barely stand a chance once you hit your groove. The online leaderboards for Arcade Mode help to give it even more replay value by trying to do better than your friends or complete strangers to try and hit #1.

If you have any doubts whatsoever, try the demo. With an hour of Story Mode gameplay, several hours of Arcade Mode and co-op bundled into the demo, it's a great teaser for what to expect moving forward.

Tip: Opt into 'Frontline' by selecting SoG in your library if you want quicker updates. The normal version receives slower updates, but your experience in the game will be much smoother.

Combat

-Main quests take you to several areas that are have their own unique themes and enemies

-The everpresent chance of obtaining cards" is one that creates the urge to grind each area's different enemies
-Not only do enemies drop cards they drop crafting materials as well as rare and unique equipable gear to further create incentive to grind

THE DEVS!
-The trio over at Pixel Ferrets are incredibly talented and hard working
-Weekly dev blog updates along with frequent patches add tons of content at a high rate
-Buy them coffee to add hyperspeed perk to your favorite dev team

Other Pros:
-Easy to connect multiplayer supporting up to 4 people
-Well done controller support
-A talking bag that roasts people

Cons:
-Smallish amount of craftable material (But of course more will be added over time)
-Some bosses are way harder than others on the hard difficulty (perhaps need more difficulty settings?)

As an early access review the full potential of this game has yet to be realized however; this game has so much personality

Early Access Review

Story-wise, it's nothing special. The story is well-written, funny at times, but ultimately nothing that will win any prizes.
Action-wise, it's nothing special. Combat systems and skill trees reminiscient of soo many other games of the same kind.
Visuals are not really anything special either. Everything is cute and well-made, like in so many other games of the same kind.

But you know what? It's engaging, it's fast-paced, it's completely glitch-free and smooth, and most importantly it supports multiplayer through Steam. It's both a relaxing and fast-paced Action RPG that I can definitely recommend that you enjoy with a friend or two. Not to mention it is still in Early Access, which means there's lots of content to still come.

So far, this game is extremely well-made and polished, and definitely something you can sink some time into, alone or not; though the multiplayer aspect was ultimately what made me buy it. I haven't tried the arcade mode yet, but I already feel I've seen enough of this game to recommend it dearly.

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

I hate grinding. I really do. But not in this game as the grinding is rewarding and the battle system is a lot of fun.

YOU DON'T HAVE TO GRIND - BUT YOU'LL WANT TOSecrets of Grindea is a 2D Action-RPG with roots in the SNES-era ARPG games such as the Mana-series and Legend of Zelda. The battles are fast and the basics are quite easy to learn. You can't just button smash your way through though. The system is very much reliant on your skills and strategies, despite the fact that you can grind for levels to overpower yourself.

The beauty of the game is that you don't have to grind an excessive amount of time, but often you'll want to. If you just want to enjoy the story and explore the world, you can advance fairly quickly through the story. Boss battles are often very tough if you're underleveled but with a correct strategy, they are very beatable without power grinding. You unlock new areas to explore by advancing the story and you are free to roam the areas you've unlocked. The enemies are visible on the map and they are all avoidable.

A 2D SANDBOX WITH TON OF STUFF TO DOFor the completionists, there is a ton of optional things to do. There's fishing, potion-making, side-quests, secrets, puzzles, pet catching, pet leveling, arena-battles, crafting and a ton of mob drops that are hard to get. I myself have already spend at least 2 times more than my Steam play-time shows in this game, doing all the optional stuff. That was over a year ago when there wasn't this much new content in it yet.

The leveling system is very nice since you get points to spend on skills as you please. There is a good amount of different skills to choose from and all of them have strategic value. There is also a lot of different equipment which you can buy, craft or get as a drop from the monsters.

YOU DON'T PLAY POKEMON-GAMES FOR THEIR STORYThe story isn't awful either. It's not the focus of the game nor the main reason to buy the game. It has enough meat in it to keep you motivated to go further and to give some context to your adventure but don't expect it to move you to tears or grab you emotionally. Think Pokemon games and their story and you'll know what level of story-telling to expect.

As a big fan of stories and powerful story-telling in games, I would've wanted a more compelling story-telling personally but because of the strong gameplay, the lack of PSX-era Final Fantasy-esque story telling doesn't bother me much at all.

TOO LONG, DIDN'T READAll in all, this has been my #1 most anticipated indie-game since 2013, when I bought the pre-order beta. SoG is a a good balance of excellent gameplay, exploration and story. While the story is not up to par with the gameplay, the complete package is still excellent and the 3 Swedish Stooges can be proud of what they've been working on for all these years.

The rare loot drops keep you farming mobs and bosses, and for the meta meta minded, there are card drops from in game enemies, in game achievements, Steam achievements, and presumably down the road, Steam cards. Greenlight - It took way too long to get Greenlight, dammit.

Development time - Stalking the devblog gets old after a while.  It has been way too long a wait for the complete game, dammit.

I might have an issue with patience.

Do yourself a favor, if you ever enjoyed overhead Nintendo games, support the devs, give this a shot.  It's only an amazing themesong and a fuzzy sprite away from being a classic.

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

It's a zelda-eqse play-with-your-friends 8 bit RPG + an additional mode where you can play it as a roguelike with your friends. It's incredibily polished and the combat system is well refined and requires more timing and depth than other games of the same genre. While some of the ways to beat the bosses are cliche, this is not necessarily a downside because they are splendidly executed. Furthermore, there are a fair amount of bosses whose patterns/attacks the developers have taken creative liberty to make unique, unexpected, and enjoyably difficult. Characters are not class bound; rather each character has a limited number of usuable skill points and the same pool of skills they can choose from. This allows for multiple unique playthroughs on both story and arcade (roguelike) mode. I haven't found a similar game that brings forth the amount of depth, polish and nostalgia that Grindea has.

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

I have over 100 hours pumped into the game [if you include the pre-steam access] and this is one of my favorite games of all time.

Pros:
- Typical story, but hilarious dialog, fun characters and environmental/discovery-based story telling makes it a great experience.
- Super deep and rewarding combat system with a plethora of skills and mechanics to master such as the perfect guard.
- Enemies and bosses attack differently between normal and hard mode, as well as single or multiplayer
- Skill charging makes it so you have almost 3 different skills at your disposal despite leveling only one skill.
- Loads of side quests, mini games and discoveries to be found.
- Multiplayer with up to 4 players that is super smooth gameplay-wise. Connection is also easy via Steam friend list.
- Gorgeous pixel art that contains many little details to make the game world feel alive.
- Music fits each area very well and does not overstay its welcome at all.
- Arcade (roguelite) mode adds a ton of replayability. Beating it is hard enough, the side roguelite quests and high score chasing allows infinite replayability.

Cons:
- Non-hosts may experience lag, which ruins the multiplayer experience [case-by-case basis]
- Would be nice for some skills to interact with each other more for multiplayer mayhem [Earth spike wall + Smash?]

For a detailed full impressions video [8 minutes long], check out this video below!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IE9YK0uO0nY

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

Admittedly, I went into this game not knowing much about it at all, which is somewhat rare for me in this day and age. I did this because I felt I didn't need to know much about the game, my very first impression from the trailer and a youtube video sold me on the spot. And I can say, roughly 9 hours into the game as of this review, that my first impression was spot on. If you enjoy the classic action RPGs of the 1990's and early 2000's, such as Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, Illusion of Gaia, or (obviously) Secret of Mana, then this game is for you and is well worth your time, money, and intrigue.

From my perspective, this game offers 4 distinct areas of interest that define the experience:
Story Mode
Arcade Mode
Multiplayer
The Progression System (Skills and Talents) I will be covering all 4, explaining my experiences and impressions of each.

STORY MODEWhile a bit lacking in the engaging story aspect, Secret of Grindea's (SoG) Story Mode offers something many RPGs have failed to have for a while now: the elegance of simplicity. Many modern titles have an obsession with creating a novel's worth of narrative. Cutscene after cutscene, wall of text after wall of text, the experience of these titles are moreso about the story and presentation of it than the actual game.

SoG takes the short and simple approach, where it gives enough story and narrative to provide context and motivation, but is spaced well enough where it does not feel like a chore to read through it all (having the option to skip cutscenes helps too). Not to say that the story isn't interesting, though. While simple and somewhat of a parady of other RPGs, many of the characters are likeable in their own right and their clever interactions are both entertaining and humurous. It's clear a lot of heart was put into the devolpment of this game from all of the silly and minor references to other games and characters.

Putting aside the storytelling aspect of SoG, there's quite a bit of content packed into what is currently available (game is still in beta as of this review). From collectables, to crafting, to minigames, puzzles, Zelda-esque dungeons, side quests, arena challenges, and engaging and replayable boss fights, there's a lot to do. But my favorite aspects are the inclusion of a genuinely difficult hard mode that can be toggled on or off at any time and the ability to customize the look of your character in the form of hats and accessories (that override the look of your currently equipped armor).

To review:

Pros:
Simple but effective narrative
Interesting and humurous dialogue
Plethora of activities, side quests, and minigames
Interesting boss fights
Hard Mode
Cons:
Game not complete (with no ETA)
ARCADE MODEArguably, this is where most of your time will go. This mode is SoG's roguelike feature, where you attempt to progress as far as you can through a serious of increasingly challenging rooms and obstacles on a single life. Much in the way of other roguelikes (such as Rogue Legacy), you have the ability the make succeeding runs easier in the form of unlocking perks. These are unlocked via a currency you obtain randomly as a drop and from completing quests and achievments.

The farther you go and the better you do, the more points you will recieve. After each death, your points are tallied up and added to your total score across all games. After certain thresholds have been met, you will revieve rewards, such as cosmetics (hats and accessories), more NPCs to interact with, and more buildings/decorations for your hub. There is also a global leaderboard for the mode, so if you're into that sort of thing you can sate your fancy here.

As for the actual content of the mode, it's challenging but rewarding. Like any other roguelikes, there are a lot of elements of randomness involved. The dungeon layout, challenges in each room, and the loot you get are all up to chance. However, this works as the combat system is based on skill moreso than raw stats. You will get farther in the dungeon because you got better rather than because you got some good luck on your drops. You find that you are excited to get as far as you can as that shows just how much better you got at the game more than anything else.

Pros:
Unlockable Perks
Achievments
Leaderboard
Replayability
Cons:
Can have a somewhat harsh learning curve
Can feel repetative at times
Like story mode, not all of the floors are implemented yet.
MULTIPLAYERWhile I have no personal experience with this feature myself, I have seen examples of this in videos and streams. From what I have seen, multiplayer is fairly smooth and simple to do. Multiplayer is available for both Story Mode and Arcade Mode, so if you have a group of friends you can enjoy all aspects of the game together with up to 4 people.

Be that as it may, it's not perfect. Currently, there is no option to play with your friends locally. You will need to connect to each other through different computers, and each person will need to have a copy. Additionally, it lacks some quality of life functions such as being able to join someone from your friends list. And, as one would expect from online play, there can exist some connection issues and bugs (although I've yet to see any).

Pros:
Can play with up to 4 people
Can play in both Story Mode and Arcade Mode
Smooth and stable online play
Cons:
Can have some connection issues and bugs
Lacks QoL polish
No Local Play
SKILLS AND TALENTSAn RPG needs to have some form of progression, and SoG does it with it's ability system. What makes this one stand out from the rest is its simplicity and its lack of restrictions. There are no skill trees, no level/stat requirements, you just choose the skills you like and roll with it. And so much is added to this game because of it.

There are a varity of skills that appeal to all forms of play, be it aggressive, defensive, evasive, melee, range, single target, AoE, Burst, DoT, etc. And given the lack of restrictions on obtaining skills, you can create a massive amount of different and interesting builds. Want to be an aggressive and fast melee striker? Go for it. Want to be a long-ranged magic nuker? Sure! Want to combine both melee and magic for a hybrid spellsword? That's cool too.

Additionally, a lot of the skills from different branches work well together. For instance, Static shock is a spell that will do additionally damage very time you hit with a physcial attack. You can restore charges for this skill from using physical skills or doing perfect guards, meaning this skill can be used in all kinds of builds, both offensive and defensive.

While I would argue a need for more skills, the simplicity of the current design is also appealing and useful. While some talents prove to be more useful than others, many of the skills have their uses and can work well given the right circumsances.

In the end, what gives this game a lot of replayability, both in Story Mode and in Arcade Mode, is the progression system and the appeal of trying out new builds and tactics.

Pros:
Non-restrictive
Skills work well together
Interesting and thoughtful effects
Easy to make and try new builds and tactics
Simple and easy to understand
Cons:
Some talents not as useful as others
Arguably not enough skills to facilitate variety

Secrets of Grindea
Early Access Review

For some odd reason, the game reminds me a lot of Paper Mario for the N64. I'm not exactly sure why... there's hardly any similarities.

I tried the demo of this game (lead up to the arena fight), and it had me sold. I was hesitant to buy it at the time, on sale, or was released... the formar took over (and I'm glad, worth every $ and then some). This game just... pulls me in and refuses to let go. I have to pry myself away from the game! (or till I feel my bladder being full to the brim...)

I picked hard difficulty as normal felt... easy for me... I have completely underestimated hard difficulty than I usually do for RPG games! At first I thought the game was just a collection of popular and maybe hardly used RPG tropes... well I'm not completely wrong. The story in the game is... interesting to say the least (up to what I reached)... at least I think there's a story? Somewhere? Maybe I overlooked it half way...

The game does encourage AND reward you for grinding/farming. I've noticed several times the spawn rate increases if it registers you grinding/farming, unlike other RPGs the spawn rate will decrease and/or would spawn mobs elsewhere instead of the spot you're on. (Looking at you MMORPG's... especially the F2P ones...) For some reason... grinding/farming isn't so trivial or boring than other games. Probably because I'm not seeing high leveled players showing me up one-hitting everything while I'm struggling (Always saw that as bad form) or the struggle isn't worth it.

Some of the mobs I feel move a bit too fast for hard mode. Strong, more HP, and additional moves I understand but... some just don't pause at all. Rather have the mobs pause less than in Normal than not pausing at all. Be nice if mobs had a weakness and resistance. Having a hard time just trying to kill them with no disadvantages.

The boss fights... either the bosses need a little tweaking, the leveling system needs bit of a fix, and/or the skills need to be reworked. There's been a few boss fights that nearly made me just go to normal difficulty (I had to temporary for the sentry mini-boss due to the stupid orbs!) Either too much is going on for me to register what's happening, I'm unable to get strong enough to properly face this boss/foe, and/or the skills I have are weak than they should be.

I've nearly crafted every item on the current list... on bit of a card hunt now. See cards as a reward for grinding/farming excessively as they give you benefits whether to your stats or purchases (that I've seen so far). Wish leveling actually increased your stats than just give you points to spend... I shouldn't feel so weak than I should be for (current) end-game bosses (toward Winter, Hydras, Toy Machine, etc.). Granted it's hard, but shouldn't be dark-souls difficult! (That's what it felt like most of the time after the numerous times of being frustrated at bosses to the point of nearly tossing my laptop out the one story window!!!)

Pick this up at its price of $15. Shouldn't wait for a sale, unless you're low on cash, to enjoy this. If you rather play a finished product than in development, then you'll be waiting for quite some time. Half of the story content is in the stable beta right now.

I'll most likely either update or completely rewrite this review when the game is finished. I think I'll wait till this game is finished before I continue any further in the story though.

Update: Tried a bit of Arcade Mode... it's not very forgiving that it discourages me. Reminds me of Rogue Legacy but harsher...

Eador. Masters of the Broken World
This is so close to being an amazing game that it causes me physical pain. It's that close, but there are a few crippling flaws that just ruin it. First, there's the combat. There are different ranks of creatures, one through four, one being weakest and four being most powerful. The problem with this is, after a certain point, anything below rank three will die in the first turn of battle because the enemy AI consists entirely of 'KILL WEAKEST CHARACTER'. The combat maps are tiny so forget any sort of strategy, mid and end game opponents can hit you anywhere you stand. Oh, and those opponents are almost always all one to nine monsters, plus nine to twelve wizards. There are three wizard types, and you will see up to a dozen in every single combat.

There are dragons in the game, and you can find them as random encounters. That isn't a problem. A single low level dragon can be beaten, but it's fairly tough unless you come loaded for end game critter hunting with high end, high level units. It's cool. You get an achievement. What isn't cool is that the dragons can spawn in groups of up to six, and all of them in the level 15 range. There might be worse groups out there, but this is literally what invaded one of my provinces in my current game. This isn't something you can fight. I also mean that Literally. You can not defeat these multiple dragon encounters. It isn't possible. You can build an arena in your home province and send heroes to battle in it to gain experience. Why am I mentioning this? because as soon as a hero reaches level ten, the enemy heroes you battle in the arena can also spawn with dragons as minions. It goes about as well as you'd expect.

On the plus side, your units can level up and improve their abilities, but it really doesn't matter, because a lvl 30 tier one unit will still be instagibbed by a lvl 1 tier four. And the upgrade system is utterly worthless as well. Why yes random number generator, I did want to improve my crossbowmans hand to hand skills for the fourth time in a row. No, he doesn't need better ranged attacks, he needs to be able to swing that butterknife he has like a man!

There are hundreds of items you can find, which is nice, but there's almost no storage space for them. You get a tiny little vault that can't be upgraded. It wouldn't be so bad but on the same screen you have access to the merchant window to sell stuff, and hey, if you guessed that had a scroll bar and infinite space in it, go get a cookie or something. You can build an artifact shop so you can buy artifacts, but unfortunately it doesn't cycle through different ones. You get the opportunity to buy three randomly chosen ones and it never changes for the rest of the game. Those three items are pretty much going to be terrible and I really want to chalk it up to being a bug that it doesn't refresh every so often, but it's been like that since release so probably it isn't.

There are four types of hero you can recruit, but you shouldn't bother getting anything but a warrior. The warrior is so much better than the other three it defies belief. Scouts can be useful for the rare encounters designed exclusively to kill warriors, but that's about it. Oh, and yeah, there are encounters designed from the ground up to murder warriors. packs of medusa will petrify you and then poison you, giant spiders will web you down and poison you, giant slugs will poison you if you hit them or vomit poison on you from a distance if you don't.

Edit: Okay, so I finally managed to grind a mage high enough to use a specific spell named 'white magic', and basically, it lets you break the game over your knee like a rotten twig. Two casts will clear virtually any combat encounter of critters, barring the two (the latest update may have added more) creatures who are magic immune. Once you get one cast per combat, better beleive that mage is going straight to lvl 30 since he can now effectively obliterate entire armies. Unconquerable foes turn instantly into big, meaty sacks of free XP. Just load up every unit slot with lvl 1 swordsmen, the enemy creatures/mages/whatever will go and kill them while your mage, free and unharmed, fires magic nukes that hit EVERYTHING ON THE MAP FOR MASSIVE DAMAGE. This is a well balanced, well implimented ability that reduces multiplayer combat to 'whoever goes first wins'. Casting it does a small amount of damage to the mage, but a couple of healers can fix it easily before any monsters that made it to turn two kill them for being a weaker, easier target than the wizard FIRING MAGICAL NUKES AT THEM.

Oh, and I hope you like really, really really loud TING! sounds, because the game plays one over and over at random for no reason I can discern.


Edit: I also hope you don't like loading saved games, because doing that while the game is running will cause the entire thing to crash. Not always, but often enough that I had to mention it.




Shouted at by a dev and I didn't even get an acheivement for it.

Eador. Masters of the Broken World
Ok I always look for negative reviews first. My opinion is that someone who hates the game will over exagerate the flaws, but at least will talk about the flaws where someone who loves it is less likely to. That being said, I still love this game even though it has flaws. However, some people won't like it as I do so I will begin with the negatives then move on to the positives since that's how I approach it anyway.

Negatives:
Crashes too much. I'd say once every few hours of play time you will have the game crash. It's not enough to bother me, but it can be frustrating.
AI can be off pretty bad. Battles that will tell you are impossible sometimes can be beaten manually without losing a single hit point. Battles that say they are so weak they are not worth your time will sometimes wipe you on auto. That doesn't happen all of the time, and with some play time you can easilly judge for yourself. Also computer players will keep throwing themselves at your defenses every time they resurect even if they die every single time in some situations.
Bugs. There are a few, one that for some reason will pop up the AI's hero screen in front of me which has shown me they get a +10 gold per turn bonus per hero at the level I was playing at.

Positives
It is constantly changing. Every time you start a new character or see a new world, the game will be different, different maps, different quests available. It kind of reminds me of Civ in that aspect.
You can chose how you play. Some games require you to be the hero, some games require you to be the villian, this game requires you to be whatever you feel like being.
It is a great strategy game IMO. Losing a single soldier at the wrong time can cost you an entire map, granted like most strat games you can always load fail (load the game and redo a fight because you lost), but not all of us play like that.

So with all of that I'd say the game play and replayability are worth it. The bugs and glitches and even AI issues can be fixed (or modders can fix them if it ever opens to mod on steam). Overall I'd say the positives outweigh the negatives enough for me.

Eador. Masters of the Broken World
This is an oddball of a game, on one hand the campaign can be incredibly tedious and repetitive (just got your castle and hero leveled to where you can kick ? Oh well, time to start the next map from scratch!). But on the other hand, it's the difficulty of fighting you're way up from the bottom that really makes this game shine.

I'm hesitant to recommend this game on word alone, find some videos first and see if you would enjoy the Civ/Might and Magic/Kings Bounty mashup. The game is pretty fun, but after a while, I'm finding I have to take it in small doses as repeating the same actions to win a slightly different map gets very boring (even with maps/shards that have different properties to them, they don't seem to be enough to warrant varying from a proven tactic).

Eador. Masters of the Broken World

You've heard the saying that 'the sum is greater than the parts'; in this game, the parts are greater than the sum.  There is such a good game here waiting to 'happen'.  Unfortunately, the overall game design is flawed.

Specifically, the size of the 'shards' and the mechanics of the shards hurt the overall game.  Because of this, you won't even use most of the best units/buildings/etc.  In essence, you've got all this outstanding content that never comes into play bacause of the mechanics of the 'meta-game'.
