These buildings can all be protected from outsiders or be set to public if you wish to share with others

The game is heavily material grind and PvE based wich in my opinion is great cause you feel that you have progression but ofcourse that differs for others.
That said PvP is also a big part of this game. At the moment when you kill other players you can loot all their resources if they aren't able to pick it up within 15 minutes. The gear will stay after the resources are picked up so you won't be completely useless after you've been killed.

Combat takes abit getting used to i'm hoping to see future improvements since the animation when swinging your melee just swings your arm rather then seeing your body put weight into the swing.
Would also love to see more diversity in melee weapons as the begin we're able to make a 'club' while the rest of the melee weapons are all knifes ( wich look pretty badass )

For guns there is a good diversity from what i've seen. Assault rifles, pistols and shotguns at the moment.
Combat with those also needs improvement since now whenever you shoot you always have to be zoomed in wich is quite annoying since you cant really see what's going on around you and walk into mobs or against walls wich gets me killed most of the time.

As for teams we're able to set a 'FoF' up at the moment that way you can share structures, portals and other stuff with your buddies.

I've had tons of fun so far and will continue playing this. Already been in a conflict with other players where i got ganked on the moon and retaliated by seeking sweet revenge upon their base !

Bring it on players !

Oh and if you don't like PvP you can always choose a PvE server :)

I hope this review gave you enough information, if you have any questions feel free to ask.
I always keep steam broadcasting on for everyone so if u want to see gameplay footage you can always check it out too !

GRAV
Early Access Review

For the Price of a Movie ticket and a soda I got a little over 3 hours of entertainment and overall I enjoyed my play of the game and look forward to what features and advances the game will add as it progresses
(EDIT: I should perhaps specify that I purchased the game while it was on sale during it's being launched on Steam, the standard price of the game is of course more)

GRAV is a crafting/resource/survival game...one of many that have sprung up from the success of Minecraft and DayZ
What I find attractive about GRAV is the Sci-fi setting, I'm not really into the swords and zombies direction most survival games take (just a personal preference)

The game is currently in Alpha and at this stage is more a proof of concept, while future features and functionality will most likely be patched in as the game goes through it's journey from Alpha to Beta and finally to RELEASE, this is what we can expect from the core experience

As of now I had no trouble running the game, nor any trouble finding a server
While at the time of this writing there is not yet a singleplayer/offline mode, this I expect will be added in the future
For now it was best for me to play on a public server, especially since there is really not much to this game except the bare bones functions and interacting with other players and what they had built gave me a jump start on the begining of the game and gave me something else to do beside the few functions available at this time
There are most certainly bugs and glitches and wonky controls, but since this is an Alpha I'm willing to set aside these flaws with the assumption that most if not all will be addressed at a later date
What I'll be focusing on is what the core elements of the game are like as of now

-IMPRESSIONS-
You spawn in the wilderness, most likely near other players which makes resource gathering a bit of a hike...since you'll have to travel to find the resource nodes you'll need to craft your items
You have only a knife and a Multitool at start, and you can make your way just fine with those alone, though stronger enemies and dungeons might require stocking up on better gear
You'll fight weird aliens and gather resources to build a home base or try your luck in one of the leveled dungeon instances that spawn throughout the world
You'll explore weird alien landscapes where the laws of physics seem to bend if not break, with rocky deserts and lush yellow forests, from floating rocks to poison seas, from abandoned structures to crashed spacecraft
All randomly generated so each trip over the mountain offers a chance at something new

-CRAFTING-
While I played I found only 5 nodes to gather resources
Trees = Wood
Piles of Bone = Fossils
Shiny Rocks = Ore
Smoking Crater = Element X
Each node has a chance to drop a more refined or rare resource, but overall these are all you can expect to find as far as gathering/farming is concerned
You use these resources to craft buildings and crafting stations
As of now there is no way to un-build what you've built, but I'd expect this to change in the future
Crafting Stations are where you'll build your equipment and refine your resources, Upgrading your stations allows for access to more items
Enemies are currently the only way to gather new recipes and blueprints

-COMBAT-
Combat is real time and skill based, you'll have to time your swings and stay outside of the enemies range of attack
You'll gain levels from killing enemies and each enemy has it's own level, so don't be surprised to see yourself die at the hands of a higher level enemy
Death is not perminent, in fact you don't even lose all your items, only a portion of your items are left at your corpse (and that portion can be reduced by spending skill points in the appropriate skill)
Your lost items will remain where you died and will be Loot Locked" for a period of time

GRAV
Early Access Review

With over a 160 hours on Grav as of the time this review was written. I did like to believe I can at least write a decent one.
I now clock over 400 hours as of build 20.

I have also written a guide for this game. Reading it will help you address the common annoyances people have with the game and also further influence your decision to get it.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=470854662
The review has had stuff added due to patch 19. Nothing was removed though.
This review has been re-written for build 20 due to the large amount of stuff and improvments added to the game. New players have a much easier time starting the game now due to the new damage curve, area level re-rolls and tutorial objectives.

Firstly, Grav is a sandbox open world, much like the other sandboxes on the market, you farm for resources, craft stuff, build bases and consume stuff to survive. It also belongs in the Sci-fi theme. The game does start out alittle boring, but once you get to around level 13 and make your first trip to the moon, the game becomes infinitely more fun then. I would suggest trying the game till this point before asking for a refund.

What sets this game apart from the others? Honestly I cant give a definite answer to this yet, and I am not gonna mention dancing. The game is still in development and community suggestions on stuff to be added to the game are conflicting. [ e.g building decay ] But still I am recommending it  based on several factors.

Pros:
Large maps
Game is gorgeous
They got the basics right
All basic resources are always useful
Great developers
Early access, updates come hard and fast, a new build every 2 weeks
Vehicles, jetpacks, wingsuits
Problems are solved fast
Building stuff is great if you are innovative

Cons:
8GB RAM requirement
Repetitive combat [or rather, non existent combat changes across levels]
Repetitive dungeons [see a few and you see it all]
No end game content [yet]
Insufficient playerbase
Resource farming requires some knowledge of where to get the fastest amount
Some lag is present
Griefers. Like almost every sandbox game? Griefers is a problem.
Building stuff is horrible if you dont excatly excell at doing stuff like that
Early access

So allow me to elaborate on the pros.
The maps are pretty large maps. The starter world for example is consisted of 2 - 3 Islands and each Island is serval kilometers wide. By basics I mean, combat, movement, UI and stuff are all decently done, there are some problems and room for improvements but updates are comming in fast for them.

The game is gorgeous? A picture says a thousand words.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=482330205

Comments saying the game did not ship with graphics shown in the store screenshots? Rubbish... They didnt turn on post proccessing, obviously it wont look the same.

All resources have a use for them, you wont, lets say... have no need for wood when you reach max level. Far from it, wood becomes more important than ever. This applies to every single resource. Something which you thought useless at the start, for example, I thought plasma was useless after I got off the moon, little did I know my vehicles and drill platfolm required plasma to run... until I got them that is.

The developers are great, they are actively talking with the community, suggestions made by the community have even been added into the experimental build within hours.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/332500/discussions/3/530645446313592491/

Proof that I aint just pulling your leg.
There is a normal build, and an experimental one. Roughly every two weeks, all the patches added to experimental is released to the normal build and the build number goes up by one. Currently waiting on build 21.

What I mean by building stuff is great if you are innovative? Well...

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=470288120

A building project I did alone dubbed Project Racer. This was completed in less than 4 days inclusive of resource gathering.
The full thing can be viewed here

http://steamcommunity.com/app/332500/discussions/0/530645446305634897/

Also my base
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487241226

You may check my guide under section 7. for building projects I have completed and am in the midst of making. Hopefully they might give you some ideas if you do intend to buy GRAV


Now for the cons.

The ultimate killer for this game IMO, the game requires at least 8GB RAM to play properly at the moment. You can disable all the graphic options to enable GRAV to run at 4GB but thats the very bottomline it can go for now. This basically means unless you are using a custom laptop / high end one. You will not be able to play GRAV on a laptop.

Like a few other reviews have mentioned. There isnt much variety, Once you see a level 1 slime, you have seen the attack patterns for a level 60 slime as well. There are also NO headshot hitboxes in the game YET. I have personally confirmed with the developers they are adding this in, but no ETA on it yet. So what does all these mean? Basically PvE combat in this game boils down to kiting over and over again. But considering its early access and they are planning to release more content for combat its excusable... at least for me.

Currently the game has basically non-existent replayable end game content. But as you can probably see, the devs are starting to prepare and release stuff for that. Vehicles for upcomming warzones like the build 20 released hammerhead [ VTOL Jet ]. New monsters, stuff like that.

Insufficient playerbase is related to its somewhat bad start and also the lack of end game content. When more content is released, I do believe the playerbase will increase substainally. This game has alot of potiential and the devs are living up to it.

Resource farming on the other hand isnt as bad as some people made it sound. As with a majority of the cons, I have covered ways to make your life easier in the guide above.


The game is horribly optimised for large scale building projects atm. Patch 19 is supposed to fix quite alot of it but we will see.
EDIT
As of patch 19, Building large scale projects no longer lags the game to kingdom come. I now run at a pretty smooth 20 fps around my base. Previous was 9 - 15 FPS along with severe lag spikes. Do note that my base is HUGE and filled with dymanic base items like laser fences. I play with 30 - 60 FPS on other planets. This is with a custom laptop.
Another EDIT
Patch 20 further improves on building with serval optimizations and also introduces building decay into the game.

And.... griefers. This one is a major blow to the game. I will be upfront and say this. The PvE servers are even worse for griefing than the PvP ones. This is because a griefer can shoot your buildings and you cant even damage them while they are doing so on the PvE ones. They are planning fixes for this but I did not ask for an ETA for this [because there are ways to grief proof your buildings]. Also there are alot of stupid things that are done [e.g new player killing] by a small minority of jerk players... well you get my point. If you do intend to get this game I recommend you head to the offical server in your region with 01 in their name. For example, I am based in ASIA PvP 01. These servers normally have an active community that will help and look out for each other to keep the griefers away.

Building stuff, this one took me hours to learn. Once you learn how to utilise the system its easy, but before that its a pain in the *ahem* to do so. Just building a simple house with a single door to a balcony can drive you nuts when you are first starting to build stuff. I have covered how to use the system in the guide.

And so yeah, do I recommend this game?
If its on sales? Of course
At full price? Sure, I gotten more than my money back already.

GRAV
Early Access Review

I had high hopes for this game and realised quite quickly this game is nothing but a daily grind.

The setting is quite interesting and I quite like the graphics. Though after a while it gets quite boring as everything just looks the same.
There is no manipulation of the surroundings, no landscaping. All you can do is build certain devices and pre-factured containers. Wooden containers, stone containers, glass and metal (which you can't build unless you level a certain profession up, which takes forever...). No free building as you would be used to from other survival/mincraft genre-like games.
And these pre-factured blocks are the main problem. All items have a certain amount of degrading time (unfortunately usually quite short, something like 2 days). If you don't login over the weekend, you'll suddenly stand there without your house. The only way to keep them from degrading is to build a certain type of shield. This shield needs a generator. This generator needs wood. So what you basically do is logging in every day, grind wood to keep the generator and your shield going to keep the house from degrading. And this is literally your own purpose in this game.
Apparently there are more features, like claiming land which then makes you be able to claim tax from other players. But unfortunately, as blueprints need to drop from bosses, after 2 weeks of playing this game and basically mainly logging in, gathering wood for the generator and killing endless mobs outside and inside of caverns I didn't get anywhere.

As it is bad enough already, I played this game with my brother, so technically there was twice the manpower, twice the chance of dropping blueprints and you would suggest twice the fun. But it wasn't. We just both got annoyed really quick and as you might be able to see in my playing time in other games, I am usually not giving up that easily.

No quests, same monsters over and over again, random NPCs called Wei Wei the Wanderer" appearing wandering about and being killed by the monsters. Same with Vending Machine robots.

Unless you're an old-fashioned WoW grinding lover... you should avoid this game."

Early Access Review

This game has some of the usual EA problems but the foundation is rock solid and I have had a lot of fun in just my first couple play sessions.   Compared to many EA games this game has a lot of content and variety and the frame rate is smooth even on my mid tier rig.   The landscapes are gorgeous and the art style works with the music to produce some real immersion.

I enjoy PvP and so far I like what I see.  Gear and level is important but so are tactics and aim.  At level 4 I was able to scare off a level 19 just using the starter pistol when he had an assault rifle.    I was also attacked by a level 9 when I was level 7 and was able to down him mostly because I had better gear (had the better pistol at that point) so it's a good mix of skill and gear based victories.

The gunplay feels  a lot like Halo to me and I mean that in a good way.  It's arcadey but still feels like skill matters and accuracy while shooting on the run is critical and can be practiced.

The end game seems completely different then the beginning so I will update my review when I get to that but so far so good with Grav.  More people should be playing this game IMO it's highly polished and fun for an EA game.

Early Access Review

This game has a good start for a good game.  However, in its current state, it is limited and buggy - as to be expected for early access.

The good:
Graphics
Combat
Exploration
Simplified resource gathering
Vehicles
Guns
Pets
Wide variety of items to craft
Classes with bonuses

The bad:
No real level progression*
Collision detection
Rarity of certain common resources*
Lack of base defense options
Lack of harvestable resource types
Lack of monster models
Very resource intensive
Small groups are ineffective*

The bad will probably be resolved, but a few really stick out.
*No real level progression: Sure your classes can level up and you can create new weapons and armor.  However, it doesn't matter.  All weapons are level based damage.  This means if you give a level 1 character the max level weaponry, they will still hit mobs that are only one level above them for minimal damage.  This is not apparent at lower levels, but after one reaches level 20 or so, it is an obvious pattern.  Bosses that used to be challenging turn into a huge time and ammo sink instead of being fun.

*Rarity of certain common resources: There are a ton of resources in this game.  However, you will run into a brick wall for one or two of them that are extremely rare - even though they are marked as common.  These resources will be staples to your progression and will basically stop it until you run around gather the 1 or two around the entire planet for a few hours.  But even then - when you do build that upgraded equipment, it won't have a noticeable change on combat.

*Small groups are ineffective: If you want to play this with 1 or two of your friends, it will be fun for the first few hours.  However, after level 20 or so, the no real level progression" portion kicks in.  If you find a loot chest or an artifact

GRAV
Early Access Review

I have played a significant amount of survival games. DayZ, Rust and Nether have been the dominant 3 for me. So far (I know it is early) Grav has all 3 beat. It seems like the dev(s) haved played all of these games as well and has corrected mistakes that the others have made. Here are a few benefits of choosing Grav over the rest.

- Penalty for dying isn't ridiculously brutal. Sure you go back to level 0 and lose some of your stuff but you keep the important stuff and get a shot at retrieving your lost goods from the spot where you kicked the bucket.

- Playing with friends. Rust and DayZ had me spending the entire time searching for my buddy so we could go.. survive. Grav has you build a Locator which gives you your lat/long. After building the Locator you never lose it. That's great.

- Food bar. No mare having to go somewhere and do the pointless activity of sitting and eating. You must collect food but eating is a passive feature.

- Traversing. Your dude moves swiftly and jumps and dances like no aliens are watching.

- Low-level areas are not overly punishing and aliens drop health. Tired of grinding in these survival games for an hour or so to start only to die and have to start over with this cycle repeating itself? Grav allows you to get going and keep going and progressing relatively easily unless you are KOS by another player which brings me to...

- The community is not full of KOS s. At least not from my experience.

Another thing I dig about Grav is while playing it, I feel like I'm in a really cool 80's space-flick. Not sure if the devs meant this but I definitely get this vibe. The music and dancing is great as well. This game is basically the MMO survival version of Planet Explorers with Unreal Engine 4 behind it.

My beef at this point is only with the lag. Lag at this point makes the game unplayable at times. It's very early access so I'll give them a break for now but that needs to be priority 1. The UI is god awful as well but you can tell it is just placeholder stuff that will soon change so no biggie.

Other than that I hope they fix the lag and focus on keeping the hackers at bay and we will have ourselves a winner.

**update 3/5** Game is currently dead. Maybe due to stability issues or lack of end game, people are likely waiting for bigger updates to hit the game before logging back in. Keep this in mind if you plan on purchasing at this time**

**Update 4/7** The devs have released some big updates and the game is coming along wonderfully. People are beginning to trickle back in. No reason at this point to not have confidense in the team behind this game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

22 hours was played thus far on a PVE server

I will start off with the negatives, if you don't like the look of any of these, stay away and come back later. If not keep on reading.
Lag issues:
-Lag is still an issue right as of now but the dev is working on it and commited to fixing it right now. A special test server is up and a patch has already helped part of the issue but there is still a way to go.

Somewhat barebones:
-You can't take down the stuff you build at the moment (well in PVE, I havn't played on a PVP server so I can't tell if it's PVE related only).
-No clear friendslist you have to make parties with custom codes and key commands.
-Inventory system is minimal and missing features like displaying the look/picture of an item when selected.

The Positives!
Alright still here? Good because what is there is really enjoyable. Did you see all the stuff in the trailer? You can do all of it (well ok 90%) at this very moment! (unlike StarForge *angryface*) You can level up to max level (30) and gear up accordingly. You can play co-op with friends and run dungeons and fight bosses together (or alone you Einzelganger you). You can build really neat bases, craft armor, weapons and yes working vehicles and jetpacks. The graphics are bright and the colorscheme is nice. The aesthetic has it's very unique, silly and somewhat cutesy personality.

All in all it's impressive how complete the game already feels for a 6 month old project and there is a lot of fun to be had already. If the developers keep this up this will be a fantastic game. But you do have to realise there is still work to be done. You must understand this is still an Early Access game (in alpha). So things will break, bugs will annoy you (and I'm not only talking about the enemies)  and stuff will be missing.

Give the trailer another go! Does it look apealing? Yes? Don't you mind alpha/beta testing? And do you want to add to the development of the game? Join in have a blast. (playing with friends recommended, game may be addicting)

GRAV
Early Access Review

Let me preface this by saying this game does have a lot of potential.  I have put quite a few hours in it, and in the beginning it was quite enjoyable.   Lets look at the good AND the bad.

Good
1. Graphics are quite nice.  The style is unique and pretty.
2. The crafting system is fairly robust.
3. Good music and sounds when they aren't bugged.
4. The IDEA behind the game is sound, if realized I may recommend this game.

Bad
1.  This has improved slightly, but this is still the most poorly optimized game I've ever seen.
2.  The sound is bugged badly since release, hasn't improved at all.  Random sounds and music at random times.
3.  This is FALSELY advertised as both Single-Player AND Survival.  It is neither of those.
4.  A better name for the game could be Grindy McGrinderson lands on the planet Grind and builds Grindytown.
5.  It literally seems to get worse with each patch.  Sounds have gotten worse, the events are no more than large groups of random mobs (unless you get slimes, then you might see some bosses), the resource placement is appallingly bad right now, and the instances are scarce and nearly useless.
6.  To call combat rudimentary would be generous. Imagine Minecraft combat, only not as intricate.

The game IS an EA title as some will surely point out.  This MAY all get ironed out by release, but I don't recommend games on what they might be.  At this state is not really worth $10, much less $20.     Do yourself a favor and let them sort out this mess, don't toss your money away just yet.

GRAV
Early Access Review

GRAV is a sci-fi themed survival game with action combat.
It feels kinda like a mix of World of Warcraft and Minecraft with a solid third-person combat thrown in.
The game is build using Unreal Engine and looks absolutely gorgeous.
And there's plenty of procedurally generated content to explore.
On top of that you can build your own base, which will undoubtedly be attacked at some point, so don't forget the defences.
Jetpacks, monocycles and pets are included.
Oh, and dancing around campfire to increase healing rate is there too! :D
Plus, developers are pushing out updates like crazy (just look at those build notes).

On the downside:
- Game in general is not very well optimized at the moment (and there are no options to tweak, only ini files). So, unless your machine meets min reqs (have at least 8GB of RAM, this game loves it), you probably shouldn't get it.
- Net code seems to be unoptimized at all - having any latency and lags to local server is a bit strange (although that might be related to fact that server as well eats tons of RAM and 8GB is just not enough for running both - server and client)
- Current (v7) progression is limited to getting all blueprints from monster and leveling your character does not do much.

Oh, and it's definitely more fun to play with you friends.
If that sounds like your thing - you'll probably enjoy playing GRAV!

Watch overview of the currently available things in the video below:
http://youtu.be/YYvj-3RsJpU

GRAV
Early Access Review

GRAV is an incredible survival game, the vibrant colors and fun art-style is a perfect mix. The game is mostly online only, I imagine there is probably a way to play by yourself, but that wouldn't make for a very entertaining experience. There aren't a lot of enemies right now, I have been told that this is due to a bug. So far I haven't experienced much PKing (Player Killing), though I have seen it happening according to the chat. The game has a nice friendly/unfriendly system, which makes playing with friends a lot easier. The caves/dungeons can be really hard to find, and leveling up can be very difficult as well, but this game is still extremely pretty and I hope to see this game get even better over the next several updates.

If you are thinking of purchasing this game, I would highly recommend it, there are a lot of friendly players and the game is very well made.

World of Goo

Its a very well thought out physics puzzler where you use your goo-balls to build structures under different rules depending on the level, and the balls at hand. While the graphics are cute you should not be fooled to think the game is very easy, it actually gets really challenging at times and requires a lot of skill, patience and luck to fully beat. Strong recommendation.

In the end, it reflects our reality, which is 2D Boy's major feature - a simple childish game with deep sense. No spoilers, of course.

This game makes you think. This game makes you feel. This game lets you be creative. This game is awesome. In my opinion, everyone should play it at least once.

World of Goo
-Quick Review-
World of Goo is an Indie-Physics-Puzzle Game developed in 2008 by 2D BOY. World of Goo is one of those quaint games that you would probably prefer to play on a mobile or smaller electronic device (with touch screen capabilities); in World of Goo you create bizarre contraptions with Goo to get to the end of the level.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You progress through the game being guided by Signs" (or the "sign painter". But I always thought the signs were the side painter)

World of Goo

Gameplay

World of Goo is a 2D physics-based puzzler with gameplay that revolves around building structures out of goo balls" in order to reach a pipe at the end of stage. While this is a relatively simple set up for a puzzle game

World of Goo
World of Goo is an absolute classic by my measure. It shines very brightly, and is a must-play for any indie game enthusiast (I have many many hours in this game, just not on Steam).

Essentially, the goal is to build architecturally-sound structures to bridge gaps. Its like a wild version of Bridge Simulator. The building mechanics are really fun, but arguably the best part of this game is the artwork and definately the storyline.  While the story is quite abstract, but absolutely emotionally engaging.

The only negative I can really mention is that the game can feel a bit dated, at this point. I loaded it up this year and all the charm is still there, but the graphics and controls have not aged all that well. Regardless, its a classic.

World of Goo
Where to start with this...
I originally played this on a Powermac G5 when it first came out around the end of 2008, I remember that I originally got it sometime around the 2008 election. My attention was focused on this game the whole time.

It's one of those games where it seems extremely simple at first, but then the complexities and depth of it gradually shine through. The puzzles are neat, and I never had to use any skips until the last part (and I normally sucka t puzzles) but they don't feel easy, they feel satisfying regardless.

The visuals are nice, and they're crisp and good looking, and most importantly they do NOT resort to trying to look like pixel art. However, the game does run at a low resolution and there is no way to change it.

The soundtrack... Well, let's just say it's one of the best soundtracks in an Indie game ever produced. It is well performed, it is entirely originally composed, and it doesn't resort to sounding like chiptune or 16-bit stuff to try and manipulate nostalgic nerves. One of the best parts of the game for certain, and even better is that all of the soundtrack (the full versions, not the shortened versions in the game) can be found right on Youtube. Very memorable soundtrack, I can say that about very very few games.

Buy it? YES! It's on sale frequently anyways.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
As a developer, what would you do when your game is loved by a dedicated fanbase, but mired in dislike for it's stifling DRM? You make a stand alone expansion that is six times the original game and streamline it for an excellent online experience. Good guy Relic.

Real Time Tactical Roleplaying Game. That is how I would describe Dawn of War Retribution. It is focussed on character building, and using special abilities to clear obstacles and objectives. Clearning these obstacles rewards you with gear and other sweet loot to use and to adapt to circumstances. However, unlike the original Dawn of War 2, this one does it with more than just the Space Marines. This time round the campaign is open to the zealous Space Marines, the dogmatic Imperial Guard,  the enigmatic Eldar, the barbaric Orks, the horrific Tyrranids and the eldritch Chaos Marines. Each faction proceeds through the same story and events, but does so for a different purpose. The Space Marines need to clear their name, as their chapter master allegedly has fallen to Chaos, while the Eldar pursue the same cause to prevent their planets from being destroyed by the Inquisition. The Orks just want to fight and the Tyrranids hunger. The voice acting in the game is top notch and delivers the ruminations of each character with gusto and panachel; Slightly over the top, yet in tune with the material. The overal experience is entertaining and diverse, allowing for many hours of gameplay on your own, or with a friend.

The game also features and extensive multiplayer component to go head to head. It plays like your ordinary RTS, but allows for so much customisation in regards to outfits and paintjobs. You might be forgiven for thinking that Valve made this game. The overal experience is a fast paced stratagem, with more focus on skirmishes between parties than massive clashes between armies.

The last mode, and perhaps the most entertaining is Last Stand. In this mode, you and two others try to fend off twenty waves of enemy hordes with customised hero units. The mode is amazing for its many options and rewarding gameplay. No matter how far you come, the game will always reward you with points or items for your effort. Get a friend to two and tackle this beast. You will be entertained.

I could go on to muse this game for another while, but if you're not really into the compact rts style, or Warhammer for that matter, then this game might not be your cup of tea. It can also get a bit boring after five campaigns. Especially the more human oriented races do feel a bit stale after a while.

What? Of course not! Humans? Stale? Art thou mad? Humanity shall prevail. The Emperor wills it. The day that Chaos rules the minds of men shall never come. Stand fast fellow warrior and join us in the eternal battle against the foul beings that the vile warp hath unleashed. Forget you money; human lives are the Emperor's currency. So spend it well, and pay your debt to his Greatness!

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
the singleplayer campaign isnt too good but its also not very bad. repetitive levels though and a rather weak and short told story. still i had fun to hunt the achievements there and to play it with friends in coop-mode. bit annoying bugs there were, even before the migration from winlive to steam when achievements wont unlock, i had to play some races multiple times to trigger them.
the multiplayer is really great though. its just a good concept to ignore base building (which is boring in my opinion) and focus on the micro management of your army fighting for points. i like the great variety of units and abilities which allow different playstyles and lots of strategies. the biggest issue is and was the small player count in the multiplayer mode, still you find and found enough to pretty much always get some games going.
the greatest mode for me is the last stand mode, i dropped hundreds, if not thousands, hours into leveling my heroes and playing for score or just for fun or to help others. it never gets old and you can always jump back in after some time. you will always find players there immediately.
really poor is the support from relic though. the game still has quite a few bugs, especially after the migration from winlive, where the game started, to steam. this update really put a lot of new bugs in the game and took some good functions away and more or less was left in this state.
there is also a so called elite mod, which truely most veteran multiplayer gamer play today. its different balanced and features some more units and even a new faction. personally i dont like the balance there and prefer the balance in the original game. it ever and ever gets modified which maybe has a charme in its own, so you can adjust yourself ever again.
after all superb game. im hoping on dow 3. but i dont have great confidence in relic when i see all the balance mess they made in coh2 (which is now after quite some years, at least at the point im writing this, in a decent state, but the way it took...)

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
Gameplay wise, it has deviated a bit from the traditional Dawn Of War 2 campaigns in favour of a more Dawn Of War - Dark Crusade like meta campaign. You can now choose between Space Marines, Eldar, Orks, Chaos and the Imperial Guard. The campaigns are the same for everyone, however each race has their own agenda. But the goal of every race is to eliminate Azariah Kyras. That means even though the campaign feels redundant, it is refreshing to be able to change tactics and play the campaign as other races.

Retribution also brings some diversity to the campaigns, such that unlike the previous Dawn Of War 2 installments, you can now further diversify your forces by replacing your regular deployable hero units with other honor guard units, depending upon your play style or according to what sort of opposition you expect to face in the campaign. You can also now field a larger number of squads by capturing Relay Beacons (or equivalent for races other than the Space Marines) and call in additional squads or vehicles subject to the amount of Requisition you have captured during your battle. This makes your campaign similar to a skirmish game albeit with campaign like objectives.

You can also gain traits for your hero units faster since you get a guaranteed trait every time you level up, unlike previous Dawn Of War 2 installments, where you have to level up 2-3 times before you get a trait.

Though I feel its somewhat inferior to DOW2 and Chaos Rising story-wise, it is nonetheless interesting to see how the story ends for the Blood Ravens in the Space Marine campaign (which I believe is canon for this series).

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
INTRODUCTION:
Dawn of War II: Retribution is the third and final expansion to the Dawn of War II titles. (Also see my Reviews for Dawn of War II and Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising).

The story takes place after the events of Chaos Rising where Gabriel Angelos and his followers were labeled as renegades by their own Chapter Master Azariah Kyras. With the Tyranid invasions, Ork assaults, Chaos Incursions and Eldar Raids, the Imperium has had enough and has now sent the Inquisition to wipe Sub-sector Aurelia from the Galaxy. The player assumes the role of Captain Apollo Diomedes of the Blood Ravens Honor Guard in his quest to uncover the truth about his Brothers and the Chapter Master he serves.

PROS:
+ More Factions in the Singleplayer Campaign: -  It is refreshing to see that Relic decided to bring back their old formula where other factions are now playable. This includes, Orks, Eldar, Chaos, Imperial Guard and Tyranids. No Tau though.

+ Active Multiplayer Scene: - I normally don't care about Multiplayer in games but I found it very impressive that there still exists a very active online multiplayer community. Last Stand is always fun to play.

+ Imperial Guard: - This faction is the latest addition to the multiplayer / skirmish mode and is very fun to play. Well balanced in my opinion and has added new and interesting characters with likable personalities like Sergeant Merrick.

+ Hero Replacement: - You can now field special Honor Guard units rather than the Hero units you are given. Example: Leave Scout Sergeant Cyrus and deploy a Terminator Honor Guard Squad instead.

CONS:
- Dumbed Down Action RPG Element: - What made the Dawn of War II Campaign unique was its RPG elements. It was seriously disappointing to see it virtually stripped to its bare minimum with only 10 levels as the cap and severely limited wargear selections.

- Poor pathfinding: - Some of the larger vehicles will literally block your army from passing through and will do some really strange movements when it tries to make room for them to pass through. This will result in a very disorganized troop movement specially in some of the smaller maps, or maps with very narrow bottlenecks.

- Short Campaigns: - As a whole, the entire campaign is long if you play through all the factions, but individually, they are shorter than the previous titles with some very weak or hastily put together plot.

- Some unresolved bugs: - At the time of this review the game should be 3 years old but still I encounter bugged missions or bugged units and sometimes out right crashes. Not game breaking but this should have been fixed a long time ago.

CONCLUSION:
GOOD EXPANSION BUT I WOULD RECOMMEND PLAYING THROUGH THE ORIGINAL GAME AND CHAOS RISING FIRST. Retribution adds new factions and units to the game both in Single and Multiplayer, it gives back life to the series with a lot of interesting new characters and story. It does suffer from a rather weak campaign when compared to the original, but makes up for it in a fun multiplayer experience.

New players might enjoy this more for the multiplayer / skirmish rather than the story so I recommend new players to try the original Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising first or even the first Dawn of War game if they want to be invested in the Story.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution is an excellent RTS-style game where base-building itself is dropped, in favor of more strategic combat involvement. While this may seem initially like a dumbing-down from DoWI, the playstyle it encourages is more fast-paced, usually more aggressive, and leads itself to large armies splitting off across the map. This has ended up being a very fun way to play an RTS.

The campaign has benefited from this style in that in place of a Commander unit, you can have up to four Heroes that are powerful (typically single-person) units with Wargear upgrades and stat boosts while in a mission. These heroes can be substitued for an Honor Guard unit, which is a stronger version of a standard army unit. While building an army is fun, I also had a blast clearing the missions with only my Heroes and their witty banter.

Multiplayer has become faster, which is usually a plus, as it allows us to play more games, or to boot up a match when normally we couldn't. I enjoy that gameplay feels more aggressive, with players capturing Requisition Points and Power Nodes in order to increase the speed that accumulate resources to purchase army units, and with holding the Victory Points, in which you must hold more than your opponent for a period of time in order to win. This leads to a very active playstyle, where you're balancing defensive capabilities with offensive, and mobility with firepower. Nearly every unit has potential upgrades, either as stat increases or new weapons, allowing them to be good against, and bad against, different types of enemies. Something as small as purchasing a few Flamers will make your unit that much stronger with melee engages, and constantly staying one step ahead of your enemy in upgrades, or creating units to counter their build, will often be the deciding factor of whether you fall from grace, or rise in glory as a successful tactician. The Hero system also carries into Multiplayer, as you select from one of six races, then one of three Hero units per race. These Heroes have different skills and Racial Abilities, and encourage different playstyles. Similar to the Campaign, these Hero units can purchase Wargear ingame once they have met the requirements (per game, no carrying over), to grant higher stats and capabilities against different enemies.

The Last Stand, also sold as an individual DLC package, is a great mode where three players try to survive, and conquer, 20 waves of enemies. Each player selects a Hero and their Wargear before entering queue, with seven different Heroes, and a LOT of Wargear options. Mirrors are possible, but do not generally affect gameplay, and will likely have different builds. Wargear is obtained through leveling up, where you gain experience points at the end of the game, or through special, sometimes difficult, achievements. Most Heroes have two achievement Wargear unlocks. The Last Stand is incredibly brutal, very unforgiving, and you may never beat it. Players have the ability to revive fallen teammates, though this immobilizes the reviver, and reduces their firepower greatly, easily causing their death as well. Also on the map are two Point Multiplying Nodes, similar in appearance to Power Nodes, that add a x3 multiplier to your team's score each. Certain types of enemies will try to capture these points for themselves. Each Hero is vastly different, and every team composition is as well, leading to immense replayability, especially if you haven't beaten either of the two maps yet... (It's always that blasted Wave 20! ;-;)

Lore-wise this game is both engaging and genuinely gets the grimdark feel of the WH40k universe. As the story progressed, through the earlier two campaigns (DoWII and DoWII:Chaos Rising) and this one, I felt the tragedies come one after the other, and each victory feeling less and less impactful until you get that one killing blow that just brings everything you've done all together, and you can feel the weight just disappear off of your chest, and you sit back in the chair and let out this sigh of relief... until you are informed of another emergency happening almost immediately. It kept me on the edge of my seat with its grimdarkness, its surprisingly fitting comedy (especially playing as those 'ard Ork boyz), and my genuine interest in how it was going to play out. While a lot of people feel that the campaign is short, and it kinda is, it certainly isn't lacking in content or gameplay, and it was very fun.

Pros        Cons                Engaging campaign, interesting and fitting characters, fun take on an RTS.        Short campaign that may be a little lackluster if you haven't played the other campaigns in earlier games.                Fun multiplayer design that encourages constant action.        May take a while to get into the mode as there is a lot to learn, and a lot to manage.                The Last Stand is a great mode with high replayability and a fun premise.        May be repetetive, harder for lower-levels which may discourage Hero diversity, and one Hero is locked behind paid DLC.
TL;DR: 9/10 A very fun game that successfully captured the essence of the WH40k universe, and gave me three fun modes to play. There is a modding community as well, keeping it alive, and encouraging its growth. I highly recommend it to any WH40k or RTS fan.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
In the mold of the Dark Crusade expansion for the original Dawn of War, Retribution allows you to play a campaign for each available faction. Unfortunately, the Risk-style campaign map present in Dark Crusade does not exist in Retribution. Instead, each faction plays an almost identical campaign on a set path, with the only major differences being the characters you use and what your characters say. While it's fun to play the new heroes from each faction, the campaign rapidly becomes repetitive. I played through the space marine and ork campaigns and had fun, but I couldn't bring myself to finish yet another campaign with a virtually identical story and identical missions.

Not recommended.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution
The last installment of Dawn of War II. Finally you can play as any race in the single player campaign. There is no carryover component from the previous games, and the game itself is standalone. The abilities and wargear are fairly fun to customize, and the game is not hard even on the highest setting. A second map was added to the multiplare arcade mode, which was harder waves than the first. There is a purchaseable arcade-mode DLC that adds a Tau crisis/broadside unit as a playable hero, which is very interesting.

I guess overall this has to be my favourite series of all time, although I don't play this game at all anymore. Across the three games in this series I have logged almost 1000 hours of play, most of which was single player.

Maybe it's a bad idea to review all three games under one title, but they are best viewed as parts of a whole. The vanilla game was really challenging when played on Primarch; there was an intricate re-deployment system that encouraged you to play every mission to the best of your ability, as well as a ton of wargear that wasn't guarenteed to drop at fixed points. Chaos rising was my favourite, offering maximal flexibility in squadmates, gear, playstyle and choices. Once the Chaos Rising patch is applied to the vanilla game, playing the vanilla part on hardest becomes really hard. The Corruption system in Chaos rising was great, decently complex, and have a bearing on the ending. Retribution was the easiest game out of the three, but you can play as any race you want and the ending is open-ended. Once again, Retribution does not require the first two games to play, and it has no carryover mechanic, although the storyline is officially continuous. If you don't like to play as space marines but like the single player aspect, just play Retribution.

A lot of the criticism and confusion of Dear Esther is brought about because it is not exactly 'a game'. There are no enemies, no objectives, no inventory, nothing we've come to expect in video games. It is where art, storytelling and games intersect, to create a masterpiece.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=553155472

Dear Esther is visually astounding. Journey deep into the island's caves and you will be utterly in awe of the beauty therein.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=498467039

The music is beautifully haunting, always appropriate in intensity for the situation, and never overwhelming it.
The narration contributes significantly to the player's emotional state while traversing the island. His rantings and musings, his rage and his despair, all help lend color to the landscape, and keep the player firmly rooted in the world before them.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=532172608

Dear Esther
Well there's something you don't see everyday - Dr. Peter Venkman, Ghostbusters

THE GOOD
Dear Esther is not your ordinary game. In some respects, it is not a game at all. Focusing on environments and atmosphere rather than gameplay and action is a nice way to change the pace, but it will definitely put some people off. If you're a person who prefers Serious Sam and Doom over Amnesia and Proteus, I do not think this game is for you. The sound in the game is, well, not very exciting overall. The intro plops you into the island with explanation of why you are there, if you pay attention. The story is told by a nameless narrator, who talks about the island, his hobbies, and the mysterious Esther. Digging deeper into the story explains more about the characters and the settings, but only if you are willing to look.

THE GREAT
The game can be frightening and intense if you let it. Beautiful environments are accompanied by the haunting yet calming voice of the narrator, who tells his life to you. While not the best decision for gameplay, Dear Esther provides with an amazing narrative and an atmosphere that is so thick you could wrap yourself up in it. The first chapter is the make or break point in this game.While not looking very stunning, the first part does do its job to set up the second half of the game. Not giving away too much, but not boring you to the point of no return. The end of the second chapter is where it is its best. The aesthetic changes completely, music greets you immediately, and the haunting feeling kicks in. The third chapter is my personal favourite, with the climax of the game leaving you able to interpret it however you please.

THE UGLY
There is no gameplay whatsoever. If the developers wanted gameplay, they could've at least given you the choice to turn off and on your flashlight, or maybe do some simple puzzle. Face the facts: You walk extremely slow. Perhaps for pacing, but it can be frustrating whil you spend the whole damn game going 10mph (That's metres, not miles). Also, for a game about discovery, there is very little to discover, not that you'd feel inclined to due the the speed of your walking. It can be quite boring if you're playing it after watching a walkthrough of it on Youtube, TwitchTV, or whatever place you use to watch gameplay videos, so I'd recommend not watching gameplay of Dear Esther before playing it. Also the visuals of Dear Esther deteriorates when it is put into videos, no matter how you set the graphical quality (1080p does NOT do this game justice via video).

THE VERDICT
There are two types of people in the world. Type one is the type who prefer Proteus over Dear Esther, and the other type of people prefer Dear Esther over Proteus. I fall into the latter category, for many reasons. If in doubt, get it on a sale. If you like it, great news! If you don't, you spent $5 and 1.4GB 'playing' a game that you didn't like. Personally, I think that the third chapter is the best chapter in this game. For the first two chapters, you explore the island, and at the end of the second chapter, a forced plot point happens which sends you to the most beautiful part of this game. The final chapter wraps it up nicely, and some people will like the final chapter more, so suffice to say the second half f the game is generally liked more. Also, this is NOT a game for children. It can be difficult to understand and there are so many plot elements that are metaphors or relatively unusual.

SIMILAR GAMES
-Proteus, in many ways, but also differs greatly
-Amnesia: The Dark Descent, although without being as scary

For more reviews check out http://steamcommunity.com/groups/truereview

Dear Esther
During the first 10 minutes or so of this game, while I was wandering (slowly) through the game's initial area, I was bored. Very, very bored.  While I was bored there was a pretentious British guy babbling to me in an overwrought poetic manner about something that had happened and for which I had no background information to help me understand what the hell he was talking about.  That changed (thankfully): the backstory filled in, the environment and audio changed, and things improved dramatically.

This game has very impressive visual and audio aesthetics.  The background sounds and ambient music enhance the experience significantly (you should play with headphones on).  The voice acting is also compelling--you can really feel the narrator's internal turmoil as he struggles with what has happened.  The world the developers built here has a sense of mystery, purpose and beauty, but also sadness, introspection, and the portent of dread.  As I progressed through the game" I felt more and more anxious about the revelations to come from the narrator. The suspense was palpable

Dear Esther
Published by: Thechineseroom
Developed by: Thechineseroom & Robert Briscoe
Genre: Adventure/Walking Simulator
Release Date: February 14, 2012

IntroductionThis 'game' truly is an artistic masterpiece. Being a walking simulator, the aim is simple; you walk around an island, taking in it's beautiful surroundings. The protagonist of this 'game' is a man set on a journey across a seemingly abandoned island. As you walk, fragments of a letter sound, and you're left with questions, allowing your imagination to run rampant. Who is Esther, and why does this quiet island resonate such familiarity with our protagonist? Are the surroundings real, or imagined? Abandoned buildings, caves and shipwrecks, this island brings forth an eerie yet calming atmosphere, and the raw emotion is exemplified with the stunning atmospheric soundtrack.

Graphics The graphics are absolutely beautiful, and there is no lack of stunning landscape and imagery throughout the hour and a half (give or take) of game play. However, to call it a game would be entirely misleading; Dear Esther is more of a immersive movie, taking you on a beautifully narrated story around a mysterious island.

Verdict:
As the graphics are generally a main focus in a walking simulator (being that there's no real 'game play'), it's super important that they get this right- which they did, perfectly. The only negative thing I could say on the visuals of this artistic masterpiece, is that it ended too soon.
Score: 8/10

Soundtrack The beautiful instrumental soundtrack, composed by the talented Jessica Curry specifically for this game, has a tranquil, soothing vibe that really adds to the feel of the story. Add to that the calming narration by Nigel Carrington, and you're set to go on a relaxing and encapsulating first person experience.

Verdict:
The beautifully orchestrated soundtrack perfectly fits the mysterious and engrossing story line, filling the story with a soothing atmosphere.
Score: 9/10

Overall VerdictThis visually appealing game is definitely worth experiencing if you like peaceful games with a rich storyline.

Overall Score: 8/10

Dear Esther
First off, let's be clear: this isn't a game for everybody. Nor is it really a 'game'. If you want fast paced action, turn back now, but if you're looking for something different, something a bit avant-garde and arty, Dear Esther is well worth your time.

You play a nameless character (first-person) who wanders along a basically linear path accross an abandoned Hebridean island for about 2 hours while a narrator intermittently reads fragments of letters to a woman named Esther. Interaction is minimal: you can walk, look around, and zoom in slightly. A flashlight automatically turns on when you enter a dark place. That's it in terms of gameplay, but Dear Esther's focus is not gameplay, it's on story.

And what a confusing story it is. Piecing together the narrative will require you to listen carefully to everything the narrator says, read past the symbolism and shifting characters, and to play the game a few times (the fragments are mixed semi-randomly each time you start the game, so you won't hear every fragment until you've played the game at least 4 times). On top of that, you'll have to look around for visual clues on the island: objects littered on the ground, books in houses, diagrams and messages painted on walls. Even then, you'll still have trouble figuring out everything exactly what happened. However, you'll be able to work out the bare bones of the story from one playthrough.

As mentioned before, the story is primarily told through letters read out by a narrator who is the protagonist of the story. The writing is poetic, symbolic, and digressive, often making it difficult to follow, but this is intentional I believe. The writing is really excellent (although a little over-wrought at times), and is delivered fantastically by the voice actor. Without giving much away, the story concerns a tragic accident in the narrator's past, and explores themes of guilt and redemption. Its stunning conclusion nearly brought me to tears, and loses none of its power on replays.

The visuals of Dear Esther are stunning, wonderfully complimenting the loneliness and sadness of the story. You get a real visual feast, from the rugged hills above ground to the etheral caves below. The music is also beautiful, and goes well with the visuals and story.

By now, you know whether this game is for you or not. If you think it is, buy Dear Esther right now and get ready for the experience of a lieftime.

Dear Esther
This game is a gamble. You'll either have a near-life changing emotional experience and come out a changed person, or... you will be bored witless on an otherwise pretty walk on an island. I fell in the latter group unfortunately, and I cannot recommend this game.

Dear Esther
I did really end up enjoying it even if I can't recommend it. On the surface this has a lot going against it. Dear Esther feels like less of a game, more of an experience. You awaken on an island at one end under a lighthouse and you walk your way to a red beacon on a radio tower in the sky. The whole thing takes an hour or less to complete the experience. The controls are simple, walk and zoom. There is no jump or sprint.

You will experience the morbid and yet gorgeous island in all of its glory. I say experience more than explore. As much as you can walk around and think you're doing your own thing, you're really just on a set path that is highly detailed and winds through coastal beaches, caves and cliff sides. It is a beautiful game and might be one of the most beautiful games ever visually.

The day turning into night was a nice touch, even if at night you can end up completely blind by the dark. It seemed like the day and night wasn't random as the game claims, but if I died, it did become darker until I was unable to see.

The whole thing is very immerse with only 3 loading 'screens' once the game begins. The game is short and sweet, it doesn't overstay its welcome for what is basically a glorified tech demo of the Source engine. Supposedly no play through is the same with different audio for each run, but when I played a second time everything felt the same even if I didn't hear the audio at the exact same spot. I explored a lot more, but everything was the same.

You can also find it in a few bundles for less than $10 which then the price is worth it, but for 1 hour of an experience, I can't recommend it.

Dear Esther
NOTE - This game has been provided to me for free for review purposes.OverviewDear Esther is not a game, it is a walking simulator, and it is an experience. You walk on a deserted island, while your mind narrates some letters you wrote to Esther (hence the name). It focuses on the environment, the music, and the very detailed world to amaze and relax you.

The Pros:Beautiful - The game is beautiful. The world is very detailed, put together with much care and thought. Every scenery is breath-taking. Lots of dense foliage, rocky cliffs, and watery caves. Wonderful lightning as well! This is a walking simulator, of course. It is meant for you to behold, to explore, to enjoy.

Great Narrative - The narration is very well performed, and the contents are nice as well. Pay close attention and you will get a grasp of what happened in the past. I won't give details about them here. Experience them yourselves.

Relaxing - Besides buying a game, you also get free relax pills. This is excellent for when you are stressed out. Just enter the game, pick a chapter, and slowly walk, breathe in deeply, enjoy the beauty. Works like a charm!Cons:Linear - The game doesn't allow you to stray too far off your obviously paved paths. There are some occasions where you will encounter dead ends, but fear not. Just turn around, look for 5 seconds and the true path will surely be revealed to you.

One Hour - That is the approximate time you will spend walking around. This is the standard length of this type of games, and I am not disappointed with it's length. But the world is so well made, I just want to see more of it!
ConclusionFor a 2012 game, this was a fresh breath of air. Good looking, interesting, and highly relaxing. If you like this type of games, get it, you won't regret it.

Dear Esther
Well, I finally got around to playing this after years of languishing in my backlog (3 years I think?). Initially, I didnt play it because my computer couldnt handle it and it kept freezing. However, I realized that since I had upgraded my GCU, there was no reason not to, and on maxed out settings no less.

The game is in a word: BEAUTIFUL. Seriously, this might be one of the best looking games if not THE best looking game ever. It's probably a bit messed up, but I kept thinking that this is how Skyrim should have looked (not that Skyrim looked bad). Anyway, I digress. This is actual a mostly linear exploration game, where the story is revealed as you check out locations.

The story itself is the subject of much speculation and debate. One thing that is not debatable is that this isnt exactly a happy story being told, although possibly it has a hopeful ending depending on how you perceive the entirety of the story. I will give my take on that at the end of this review so it wont spoil the game for anybody who doesnt want to read it. It is told in narrative fashion.

The gameplay itself is simply you walking around, looking at stuff. You can zoom in, and that is exactly all your actual gameplay options.Keeps it pretty simple that way.

I mentioned the graphics before, but seriously, the attention to detail, even the minutia of a scene, is fairly well flawless. I can find zero fault with it whatsoever. You will be truly amazed with this aspect of the game in my opinion. There are some really jaw dropping images in this game. If you are curious, take a peak at the 140 or so screenshots I took, lol (but be wary of spoilers in them).

So, that is pretty much it. This game is perfection as far as walking simulator/exploration games go. I've seen nothing better yet. 10/10

Alright, now to the SPOILERS

It is my opinion that our protagonist is a ghost, revisitng his final days, his final regrets, and finally coming to terms with everything. I am of the opinion that, whether or not s/he was actually dead (the voice is male, but the reality of his gender is ambiguous at best), he was at the very least hallucinating and/or in a hospitalized, drug induced state of disorientation. His mind is clearly fractured and I think the people he references (himself, Jacobson, Esther Donnelly) are all parts of his own consciousness. The cause was obviously an auto wreck, although maybe this was just metaphor as well, and I coulnt help but think that he had lost a daughter, which was the source of his wrecked mind.

I dont know though. This story leaves a lot of your own subjective interpretation, which is actually another appealing aspect of this game

SPOILER/REVIEW END.

Dear Esther

Exploring the area allows you to further understand the story, with a well laid out path for you to follow. The tale also inspires extremely beautiful visuals for just being a Source game, known for their fast pased gaming titles previously released. At a slow and easy pase, there's absolutely no distractions from a unrelaxing experience, rather you'll actually get some sort of sadness out of it.

My experience playing it was great. I understood everything from the story, and was instantly hooked by the second of four chapters. The visuals were added bonuses. I loved every minute of it, up to the very end of the tale, with the game ending in the most scenic way possible, and provided a lovely score to it as well.

I encourage you to give this game a try, no matter the price, because at the price I got it ($2 USD) I feel I should have payed more for such a beautiful and relaxing tale.

Dear Esther
I've recently been exploring walking simulators and unfortunatley its been in descending order. Firewatch was engaging, interesting and immersive. Gone Home was slightly less immersive but still interesting enough to finish with fond thoughts.

Dear Esther is far and and way the worst of those three and really is just a terrible game. Even for a walking simulator it was far too light on the game aspect of being a game. The lack of an interact button should have been a giveaway. At least in the above mentioned games you can amuse yourself throwing mugs off towers or turning on every light in the house. In Dear Esther you wander (VERY SLOWLY) around a deserted Island, probably in the Northern Atlantic. While you do so fragments of a fairly obvious story are told to you in a disjointed, fragmented manner. This makes its tough to figure out what's going on but even more confusing is that most of the time the fragments have nothing to do with what you are looking at. The much touted soundtrack cuts in and out with awful editing, at first i thought it was to add to the disquieting atmosphere but in hindsight it was probably just lazy like the story.

Whats worse is that it felt like it was punishing me for exploring, as is basic instinct for gamers i dutifully went down every path and looked in every cave. Dear Esther
Dear Esther is the remake of an experimental mod for Half-Life 2. The original was developed by a research project at the University of Portsmouth led by professor and media researcher Dan Pinchbeck.

The first thing that is to say about Dear Esther is: It's not a game. It has no gameplay elements and its experimental approach makes it impossible to categorize. The author calls it a ghost story

Dear Esther
It's a poem where you get to walk in it. It's short so it won't have any chance to bore. It looks great, music is absolutely awesome and it makes you think and comment on it  (while you're alone in your room, talking to yourself)

If you have the patience of someone who even can't stand game intros (you idiots) stay away. Otherwise take a walk, listen to the wind and see the reflections of an old man on a beautiful island.

Dear Esther
Very emotional, very beautiful. The atmosphere is stunningly strong and solid. There is a feeling of something dark and mysterious always lingering around, makes you paranoid, scared. The poetry is hard to understand and I didn't know what the man was talking about half of the time but it was beautiful and mysterious. The Source engine is perfectly utilized as the environments and all the details are absolutely breathtaking. The music and sounds are significant parts of the atmosphere. The game design is so good it doesn't need any item pickups, puzzles or any sort of advanced controls and that's a very unusual feat. It just works on it's own as an emotional, artistic experience and I think that modern games should be heading that direction to support the gameplay, or as in case of Dear Esther, be completely symbiotical, to create unforgettable games.

Incredibly magical experience after this game. Everything fits together like a puzzle. You know the feeling, when you want to end the game (to know the ending) but also do not want to end (because the game is really good)? I had this feeling after finishing this game.

Story
The story begins on a deserted island in the middle of nowhere. Deserted island has one charm - nature. You have to go on a journey and with exploring the island, you also uncover parts of the story to the end, which is perfect.

Graphics
I don't know what to say. The waves beating against the rocks, cold wind, in dense fog shrouded lighthouse, amazing night beach, gorgeous moon, caves - such a visual experience offered by Dear Esther. However, I miss there any wild animals on the island (i've seen just one seagull).

Audio
Beautiful soundtrack by Jessica Curry plays a big role with a voice of a narrator, who is very important in the story games. I must also mention great sounds of nature - like the sea, the wind, falling drops of water in the cave.

Gameplay
Well, all you need to do in this game is just walk around and listen to a narrator, what is a great pity. Story like this just needs some investigations of items or searching for clues, eventually some easier puzzles. But I have to commend the developer console, which is enabled in the settings. Gameplay is really short (1-2 hours).

Price
I get this game for free from my friend but I think that 9,99 is enough because you can finish it in two hours.

Dear Esther
You walk around while the narrator reads you an irrelevant story. And pretty scenery?

I could get behind this game if the story being read at least felt relevant to the stuff I was seeing or doing, but otherwise it just all feels lazy and boring. The story itself isn't even very interesting, and uses annoyingly flowery prose. The graphics aren't quite pretty enough for me to get by enjoying sightseeing, and the setting/environment doesn't get my curiousity going.

Dear Esther
It's often difficult to write about something that means so much to you personally. For me, Dear Esther lies in category. Over the 2 and a half years that I've owned and loved this game, I've tried to write a review, but often gave up because I could never find the words to describe my thoughts on it.

It's one of the first and only games to move me emotionally, to make me truly  feel  something. A chilling sense of wonder about the beauty of life, and yet, the frailty of it all as well. Hope and hopelessness, both at once. Even as I wander down the same paths I have several times before, I find myself awed time and time again by the astounding beauty of something so simple as the view of a moonlit beach or a gentle breeze blowing through the grass. I load it up every so often, just to experience that world again. It's almost turned into a kind of private escape for me.

To truly enjoy and appreciate this game, you must let yourself become immersed. The sights, along with the sounds, are stunning and realistic. The music and voice acting are top notch, and easily lands itself high on my list of favorite game soundtracks. There is no gameplay to speak of; it's simply a walking, exploration game, as the background of the characters and island are revealed as you move along. That being said, the world as well as the characters are interesting and mysterious, and drive the desire to keep diving further into the island.

If you enjoy this type of game, do yourself a favor and get it. If you're not sure, get it, and remember to keep your mind open.

Larva Mortus
Larva Mortus is a top-down shooter. You go from room to room killing everything with up to eight different weapons. You can level up your stats, play through tons of levels, or you could just play something else.

The biggest problem with LM is that the difficulty is unbalanced. When you select your difficult setting, you're actually deciding on how much you want to be annoyed. This game features a lot of small enemies, some that leave trails of fire everywhere, spit multiple projectiles, and even randomly become invincible. The harder difficulties mean you have to put up with more of their crap, blow through all of your ammo, and possibly get killed in the process. The easiest setting seems like the best choice, since all difficulty really affects is how much the player does and takes damage. However, this setting also makes the game too easy...which I guess is to be expected...hm. Regardless, the alternative is pointless frustration.

Insta-death also starts to become a common theme later in the game. Devils and Champion Knights have attacks that'll kill you regardless of health or difficulty. Circle-strafing is a good method of avoiding this deadly attack, but these jerks tend to attack in groups, and other enemies lending a hand. Still, death really isn't very punishing, unless of course you managed to collect a rare item. There are a number of unique treasures that strengthen the player or offer a big XP bonus. These are lost if you die before completing the stage. Strangely, all of the achievements are tied to these rarities, you don't even get a cheevo for beating the game.

Larva Mortus is just a very dull game. Within 15 minutes you've seen most everything the game has to offer, and yet it just keeps going for hours, without purpose or entertainment value. There are a few moments of satisfaction, like blowing up a half-dozen monsters with a cannon, or shooting a werewolf in the face with a shotgun, but you can get more entertainment from playing a classic FPS like Doom. This game consists of running through rooms, occasionally finding something interesting, sometimes dying, and just never really caring.  Your free-time is more valuable than that.

Larva Mortus

Larva Mortus
Larva Mortus adds a sinister horror environment to the classic top-down arcade experience and with its surprisingly fun gameplay and ominous storytelling, it was very entertaining! Demonic rituals and classic horror creatures like werewolves, vampires and zombies fill up every corner of this game and are complimented by perfectly eerie, evil-sounding music and ambient whispers and noises that invade the players head. All of these aspects make up the spooky atmosphere Larva Mortus boasts, and the story, conveyed in an awesome graphic novel-type style, lives up to the games overall horrific demeanor and is actually very interesting. As you progress through the game, you'll discover new weapons at a pretty fast pace and you will have the opportunity to personalize your character a bit with upgrade points gained by leveling up. There are also A LOT of side missions to tackle other than the main story line which can really help you catch up if you're stuck on one of the main quests. One of the best things about the gameplay though is the fact that the levels are randomly generated. What that means is that if you do happen to die near the end of a level, you do have to play through it again, but the level will be re-designed with different rooms and monster spawns. This keeps the game from getting tedious on some of the more difficult parts. I did encounter a bug that would cause monsters to occasionally not spawn where they should. It doesn't affect the gameplay too much though, it just means that you have to run out of the room and back in to reset the spawns. I also really would have liked to see some multiplayer in Larva Mortus. Hopefully the developers will eventually get around to adding it. I think that would be a blast! Needless to say, the gameplay itself is smooth and enjoyable but there's nothing amazing about it alone. It's the combination of the gameplay and the demonic-horror style that really makes the game shine as a whole. In conclusion, I absolutely recommend Larva Mortus, especially if you're a horror fanatic like me.

Larva Mortus
A top-down horror shooter with very arcade-like action; you'd think it would be twin stick but it's not. The game is mission-based and you select from either story or randomly generated missions on a world map. Missions take place in a small, NES Zelda-style dungeon with an objective. Random missions give you a chance to level up, find artifacts and better weapons before progressing with the story.

Upon leveling, you can put points into stats like max health, regen, run speed and resistances, adding some lite rpg elements. You'll amass an arsenal of weapons you can switch between at any time, from the basic revolver and shotgun to flamethrowers and cannons.

Natively, the game runs at 1024x768, but looks fine and the Steam overlay works. The story is dull and short; most of your hours will come from grinding, due to the difficulty. Repetitive and shallow, I can't really recommend it with so many other games to play.

Gameplay

Our hero is easy to work with, which is definitely welcomed as combat always happens in cramped rooms. The mechanics is exactly this - you basically go from room to room and clean them out from monsters. Levels are generated randomly so you never know into what you go, but as long the level design regardless of the environment serves the same purprose, it doesn't really requires you some change in tactics or would surprise you in any way. Except the boss level templars, they don't really represent any serious force and usually are trying to make up for the lack of their power with rather high numbers. Exceptions might be missions where you need to rescue a certain number of civilians, blasting trough the rooms and just focusing on the rescue can save some time and nerves.
